Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Welcome to Weapons of Lore—a 5E supplement of wondrously magical weapons.

This book contains more than 140 magical weapons, including cursed, rechargeable, traditional, and weapons that increase in power. These unique creations can be handed out as treasure, provided as a reward, found in forgotten and lost locations, or be wielded by an adversary.

What's Inside?

This supplement contains several sections: Weapons of Lore, Cursed Weapons, Rechargeable Weapons, Enterprising Entrepreneurs, and Traditional Weapons.

  • Weapons of Lore. Weapons that increase in power as the attuned creature gains experience, completes tasks, or fulfills quests. Each of these entries includes the weapon's Lore, Location, Encounter Ideas, Progression Rules, and the Weapon's Progressing Statistics.

  • Cursed Weapons. Weapons that give and take.
  • Rechargeable Weapons. Weapons with limited charges, requiring the successful completion of a ritual or task to replenish the expended charges.
  • Enterprising Entrepreneurs. NPCs that can help the adventurers recharge their weapons.
  • Traditional Weapons. Weapons that do not increase in power, are free of curses, and recharge with a rest.

Weapons of Lore

The first section of this supplement contains Weapons of Lore. Each of these entries features lore, encounter ideas to give GMs inspiration on how to add the weapons to their campaign, and fantastic artwork. We also include progression rules for advancing the weapon's power (which rises in tandem with its rarity). The criteria for advancement might range from character level, character tier, a character's proficiency bonus, or quests and tasks that need to be completed. Examples of these tasks include sacrificing hit points or Hit Dice, ability score reduction, or the acquisition of additional weapon parts.

References to Cthulhu

Several weapons in this supplement reference Cthulhu, a concept created by H.P. Lovecraft whose work is considered public domain.

Attunement

Since Weapons of Lore advance as the character advances, the character must link themselves to the weapon, forming a bond so they can grow in power together. This is achieved via attunement. It is important to note that even the common version of a Weapon of Lore requires attunement. This is an atypical characteristic for a common magic weapon.

Some of the weapons have special attunement requirements. You may choose to remove these special requirements, but if you do, please note that they do help balance the weapon's long-term power so removing them might affect your campaign's difficulty curve.

Let's look at the Mariway's Staff as an example of special attunement requirements.

Common. Mariway's Cost. When you attune to this magic weapon, you must permanently sacrifice one Hit Die to the weapon. The sacrificed Hit Die empowers the weapon's future traits, increasing its unique ability as it progresses.

Uncommon. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Mariway's Health. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to expend a 1st-level spell slot to regain hit points equal to your Cost die roll + your spellcasting ability modifier.

Rare. When using Mariway's Health, you can now expend a higher level spell slot (up to a maximum of 3rd level) to increase the healing by one Cost die for each slot level above 1st.

A GM may find players, or their characters, ask why they must attune to a common magic item. If the GM wishes to keep the weapon's true nature secret, they may simply state, "you can tell there's something unique about this weapon," or, "this item feels more powerful than a common magic weapon," or, "you believe the item contains power yet to be unleashed," or, "when you attuned to this weapon, you felt something weave through your body, as if connecting to your very lifeforce." In addition, a successful Intelligence (Arcana) check, the DC of which is at the GM's discretion, might reveal the weapon is of special power. The use of the identify spell may also reveal the item is a Weapon of Lore. At this time, the GM may wish to divulge all the weapon's mechanical details to the player, allowing them to see the potential of the weapon's power and how it will change as its rarity increases.

Attuning at a Higher Level

Weapons of Lore are meant to be introduced to a character as a common magic item. This means a high-level NPC who wields the weapon cannot simply perish and leave a low-level character to inherit a high-level weapon. The weapons, when they are attuned to by the character, form a link, which resets the weapon anew as a common item. However, during attunement, the character can attempt a Wisdom saving throw (see Attunement DC in the Rarity and Level Equivalents Table). If the character succeeds on the saving throw for their current character level, the weapon begins at that corresponding level of rarity. If a high-level character fails against their character level DC, but succeeds versus the lower DCs, they gain the lower properties. For instance, a 17th-level paladin attuning to a Weapon of Lore rolls an 18 on their Wisdom saving throw; this result means the item begins at rare, instead of common or legendary rarity.

Magical Weapons

All Weapons of Lore, even those of common rarity, are magical.

Merchants

The untrained eye may have a difficult time recognizing a Weapon of Lore. Someone familiar with these weapons, like a seasoned merchant or weaponsmith, might recognize a Weapon of Lore by succeeding on a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check. Also, a scholar or historian succeeding on a DC 15 Intelligence (History) check may recall a tale or two about the weapon and know of its ability to progress in power.

Pricing and Selling

Pricing. Weapons of Lore are difficult to price. If the weapon's extraordinary ability to grow in power is known, then the merchant's selling price begins at 1d6 + 14 thousand gp, giving them a price range of 15,000 to 20,000 gp. Though the weapon may not be at its most powerful now, the merchant knows its true power. 15,000 to 20,000 gp is a fair starting price for a weapon of such quality and legend. A character successfully haggling with the merchant may see the price decrease by up to 20%.

If a merchant is unaware of the dormant weapon's potential, they price the weapon somewhere in the range of 250 to 1,000 gp and consider the weapon to be of common or uncommon rarity.

Selling. If the weapon has been successfully identified as a Weapon of Lore, a merchant offers to purchase the weapon for 1d6 + 4 thousand gp, giving them a range of 5,000 to 10,000 gp. The merchant knows that they will be hard pressed to find a suitable buyer for the weapon and will have to disclose the weapon's powers and progression conditions to the potential buyer.

If the weapon has not been correctly identified, a merchant may offer to purchase the weapon for 20% more or less gold depending on the weapon's current rarity. However, a merchant who purchases a Weapon of Lore for a large sum of gold, only to witness its power diminish when the character ends their attunement would find it difficult to trust the characters in the future and may even accuse them of swindling them.

Weapon Spell Casting

Many of the included weapons have the ability to cast spells. Those weapons all share the below Spell Casting trait.

  • Spell Casting. Spells cast from the weapon require that you hold the weapon.

Uses

Many weapons have Uses. For all Weapons of Lore, cursed, and traditional weapons, the following provides more information on how a weapon regains expended uses.

  • Once per long rest. Once used, you cannot use this property again until you finish a long rest.

  • Once per short rest. Once used, you cannot use this property again until you finish a short rest.

  • Twice per long rest. You may use this property twice, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Weapon Progression

Two things must occur for a weapon to progress in power. First, the condition for progression must be met. Secondly, the character must subsequently finish a long rest while in possession of the weapon.

Progressions may include an increase in the attack and damage modifiers or number of charges, increased save DCs, damage, and ranges of the weapon's properties, or the gaining of entirely new properties. In most cases, the weapon retains the properties from its previous version, but sometimes those properties are removed or replaced. Unless otherwise noted, assume the weapon retains its previous properties.

As an example, the Mist Guardian begins as a common weapon with the following property:

Misty Dew. While holding this magic weapon, you can use a bonus action to cause your space to be lightly obscured by a refreshing spray of cool mist. This mist disappears after 1 minute, or when you use this property again.

When the weapon progresses, the uncommon version adds this:

Ixkakaw's Virtue. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to create a rainbow arch in your space. Creatures of your choice that can see the rainbow can use their reaction to regain 2d4 hit points and neutralize one poison affecting it.

The rare version makes these further changes:

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Rain of Renewal. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to cause a pleasant-smelling rain to fall from the sky in a 10-footradi ¬us, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on you, which lightly obscures the area. The rain moves with you and falls for 1 minute, or until you dismiss it as a bonus action. Creatures within the rain immediately end any of the following conditions affecting them: &Reference[blinded], &Reference[paralyzed], &Reference[poisoned], or &Reference[stunned].

Progression Requirements

Though some of these weapons have more specific requirements before advancing in power, many progress as the character levels up.

Let us take a peek at the Pilum of the Lost Legion's special progression requirements.

Pilum of the Lost Legion progresses each time its wielder uses it to kill a creature with a CR that is 3 or more higher than their level. The wielder must use the spear to deal at least one third of the damage required to kill the creature. Once the spear has progressed, it cannot do so again until the wielder's level increases.

If you would rather, instead of using the special progression rules, you can simply have the weapon progress as the character gains levels according to the table below. Keep in mind that the special requirements are meant to help balance both the character's and the weapon's power.

Using the Rarity and Level Equivalents Table, a character receiving a Weapon of Lore at 1st level would see the weapon's power increase when the character reaches 5th level, for example.

NPCs and creatures can also wield Weapons of Lore. Reference the Creature CR column in the table below to determine what rarity the creature wields. For instance, a CR 6 NPC or creature wields the uncommon rarity of the weapon.

Magical Buffs

There are many items that might increase a character's proficiency bonus, ability score modifier, or other statistic whose increase is listed as a progression requirement for a Weapon of Lore. If the item that grants the increase requires attunement, then the increase satisfies the progression requirement of the Weapon of Lore for as long as the character is attuned to the modifying item. However, in the case of (most) consumables, the modification is short-lived and does not satisfy the progression requirement. For instance, both a belt of giant strength and a potion of giant strength modify a character's Strength score, but only the belt requires attunement and so only an increase granted by the belt would satisfy the progression requirement of a Weapon of Lore that progresses when the attuned character's Strength score increases. An increase granted by the potion would not.

If a character ends their attunement to the modifying item, the Weapon of Lore will regress in rarity if the progression requirement is no longer satisfied.

Not All Are Created Equal

This same rule applies if the character is affected by a spell or curse that permanently decreases or increases one or more of their abilities.

By design, the various weapons' traits are not equal in power. Not all campaigns are high magic, and we wanted to provide a wide range of choices for players and GMs.

Encounter Ideas

Each of the weapons in this supplement includes associated encounter ideas. We provide these as suggestions for how to introduce the weapon into your campaign, though you may come up with more fitting ways to tie these items to your world specifically.

Multiclassing

When a character multiclasses, the weapon's progression follows the rules of multiclassing, with the sum of the character's class levels equaling their character level. For example, a character with three levels of rogue and two levels of fighter is considered a 5th-level character.

Creating Your Own Weapons

Feel free to use these weapons as inspiration for creating your own Weapons of Lore. You might remove one or more properties from a listed weapon and replace them with properties of your own creation, or properties from another existing Weapon of Lore.

Cursed Weapons

The second section of this supplement contains cursed weapons. While these weapons may provide a boon, they also include a hindrance.

Curse Removal

Curses are typically removed via the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplRemoveCurs]{remove curse} spell. However, several of the following cursed weapons require the use of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplGreaterRes]{greater restoration} spell, requiring positive energy to offset the dark, foreign world curse. Greater restoration is a 5th-level spell, which means the curse remains in effect longer, since remove curse is a 3rd-level spell.

Rechargeable Weapons

The third section of the supplement contains unique rechargeable weapons. Rather than recharging after a short or long rest, these weapons require a character perform a special task, provide a monetary sacrifice or component, or something else. Each recharge requirement is listed in the weapon's text.

Enterprising Entrepreneurs

These groups or individuals provide unique services. Rather than a character waiting for a special event to occur to recharge their weapon, they might visit an Enterprising Entrepreneur who can perform the special task or provide the rare material.

Traditional Weapons

The remainder of this book contains traditional magic weapons which do not progress in power. You might also consider using properties from these weapons when creating your own Weapons of Lore.

Autumncrest.name: Autumncrest
Autumncrest.text:
"A natural life is a better life."

A soothing satyr with long gray hair braided artfully around their horns, dressed in plain, earthy-toned garments.

Autumncrest (satyr) is the kind, loving owner of Roam Free, a sprawling sanctuary for vulnerable creatures, aiming to replicate their natural habitat as closely as possible. They are proud of the life and home they provide for close to two hundred creatures who have been displaced over the years by careless adventurers, natural disasters, and city sprawling. The creatures at Roam Free vary from common to rare, and from great to small.

Free Range. Autumncrest knows the environment which they have created is the best option for creatures to thrive if rehoming is not possible. They are so confident that they will happily let folks explore Roam Free—supervised, of course. Guests are allowed to get up close and personal with the sanctuary's residents, with Autumncrest often showing off things like how the venom from their snakes is silkier and greener than those that are raised in tanks and/or outside of their natural living conditions. Harming the creatures will be met with a long term, perhaps even permanent, ban.

Encounter Idea

Escort Mission. The captain of the town guard is hiring adventurers to protect a creature being transported to Roam Free. Though the guards had tried several times to settle this relatively rare creature in the caves of the local mountains, it continues to ransack refuse piles in town. It is for the safety of both the townsfolk and the creature itself that it is being sent to Roam Free.

The Fearless Four.name: The Fearless Four
The Fearless Four.text:
"You can count on us!"

A young party, new to adventuring, who are eager to take on any jobs that might be too menial for more seasoned adventurers.

This newly formed party puts themselves out there any chance they get. They want novel experiences, coin, and a chance to spread their name far and wide. There is not much they would turn down as far as work goes, but the group gets most excited for jobs that send them to new places.

The Party

  • Timmal Zormorn. A bronze dragonborn thug with a sharp smile and strong desire to prove his worth.

  • Elnove Tinkercord. A bespectacled gnome priest who is always drawing in their sketchbook.

  • Song. A lithe orc acolyte who dresses in shades of purple and loves to show off her singing voice.

  • Presna Vuldro. A light-fingered high elf spy with a spunky attitude and habit of making herself laugh.

Trust Us. The Fearless Four are happy to take on almost any job, including those that require them to take magic items with them. To build trust with their clients, they willingly sign magical contracts or insist—in lieu of a contract—on leaving Timmal's magical (and expensive) ring as collateral before they attune to any item.

Encounter Idea

Ad-Venturers. Plastered in the center of the city's job board is an ad from The Fearless Four. It reads, "Need a valuable item watched or a pesky creature killed? Perhaps you don't have the time for a frivolous task. Hire us! There's no job too small."

Rapacious.name: Rapacious
Rapacious.text:
"I have what you need."

A blue tiefling merchant with a mischievous smirk and short, black hair who carries a briefcase with her at all times.

Rapacious (mage) lurks in places where adventurers who have acquired rechargeable items spend time. It is as though she can sense these unique items and is guided towards them. While she behaves in a reserved manner, she knows how to negotiate and get the best deal for herself and whomever she serves. That being said, it is almost impossible to locate her again after a purchase has been made. She will find you.

Rapacious sells the following magic items:

  • Bag of Temperature Control (50 gp). A leather bag that keeps a creature carcass fresh for 1 day before losing its magic. This allows for remains that must be used for recharging magic items within 1 hour of dying to be used within 24 hours of dying.

  • Bottled Breath (250 gp). A vial of iridescent, swirling, dragon's breath captured from a high-level dragon that requires special gloves to handle.

  • Energy Bank (500 gp). Locked inside of a small, lead lined box, this stone is carved with runes and has enough magical energy to fully recharge one item.

  • Extend-A-Use Gem (1,000 gp). A milky white gem. While holding it, you can use an action to cause a magic item of your choice within 10 feet to regain up to two charges. Then the gem disintegrates.

  • Success Amulet (1,000 gp). This ruby and gold amulet allows the wearer to automatically succeed on one ability check or saving throw required to recharge a weapon. Then the magic evaporates and it becomes a mundane amulet worth one-tenth of its original value.

Target Acquired. Rapacious seeks out the party members who have rechargeable items with an eerie accuracy and approaches them when their coin pouches are heaviest. She is confident that at least one item in her briefcase of goodies will catch their attention.

Encounter Idea

Celebration. Rapacious finds the adventurers while they are celebrating a big win and—more importantly—a big payday. Smiling and full of celebratory energy, she buys them a round. Once they have shared the story of their success with her, she lays down her briefcase and tells them she wants to ensure they only have success stories to share in the future.

Wize Socki.name: Wize Socki
Wize Socki.text:
"It's wild in there, y'all!"

An eccentric human with a rotund stomach, shoulder-length brown hair, and a rat-tail down to the middle of his back.

Wize (druid) is a fun-loving, loud man in his mid-thirties. As the owner of Socki's Wild Animal Adventures, Wize is pure chaotic energy. The wild animal park is relatively remote, but attracts a large number of tourists each year. He loves filling his park with unique and sometimes dangerous creatures. Everyone entering must pay the fee, sign the magically binding waiver, and enter at their own risk.

On the Down-Low. Wize has an affinity for all of the creatures that inhabit his wild animal park, but for the right amount of coin and/or items, he is willing to let adventurers hunt and kill one creature for their own needs.

Encounter Idea

Road Trip. The adventurers come across a caravan of families who have a couple of days' travel ahead of them. A group of kids animatedly tell the party that they are heading to Socki's Wild Animal Adventures and are especially eager to see some rare and scary creatures.

Zilzol & Zaldralk.name: Zilzol & Zaldralk
Zilzol & Zaldralk.text:
"Yeses! Brings on the storms."

Storm-chasing goblin siblings with round eyes, pale yellow skin, and wild senses of adventure.

Zilzol (goblin), the elder sibling, is the strategist. She is smart and knows the best ways to get in and out of hair-raising weather. Zaldralk (goblin) is younger and a little bit more rambunctious. He is also the one who finds, tracks, and chases down storms with uncanny accuracy. Neither of them act particularly worried about their lives as they dive into lightning storms, pursue blizzards, or stalk tornados and hurricanes.

In Pursuit. Zilzol and Zaldralk are almost always tracking a couple of storms. It would be no problem for them to aid adventurers in finding the weather system they need. Better yet—and for the right price—these goblins will attune to an item and happily jump into the storm themselves. Honestly, they were probably going in anyway.

Encounter Idea

Forecast is Forewarned. A small town has its windows and doors all boarded up. There is some damage done, but overall, everything is relatively safe. Townsfolk are returning as the adventurers pass through. The party overhears folks praising the knowledge of Zilzol and Zaldralk, who saved their lives by predicting the path of a massive storm.
