Blob Barb.name: Blob Barb
Blob Barb.text:
Weapon (Dart), Rare

This gray dart has a sharp tip, but the shaft feels soft and tacky.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Caustic. A creature hit by an attack using this weapon takes an additional [[/r 1d6[acid]]]{1d6 acid damage} at the start of your next turn as it dissolves into a slime that spreads across the creature's skin. If the target is wearing nonmagical armor, the armor is partly corroded and takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed if the penalty reduces its AC to 10.

Encounter Ideas

  • Liquid Assets. An evil cult intends to dissolve urban populations with oozes. Cultists unleash oozes on the nearest city. Glubrus, a cult fanatic, leads the group and is armed with a handful of blob barbs.
  • One Person's Trash. After battling an otyugh, the party discovers a holster of 1d8 + 2 blob barbs in the refuse.
  • Dump the Slime Bucket. An underground movement seeks to overthrow the corrupt Queen Annalia (noble), requesting the party's help. They offer a quiver of blob barbs to defeat Licinius, captain of the guard (veteran).

Bluering.name: Bluering
Bluering.text:
Weapon (Shortsword), Rare, (Requires Attunement)

A mysterious-looking, blue-ringed octopus wraps itself around this weapon's blade.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 1d6[poison]]]{1d6 poison damage} on a hit. If you score a critical hit against a creature with this weapon, it must also succeed on a [[/save constitution 14]]saving throw or be &Reference[stunned] until the end of its next turn.

Mucosa. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to cause the weapon's magic to seep from your pores, coating you and your belongings in a toxic mucus for 1 minute. For the duration, whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, mucus splashes from you and the attacker takes [[/r 1d6[poison]]]{1d6 poison damage}. Fight or Flight. When you become &Reference[frightened] or take damage, roll a d6. On a 1, the weapon automatically activates Mucosa, expending its use if it has not already been used.

Encounter Ideas

  • Gross…Yuck…Ouch! As a character battles an enemy, they experience the gross and stinging sensation of the weapon's Mucosa property.
  • Well, That's Interesting. While perusing a merchant's wares, the characters notice a bizarre-looking octopus crawling along a shortsword. The merchant explains that the creature never leaves the weapon, and seems to thrive without food and water.
  • Bodyguard. The weapon's Mucosa property activates in response to its wielder being &Reference[frightened] or unknowingly attacked by one of the characters.

Catalyst.name: Catalyst
Catalyst.text:
Weapon (Rapier), Rare

A fancifully crafted rapier with a guard and hilt decorated in a chaotic pattern of smooth red and white gemstones.

This magic weapon has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can immediately expend 1 charge to do one of the following, requiring no additional action:

  • Move up to half your speed.
  • Cast a cantrip.

Make one melee attack with a +2 bonus to the attack and damage roll. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to expend 1 charge to do one of the following:

  • Regain hit points equal to 1d4 plus your level.
  • Move up to half your speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Encounter Ideas

  • Laughing Foe. As the characters battle a villainous noble named Jeffrey Cee, their foe laughs when damaged while blurting phrases like "Haha!" or "Do your best!"
  • Dead Bard. While seeking refuge from a billowing storm, the characters find a dilapidated house. Inside, the decomposed remains of a neatly dressed woman holding a rapier sits in a rotting chair next to a cold fireplace.
  • Prized Possession. Noting the adventurer's interest in magic items, a local merchant gasps and exclaims, "Wait right here!" as she rummages through piles of merchandise. She then pulls out a dusty, wooden case and opens it, revealing Catalyst. She looks at them with large eyes while saying, "This! This is my most prized possession!" In truth, she had completely forgotten about the sword until the adventurers arrived, and she has no knowledge of its properties. She makes up grand stories if asked about its history.

Colossus Anchor.name: Colossus Anchor
Colossus Anchor.text:
Weapon (Greataxe), Common

This rusty, barnacle-encrusted anchor has sharpened edges, though the real danger comes from its prodigious weight.

While holding this magic weapon, you have advantage on saving throws against being moved against your will. If your Strength score is lower than 16, you have disadvantage on attack rolls made with this weapon.

Encounter Ideas

  • Sink or Swim. As the characters cross the sea, a sea hag wields a colossus anchor on a chain and attempts to drag their ship beneath the waves.
  • Draconic Boon. The characters discover a bronze dragon wyrmling trapped beneath a shipwrecked boat. Once freed, the wyrmling sharpens the ship's anchor on its scales and gifts it to the characters.
  • Lady of the Lake. Local legends say a merfolk dwells in a nearby lake, dispensing unusual weapons (such as the colossus anchor) upon adventurers who please her with songs and tales.

Deep’s Reach.name: Deep’s Reach
Deep’s Reach.text:
Weapon (Whip), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This whip is crafted from a giant octopus's dark tentacle, attached to a smooth, pink coral handle. The tentacle is magically alive and makes wet, squishy noises as it squirms and writhes.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an additional [[/r 2d6[cold]]]{2d6 cold damage} on a hit. This weapon's reach property adds 10 feet to your reach with it instead of the usual 5 feet.

Cephalopod. While attuned to this weapon, you can breathe air and water, have advantage on climbing related checks, and have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Suckered. This weapon has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to attempt to wrap the tentacle around the target. The target must succeed on a [[/save constitution 15]]saving throw or be &Reference[restrained] until the start of your next turn, when you can expend another charge to force your target to make another saving throw. You cannot attack using Deep's Reach while a target is &Reference[restrained] this way.

Encounter Ideas

  • Plea for Help. A merfolk village asks the adventurers to rid them of their nemesis, Ssketha, a sahuagin known for his vicious whip.
  • Crab Food. Along a beach, a pack of giant crabs chase after what looks like a long snake (spoiler: it is Deep's Reach). The weapon is grateful, and "hugs" its rescuers.
  • Drowning Hole. A lizardfolk tribe will not go near a stagnant bog, where many of their members have drowned. Deep's Reach is stuck at the bottom, reaching at anything to pull itself out.

Confetti.name: Confetti
Confetti.text:
Weapon (Longsword), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Colorful tassels dangle from this finely crafted sword's pommel. Its blade rests inside a polka dot sheath.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Confetti. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to speak the command word, causing the weapon to explode into a 20-foot-radius sphere of colorful confetti centered on you until the end of your next turn. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured. However, you can see through this sphere. A wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it. At the end of the duration, the weapon reforms in your hand or its polka dot sheath, whichever you choose.

Encounter Ideas

  • Hazard Prime. A traveling street performer calling herself Hazard Prime uses the weapon's power to fascinate spectators.
  • I'll Take That. A cunning spy uses the weapon's power to increase the likelihood of successfully picking pockets.
  • Surprise! While battling a foe, the characters witness their adversary's weapon explode into a cloud of confetti. Soon after, the confetti cloud disappears, and so too has their foe.

Devil’s Tongue.name: Devil’s Tongue
Devil’s Tongue.text:
Weapon (Greatsword), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This flamberge has a hilt resembling a devil's head. Its blade, a woven fibrous pattern of bronze and red metal, emerges from the fiend's mouth.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Tongue Lash. This weapon has 6 charges, and regains 1d6 expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a Large or smaller creature with an attack using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to tongue lash the target. The target is &Reference[grappled] (escape DC 13) as the weapon wraps around it. Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained], and the weapon cannot attack another target. While &Reference[grappled] this way, the target takes 2d6 + [[/r (1)[slashing]]]{1 slashing damage} at the start of each of your turns.

Encounter Ideas

  • Honey-tongued Devil. Sebraxia, an erinyes wielding a devil's tongue, is the king's bodyguard and advisor. The king, believing Sebraxia is an angel, obeys her orders, starting unnecessary wars and mistreating the citizens. A local priest discovered Sebraxia's true nature and asks the party for help.
  • Tongue-Lashing. Duchess Dilara (noble) hires the party to recover a devil's tongue from Blackliver the Pirate (bandit captain).
  • Cat Got Your Tongue. A dead deer is found with spiral-shaped lacerations. Locals suspect an unknown constrictor snake and want it hunted. The deer was in truth killed by Chui, a weretiger wielding a devil's tongue.

Elysian Glaive.name: Elysian Glaive
Elysian Glaive.text:
Weapon (Glaive), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This gleaming polearm glows with inner light, bathing all around it in golden brilliance. Along the length of its haft is carved a prayer, only decipherable to those speaking the celestial tongue of the heavens: "Oblivion awaits those who stand against the divine light."

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 2d8[radiant]]]{2d8 radiant damage} to Undead and Fiends.

Golden Shine. The weapon's golden blade continually emits bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet.

Return. As long as the weapon is within sight, the wielder can use a bonus action to speak the command word "return" to summon it to their hand.

Spellcasting. Once per long rest, you can use your action to cast flame strike (save DC 15).

Encounter Ideas

  • Fallen Celestial. Plummeting from the sky in a ball of radiant fire, a mortally wounded celestial crashes to the ground in front of the party. As a bloodstained elysian glaive falls from its grasp, the heavenly creature gasps with its last breath "Beware, they are coming."
  • Arcane Collector. Held within a glass case, etched with all manner of protective runes, an elysian glaive is the prized possession of an eccentric collector of magical artifacts. They are only willing to entertain the thought of letting it go in exchange for something equally as rare and powerful.
  • Storm Giant's Accessory. Helsif the Thunderer, a storm giant lord, is best known for two things: his love of battle and his ostentatious use of an elysian glaive as a toothpick.

Falling Stars.name: Falling Stars
Falling Stars.text:
Weapon (Dart), Rare (Requires Attunement)

These small, star-shaped darts are made from meteoric iron, and each has a silvery-blue sheen and is frigid to the touch.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an additional 1d6 radiant and [[/r 1d6[cold]]]{1d6 cold damage} on a hit.

Encounter Ideas

  • Mage. The adventurers encounter an angry mage. The mage keeps falling stars for back-up.
  • Monastery. The adventurers are resting at a local monastery when renegade monks attack. The leader of these renegades is armed with these darts.
  • Ogre's Cave. An ogre has moved into a nearby cave and is preying on innocent travelers. A set of falling stars hangs on the cave wall.

Firebug.name: Firebug
Firebug.text:
Weapon (Flail), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

Thick chains attach five large metal fireflies to this weapon's leather wrapped handle.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Luminate. As a bonus action, you can speak the command word to cast faerie fire (save DC 14), or to cause the flail's heads to glow a greenish yellow, creating bright light in a 15-foot radius for one hour. You can use each of these features once, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Encounter Ideas

  • Guide. The adventurers hire a local guide named Esmerelda Pinebark (halfling scout) to take them to a hidden, undead-riddled ruin rumored to hold a lost treasure. Esmerelda wears a leather vest with her name printed on it, below which reads, "Let's Explore Together!" During the journey, Esmerelda uses the flail to light the way.
  • Lost Ruin. The adventurers find a lost ruin. The emaciated carcass of Esmerelda Pinebark and three young adventurers are found within, as well as Firebug and several ravenous zombies.
  • Ettin Terror. While traveling, the adventurers encounter Esmerelda and an elderly explorer named Hobarth Toothwiggle (orc veteran with disadvantage on attack rolls) fending off an aggressive ettin named Blue Eyes. If the adventurers intervene, Hobarth realizes he may need the party's assistance and offers them half the recovered treasure if they accompany him and Esmerelda on their journey to loot a hidden ruin. He is open to negotiations. He just wants one last adventure!

Flip Switch.name: Flip Switch
Flip Switch.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Rare (Requires Attunement)

One side of this dagger's blade is black, the other side white.

Twice per long rest, immediately before making an attack with this magic weapon, you can flip the weapon in the air, catching it as it falls. Roll a d6. On a 1–3, the weapon lands with the blade's white area exposed and you gain a +5 bonus to your attack roll. On a 4–6, the weapon lands with the blade's black area exposed and you have a −5 penalty to your attack roll.

Encounter Ideas

  • Cheeky Rogue. Flint Gold, a smooth-talking rogue (assassin), continuously flips Flip Switch while he discusses business or shares rumors with the adventurers.
  • 50/50. The adventurers find themselves in a battle with Flint Gold and his gang of five thugs. During the confrontation, Flint flips the dagger and activates its special property, which may be good or bad for him.
  • Sweeten the Pot. Flint hires the characters to transport a rare painting to a local collector. In addition to the 50 gp payment, he sweetens the pot by including Flip Switch.

Folded Space.name: Folded Space
Folded Space.text:
Weapon (Shortbow), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

A bow carved from otherworldly lumber sourced from each of the Outer Planes, magically fused into one piece of wood, and strung with a beam of pure astral energy.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, and ranged attacks made with this weapon do not suffer disadvantage due to a hostile creature being within 5 feet of you.

Folded Space. The weapon has 12 charges, and regains 1d10 + 2 expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you make an attack with this weapon, you can expend charges to use one of the following abilities.

  • Omnidirectional Arrow (1 charge). The attack ignores half and three-quarters cover.
  • Step Through Space (5 charges). If your attack hits and the target is within the weapon's normal range, you can immediately teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the target.

Encounter Ideas

  • Planar Nexus. The adventurers encounter a nexus of overlapping planes, a confluence of various locations and structures. This bow lies at the center of the warped labyrinth.
  • Planes Walker. A mysterious traveler appears before the party seemingly from nowhere. In exchange for escort, he offers this bow.
  • Phantom Thief. A thief uses this bow's teleportation abilities to become nigh uncatchable. Though with each new

Hammer of Dismantling.name: Hammer of Dismantling
Hammer of Dismantling.text:
Weapon (Light Hammer), Uncommon

This gnomish ball-peen hammer jitters in its wielder's hand, eager to take apart anything it touches.

Once per long rest, as an action, you can touch a constructed nonmagical object no larger than a 10-foot cube that is not being wielded or worn with this magic weapon. A shockwave passes over the object, instantly disassembling it into its component parts. The parts land harmlessly on the ground in the object's space.

If the object was locked, such as a door or chest, you must make an attack roll with the hammer against the lock's AC, disassembling the object on a success.

Encounter Ideas

  • Safecracker. A gnomish rogue is using a hammer of dismantling to steal from all the city's banks and shops, taking apart their safes in seconds.
  • Flat Tire. A crew of bandits ambush the characters by instantly dismantling the wheels on their carriage. When the party climbs out to investigate, the bandits strike!
  • Carpentry Contest. A logging town is holding a festival where participants build and take apart furniture as fast as possible, with the winners earning a hammer of dismantling.

Hornets’ Nest.name: Hornets’ Nest
Hornets’ Nest.text:
Weapon (Spear), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Several hornets fly around a large hornets' nest magically attached 10 inches below this spear's point.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an additional [[/r 2d6[piercing]]]{2d6 piercing damage} on a hit.

Lie Detector. Once per long rest, you can speak the command word to cause a swarm of hornets to billow from the nest, creating a soft buzz of wings. For the next minute, any creature within 30 feet of the weapon must succeed on a [[/save charisma 15]]saving throw when it attempts to lie to you. On a failed save, you know the creature has lied and the hornets become irritated and buzz loudly. At the end of the duration, the hornets disappear.

Angry Hornets. Once per long rest, you can speak the command word to cause a swarm of hornets to rush from the nest, targeting one creature you can see within 60 feet. The target must make a [[/save dexterity 15]]saving throw. A creature takes [[/r 10d6[piercing]]]{10d6 piercing damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Upon inflicting their damage, the hornets disappear.

Encounter Ideas

  • Goblin Truth Seeker. Fetid Feet, a goblin gladiator, works with many crime lords who hire him to accompany them when meeting with "clients". Fetid uses the spear's power while the crime lord or their thugs question individuals.
  • Kick the Nest. While traveling cross country, the adventurers encounter Hornets' Nest, though it is hidden in an overgrown field. A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check notices the hidden spear. On a failed check, they kick the hornet's nest and activate the weapon's Angry Hornets property, which targets the kicker.
  • What's All This? While being questioned by the town guard, their leader Giovanni Kleb (human veteran) uses the spear's power during the interrogation to test the characters' truthfulness.

Bolstering Blowgun.name: Bolstering Blowgun
Bolstering Blowgun.text:
Weapon (Blowgun), Uncommon

These mithral forearm crutches appear to be ordinary crutches with hollow handles.

This magic weapon takes the form of a pair of hollow crutches which adjust to fit a creature of Small to Large size.

Bolster. This weapon has 4 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, instead of dealing the weapon's normal damage, you can expend 1 charge to give the attack one of the following properties:

  • Neuroshock. The target takes [[/r 1d4[lightning]]]{1d4 lightning damage} and must succeed on a [[/save constitution 12]]saving throw or be &Reference[stunned] until the end of its next turn.
  • Poison. The target must succeed on a [[/save constitution 12]]saving throw or take [[/r 1d4[poison]]]{1d4 poison damage} and become &Reference[poisoned] for 1 minute.
  • Susceptible. The target must succeed on a [[/save wisdom 12]]saving throw or be &Reference[charmed] by you for 10 minutes or until you or your companions do anything harmful to it. The &Reference[charmed] creature regards you as a friendly acquaintance. When the effect ends, the creature knows it was &Reference[charmed] by you.

Encounter Ideas

  • Shoot Your Cuffs. A noble, Baron Lorcustin, was recently assassinated by a &Reference[poisoned] dart. His family hires the party to investigate. The assassin was a disabled chef who sought revenge after the baron forced her to cook her pet chicken.
  • Darting Away. A city guard released a bandit from jail at the request of a disabled beggar (uses the spy stat block, but replaces their hand crossbow with a bolstering blowgun). The beggar and bandit have disappeared, and the guard insists the beggar &Reference[poisoned] her.
  • Don't Shoot the Burglar. A rogue, Jamie Roofhop (uses the spy stat block, but replaces their hand crossbow with a bolstering blowgun), is suspected of stealing from the city treasury, and city guards cannot catch her. Jamie did steal from the treasury, but she vaults across rooftops with her crutches, so good luck!

Dimension Dart.name: Dimension Dart
Dimension Dart.text:
Weapon (Dart), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This dart is decorated with chalks and inks that form runes of conjuration magic.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Dimension Walk. This weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charge when you finish a long rest. You can use an action to expend 1 charge to throw the weapon to an unoccupied space within range and roll a d20. On a 2–20, you are teleported to this location and can bring along objects as long as their weight does not exceed what you can carry. You can also bring one willing creature of your size or smaller who is carrying gear up to its carrying capacity. The creature must be within 5 feet of you when you use this property. On a 1, you and your belongings, as well as any willing creature, are instead teleported to a harmless demiplane, where you remain until the end of your next turn, when you reappear in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of your target. Creatures within the demiplane are &Reference[incapacitated].

Encounter Ideas

  • Monastic Majesty. A monk in the party successfully catches an oncoming dimension dart using Deflect Missiles.

  • Child's Play. The sound of children shrieking in joy reaches the party. The eldest of the children is showing off by tossing a dimension dart across a field, disappearing, then reappearing at the dart's target. They clearly do not know the extent of what they possess.
  • Bamf! The party is being chased by an assassin when suddenly a dimension dart careens over their shoulders, and the pursuer appears directly in front of them.

Mind Pick.name: Mind Pick
Mind Pick.text:
Weapon (War Pick), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Made of steel with a green patina, the head of this war pick is stylized as an exposed brain with tentacles, which twist together to form the pick's spike.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 1d6[psychic]]]{1d6 psychic damage} on a hit.

Telepath. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to cast detect thoughts (save DC 15), requiring no concentration. For the duration of the spell, you can focus your mind on only the target, and on subsequent turns you can probe deeper into the target's thoughts using a bonus action instead of an action.

Encounter Ideas

  • Astral Serendipity. Lost in the Astral Plane, the adventurers stumble into a pocket dimension dungeon. Near the end, they can find this war pick atop a pile of gems and coins.
  • Inquisitor's Tool. In the dungeons of a castle, a royal inquisitor uses this war pick to simultaneously torture and question prisoners. The adventurers are hired to free a captive.
  • Mind Hunters. A bounty is out on psionic monsters, with an extra reward for bringing back an undamaged brain. If the party does, part of the brain is used to craft this war pick.

Ki-Flame Blade.name: Ki-Flame Blade
Ki-Flame Blade.text:
Weapon (Shortsword), Rare (Requires Attunement by a Monk)

This bluish steel sword has a shimmering gold ribbon tied to its pommel. The blade is heavy in the hands of a conflicted soul, but for a peaceful one, it is light as wood.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls using this magic weapon.

Ki Flame. When you spend 1 or more ki points as part of a monk feature while holding the blade, it ignites with blue flames. Until the end of your next turn, attacks with the blade deal an extra [[/r 1d6[fire]]]{1d6 fire damage} on a hit. This damage increases to 2d6 against incorporeal creatures.

Ki Beam. As an action, you can point the blade and spend 3 ki points to create a beam of blue flames in a 30-foot-long, 5-foot-wide line. Each creature in the area must make a [[/save dexterity]] saving throw against your ki save DC, taking [[/r 6d6[fire]]]{6d6 fire damage} on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Incorporeal creatures make this saving throw with disadvantage. Once per long rest, you can use this property without spending ki points.

Encounter Ideas

  • Revenge Quest. The characters discover a dead succubus with a ki-flame blade driven into her chest. Unbeknownst to them, the succubus's incubus partner seeks vengeance against the blade's wielder.
  • Heirloom Blade. A renowned martial artist is seeking a worthy heir for her ki-flame blade by roaming the land and attacking monks.
  • Dark Ritual. The characters stumble into a group of malevolent ghosts performing a dark ritual to destroy a ki-flame blade, which they fear could be used to destroy them.

Motley’s Fool.name: Motley’s Fool
Motley’s Fool.text:
Weapon (Rapier), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This weapon's colorful pommel and handle are shaped like a musical treble clef, while its guard is embossed with musical notes.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Raucous. Once per short or long rest, if you cast vicious mockery while holding this weapon, you can target one additional creature within 30 feet of the original target.

Encounter Ideas

  • Bad Slams. While battling an adversary who mocks the characters, they notice their opponent's mocking impacts more than one of them, which is very odd.
  • Love Me True. A jester named Love Me True (an acolyte who knows vicious mockery) performs in a tavern, waving the rapier about as they joke and pun. As they mock the crowd, the characters notice that Love Me True's puns are very impactful.
  • Reward. As a reward for their good deeds, the party's bard is awarded the rapier by their guild.

Pachyderm’s Pride.name: Pachyderm’s Pride
Pachyderm’s Pride.text:
Weapon (Mace), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This iron mace is fashioned to resemble an elephant, with the animal's head and ears forming the weapon's head, and its trunk as the shaft.

This magic weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. As an action, you can expend 1 charge to activate one of the following properties. The save DC of each property is equal to your passive Performance score (10 + Performance skill).

Stomp. You heavily stomp your feet on the ground, casting thunderwave.

Trumpet. You loudly mimic an elephant's trumpeting while using your arm to represent its trunk, casting shatter. When you cast the spell this way, it is centered on you and you are immune to its effects.

Encounter Ideas

  • Trumpet's Folly. While battling a gaggle of ruffians, the group's bandit captain leader is seen stomping about and mimicking an elephant.
  • Reward. A village sends the adventurers on a quest to defeat a wyvern that has been eating their livestock. If successful, the characters are awarded Pachyderm's Pride.
  • Sanctuary. While exploring, the adventurers encounter an elephant graveyard. Found amid the many massive bones is Pachyderm's Pride.

Refutation.name: Refutation
Refutation.text:
Weapon (Longsword), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Bickering faces are engraved on this sword's blade.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Anathema. When you score a critical hit against a creature with this weapon, roll a d6. On a 1–5, the target suffers the effects of a bestow curse (save DC 16), on a 6, the spell targets you instead. When cast this way, the spell does not require concentration and the nature of the curse is determined at random by rolling a d4. If the spell has targeted you, the target of your original attack is treated as the caster of the spell.

Encounter Ideas

  • Bad Ape. An ape (perhaps in the jungle or an escapee from a local zoo or traveling circus) has stolen Refutation from the hip of a passerby. The beast swings the blade about, attacking anyone who comes too close.
  • Witch Way. Knowing the weapon's power to both curse its wielder and those it damages, a sea hag gives the weapon to the characters as reward for completing an easy task.
  • Ante Up. While playing a game of chance, an explorer bitten by the gambling bug offers Refutation either as an ante, or to raise the pot.

Galifinaka’s Dagger.name: Galifinaka’s Dagger
Galifinaka’s Dagger.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Very Rare, Requires Attunement

This dagger's blade is fashioned from crystal and resembles a fancy eye mask.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Spellcasting. The weapon has 4 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. As a bonus action, while holding the blade to your face like a mask, you can expend charges to cast the following spells: comprehend languages (1 charge), darkvision (2 charges), see invisibility (2 charges) Each spell's duration is unchanged, but you only gain its benefits while you peer through the blade's eyeholes. Additionally, when you cast comprehend languages this way, you can only understand written text.

Encounter Ideas

  • Lost Explorer. The adventurers encounter a lost explorer in a ruin filled with dark spirits. The explorer (assassin) is found holding the blade to their face and complains about unseen dangers.
  • Petrified. While exploring a forgotten keep, the weapon is found clutched in the hand of a statue. The weapon's owner did not know it was useless against the ruin's medusa.
  • Traveling Scholar. A dragon bequeathed the weapon to a rather scholarly minion named Cyrex (kobold). Cyrex now travels the realm, reading any text she can find. She funds her travels by charging a few gold pieces to read foreign text for others.

Ram Hammer.name: Ram Hammer
Ram Hammer.text:
Weapon (Warhammer), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

Intricately adorned with outlaid silver goats and horns, this hammer was a prize for the greatest cleric-shepherd of the region. It was given as a reward for using a trip of goats to save a town from an ogre assault.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Bleat. When you hit a creature with this weapon, it makes a loud "bahhh!", audible to anyone within 30 feet, and the target takes an additional [[/r 1d6[force]]]{1d6 force damage}.

Encounter Ideas

  • Prized Trophy. The town hall where the cleric often resided still holds this weapon on display and celebrates Goat's Day annually.
  • Blacksmith Store. While the weapon is well-decorated, a blacksmith has no use for a warhammer that makes an odd noise. It can be bought for a price or a favor.
  • Ogre Lair. Ironically, the warhammer now rests on the belt of an ogre champion. The ogre finds the weapon funny, but it makes a nice fashion statement.

Sea Dogs.name: Sea Dogs
Sea Dogs.text:
Weapon (Handaxe), Rare (Requires Attunement)

A collection of serrated shark teeth forms the blade of this crude wooden handaxe.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Blood Frenzy. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. As a bonus action, you can expend 1 charge to trigger a bloodlust until the end of your turn. For the duration, you have advantage on attack rolls made with this weapon against creatures that do not have all their hit points.

Encounter Ideas

  • Outrageous Sam. The half-red dragon veteran Outrageous Sam is well known in local bars and taverns. Sam often over imbibes, which causes him to wave the handaxe in the air while openly challenging anyone in the bar who thinks they can best him.
  • Merfolk Prince. While traveling or camping along a water source, the adventurers are approached by a merfolk prince named Giovalia. The prince explains that a violent brigand (orc berserker) murdered his brother and then absconded with his belongings. Giovalia asks them to find the killer—an orcish brute clad in bones and leading a band of war-painted marauders. He also explains the killer might be carrying his brother's shark tooth handaxe.
  • Clever Hobgoblin. While battling a group of hobgoblins, the adventurers experience the group's otherwise disciplined leader suddenly making wild, bloodthirsty, and highly effective attacks.

Hushed Kiss.name: Hushed Kiss
Hushed Kiss.text:
Weapon (Scimitar), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

An ivory hilt decorates this well-crafted scimitar.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Whispers. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to create a 60-foot-radius sphere of sound dampening magic which is centered on the weapon and moves with it. Within the sphere, sounds travel only half as far and spells with a verbal component have their range halved. This effect lasts for 1 minute, ending early if you fall &Reference[unconscious] or lose contact with the weapon.

Encounter Ideas

  • Whispering Fool. Torvis Gnatwing, a gnome bounty hunter (bandit captain), has been hired to thwart the adventurers. Torvis and his non-spellcasting bandits ambush the characters, using the weapon's ability to stymie spellcasters while utilizing potions of speed to gain the upper hand.
  • Heckler. Butrard Bolley, an obnoxious noble, heckles a street performer then uses the weapon's power to thwart the performer's retorts. Though the performer is obviously agitated and appears to be yelling, their words come out as whispers.
  • Mage Killer, Inc. A group of sellswords calling themselves Mage Killer, Inc. use the weapon to get close to their arcanist foes. The city's mages hire the adventurers to dispatch the sellswords.

Sea Maiden’s Whip.name: Sea Maiden’s Whip
Sea Maiden’s Whip.text:
Weapon (Whip), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This magical whip is braided from strands of black, silky harpy hair and carries a faint odor of putrescence.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls using this magic weapon.

Spellcasting. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. While holding the weapon, you can expend 1 charge to cast dominate beast (save DC 15) or 2 charges to cast dominate person (save DC 15).

Encounter Ideas

  • Shipwreck. The adventurers investigate a wrecked ship lying partially submerged at the base of rugged cliffs. Three harpy matriarchs and their flocks live on the cliffs, competing for the best nest sites. The harpy matriarchs band together to attack anyone attempting to claim the whip.
  • Pirates. Pirates (bandits led by a bandit captain) are raiding the coast, attacking merchant ships and small towns. The captain wields Sea Maiden's Whip.
  • Poker Game. A sailor who has lost all his coin gambling adds the whip to the pot at a cutthroat poker game in a desperate effort to regain his gold.

Sky Hunter.name: Sky Hunter
Sky Hunter.text:
Weapon (Longbow), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

Ammunition fired from this wooden bow is trailed by red and yellow strips of magical energy.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Ammunition. If you load no ammunition in the weapon, it produces its own, automatically creating one magic arrow when you draw the string. The arrow created by the bow vanishes after it hits or misses a target.

Ribbons. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you make an attack against a creature using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge and speak the command word. On a hit, strips of magical energy envelop the creature, and the target is &Reference[restrained] until the end of your next turn.

Encounter Ideas

  • Two Birds, One Roc. A wealthy benefactor has a bit of a roc problem—it is scaring away the local giant eagles. The benefactor provides a sky hunter to any party brave or foolish enough to help them, in addition to anything of value the roc may have in its nest.
  • Hoarded. A sky hunter rests among the other treasures in the lair of an adult white dragon. Undoubtedly a keepsake from an unlucky adventurer.
  • Heirloom. The scion of a famous dragon hunter inherits a sky hunter after the death of his parents. As a bard, he finds no value in it and is willing to part with it in exchange for an equally magical instrument.

Spit-Gut.name: Spit-Gut
Spit-Gut.text:
Spit-Gut Weapon (Shortsword), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This weapon's guard is a small skull, the hilt a rigid column of vertebrae, and the blade is made of what appears to be compressed bones.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 1d4[necrotic]]]{1d4 necrotic damage} on a hit.

Summon Skeleton. Once per long rest, as an action, you can speak the command word, causing the weapon to transform into a Small goblin skeleton named Spit-

Gut. This skeleton acts as though you had summoned it with the animate dead spell, but reverts to its weapon form after a number of hours equal to your proficiency bonus. It reverts to a weapon early if it is reduced to 0 hit points or if you choose to use your bonus action to speak the command word again. The skeleton wobbles around like a toddler unsure of their legs (this does not affect its speed). If not supervised, it starts mischief and touches things that should not be touched.

Encounter Ideas

  • Lost in Translation. A skeleton with goblin features walks into a bar, its teeth chattering and its motions miming the swinging of a sword. If destroyed, the bones reshape into the shortsword. Otherwise, the skeleton transforms into a shortsword after 1 hour of following the characters around.
  • Skeleton Sidekick. As the characters battle a formidable foe, they witness their opponent draw a boney shortsword and speak a word, causing the weapon to unfurl into its goblin-sized skeleton form.
  • Ugly Sword. The dusty and boney sword is seen on a shop keeper's wall. They offer to sell the ugly sword at the discounted price of 473 gp if the adventurers are interested. It has been hanging on their wall for many years and no one else has been interested in it. The original owner mentioned it was magical.

Spout.name: Spout
Spout.text:
Weapon (Javelin), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This clear glass javelin is mostly filled with blue-tinted water. As the weapon is moved or tilted, the water within flows about its empty space.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Aquanaut. While holding this weapon, you can hold your breath for 60 minutes. Once per long rest, as an action, you can cast control water (save DC 15) from the weapon.

Encounter Ideas

  • Ships' Queen's Wrath. A pirate (bandit captain) known as Ships' Queen uses this weapon's power to commandeer rival pirate and merchant ships. Though typically rivals, the pirates and merchants team up to offer a large reward to anyone who defeats Ships' Queen.
  • Whale Back. While on a seafaring expedition, the adventurers' ship is attacked by a reckless killer whale with a glass javelin protruding from its back. If the adventurers can remove the javelin, the whale ceases its assault.
  • Wanna Bet? An elf gladiator bets 10 gp that she can hold her breath longer than anyone else. So far, she is undefeated.

Star of Mourning.name: Star of Mourning
Star of Mourning.text:
Weapon (Morningstar), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This morningstar is made from white marble with veins of deep black.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Anguish. When you score a critical hit against a creature with this weapon, the target is &Reference[incapacitated] for 1 minute, as it becomes overwhelmed with despair and grief. At the end of each of the &Reference[incapacitated] creature's turns, it can make a [[/save wisdom 14]]saving throw, ending this effect on a success. It then becomes immune to this effect for 24 hours.

Mourning. If one of your allies dies, the weapon's veins begin to glow with a sorrowful blue light and continue to glow for 48 hours, or until the ally is returned to life. While the weapon glows, attacks made with it score a critical hit on a roll of 17–20.

Encounter Ideas

  • Hero's Grave. The adventurers discover the resting place of a forgotten hero, this morningstar set into their headstone.
  • Spirit's Gratitude. A mournful spirit cannot move on until it honors its lost loved ones. When the party resolves its desire, it shows them a cache of heirlooms containing the morningstar before passing into the next world.
  • Warlord's Lament. Grieving the loss of his wife, a knight imbues a morningstar with his despair, then raises an army of bandits, swearing to conquer in her name to secure her legacy.

Swarming Snare.name: Swarming Snare
Swarming Snare.text:
Weapon (Net), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This braided net looks shinier than an ordinary net. On closer examination, the braid looks and feels like writhing centipedes.

A creature &Reference[restrained] by this magic weapon takes [[/r 4d4[piercing]]]{4d4 piercing damage} at the end of each of its turns as it animates and crawls over the target, biting it. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this damage is stable but &Reference[poisoned] for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points, and &Reference[paralyzed] while &Reference[poisoned] in this way. If the weapon is destroyed, it reforms after 24 hours.

Encounter Ideas

  • Cast a Wide Net. The party discovers a series of murders where the victim's bodies are covered in insect bites.

  • Nothing But Net. Bloodbringer, a gladiator from the arena, vanished, and the local noble, Lord Harlach, hires the party to investigate. Lord Harlach promised Bloodbringer retirement with family support but reneged because Bloodbringer draws a crowd. Bloodbringer borrowed a swarming snare from the thieves' guild with which to assassinate Lord Harlach.

  • Retrocede the Centipede. The local thieves' guild owns a swarming snare, but it vanished. A member hires the party to recover it. A member of the guild, Theren "Nimblewrist" Golifax (scout), stole it. He wants to kill the guildmaster, Listan "The Eye" Blackwater (assassin), and take over, because the guild recently accepted a contract to kill Theren's relative. Guild members begin to turn up dead, covered in bites.

Syringe Stiletto.name: Syringe Stiletto
Syringe Stiletto.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This slender silver dagger has an empty vial in its hilt and a hollow needle in its blade. When the vial is filled with fluid, the tip of the dagger drips.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls using this magic weapon.

Heal or Harm. Over the course of 1 minute, you can carefully fill the hilt of the dagger with a potion of any kind. Once per long rest, when filled, you can use an action to jam the dagger's tip into a creature within reach, choosing to heal or harm. Make an attack roll if the creature is unwilling. If you choose to heal, the target regains 4d6 hit points. If you choose to harm, the target must succeed on a [[/save constitution 14]]saving throw or take [[/r 4d6[poison]]]{4d6 poison damage} and become &Reference[poisoned] for 1 minute. A &Reference[poisoned] creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

Encounter Ideas

  • Deliver the Cure. A doctor fills a syringe stiletto with medicine and asks the characters to deliver it to a dying hermit deep in the monster-infested wilderness.
  • Fiendish Plague. A scheming rakshasa is injecting people all over a major city with a potent plague from its fiendish plane.
  • Sponsorship. An alchemist offers to sponsor the characters in an upcoming tournament if they use his syringe stiletto to administer a variety of potions during the matches, driving business to his shop.

Thoughtrazor.name: Thoughtrazor
Thoughtrazor.text:
Weapon (Scimitar), Rare (Requires Attunement)

The translucent blade of this curved sword is made of congealed slime from psychic brain matter. Bubbles slowly drift up and down inside the blade, suggesting a dormant intelligence within.

Attacks made with this magic weapon deal extra psychic damage equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) on a hit.

Forget. The first time you damage a creature with an attack using this weapon, the target must succeed on a [[/save intelligence 15]]saving throw or permanently forget what happened within the last [[/r 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}. Whenever you score a critical hit, the target must make the same saving throw. On a failure, the creature also falls under the effects of the confusion spell (no concentration required).

Encounter Ideas

  • Lost in Thought. A quarrel results in one of the participants dead, and the other with no memory as to what led to the fight. The scimitar plunged into the back of the deceased is the only clue.
  • Dream Manifestation. After waking up from a significant dream, an adventurer finds the blade hovering hazardously above them.
  • Last Resort. A confidence artist offers the weapon as a gift if the adventurers agree not to reveal her tricks.

Triumvirate.name: Triumvirate
Triumvirate.text:
Weapon (Trident), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

The three prongs of this trident each represent one of the three powerful hags who forged it.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which has the light property.

Precision. If you use this weapon to make three weapon attacks in the same turn, you gain advantage on the third attack, which deals an extra [[/r 3d6[force]]]{3d6 force damage} on a hit.

Spellcasting. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charges when you finish a long rest. You can use an action and expend 1 charge to cast one of the following spells (save DC 17): bane, bless, or magic missile. Spells cast this way do not require concentration.

Encounter Ideas

  • Coven's Champion. A coven preparing a solstice ritual comes under threat from religious zealots. They offer this trident alongside a favor if the adventurers protect them until the ritual's completion.
  • God Slayers. A three-faced minor deity summoned by a cult wreaks havoc in the city and just used this trident to blast the door off the party's favorite tavern!
  • Three Treasures. The adventurers discover a legend telling of three mystical, hag-shaped spikes at various secret locations that, when combined, create a powerful weapon.

Trollclaw Staff.name: Trollclaw Staff
Trollclaw Staff.text:
Weapon (Quarterstaff), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Formed by the fusion of two severed troll arms, this quarterstaff is covered in leathery green flesh. The forearms and fingers on each end continue to flex if the muscles are manipulated.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Grasping. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can attempt to grapple the target with it (the weapon's Athletics skill bonus is treated as +4 for the grapple check). You cannot attack with the Trollclaw Staff while grappling a creature this way. You can drag or carry a creature &Reference[grappled] this way at your normal speed.

Reaching. While wielding the staff, you can place a one-handed melee weapon into one of its hands. You can then make attacks with that weapon as though it had the reach property as long as you are holding the Trollclaw Staff and it is holding the one-handed weapon. You cannot attack with the Trollclaw Staff itself while it is holding a weapon.

Helpful Troll Hand. Once per long rest, you can use an action to sever one of the hands. The hand functions as per the mage hand spell, but you can only move the hand up to 10 feet per turn and the hand (which has AC 12 and 2 hit points) can be destroyed. If the severed hand is not reattached to the staff within 1 minute or is reduced to 0 hit points, it dissolves into a puddle of slimy flesh. The staff regrows a hand after 1 day and a troll grows from the flesh puddle after 10 days. A troll created this way is friendly to you for 1 hour. Then, roll a d6. On a 4–6, the troll becomes hostile, and its actions are determined by the GM. On a 1–3, it remains friendly to you until you finish a long rest, at which point this roll must be made again.

Encounter Ideas

  • Troll on the Hunt. A creature consisting of two trolls connected at the shoulder attacks a village in search of its dismembered arms.
  • Reckless Experimentation. An alchemist uses the weapon to distance herself from the vat of radiant energy she uses for her research.
  • Handful of Jokes. The town prankster uses the weapon to play tricks on the village. Unfortunately, the severed hands have gone unrecovered.

Voltaic Spine.name: Voltaic Spine
Voltaic Spine.text:
Weapon (Whip), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This hideous whip is made from nerve fiber with the sharp vertebrae still attached, created by removing the intact spine of a recently slain blue or bronze dragon. Violet electricity still courses through it.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 1d8[lighting]]]{1d8 lighting damage} on a hit.

Shock. Twice per long rest, immediately after you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can force the target to make a [[/save constitution 15]]saving throw. On a failed save, the target is &Reference[paralyzed] until the start of your next turn. Targets with immunity or resistance to lightning damage automatically succeed.

Encounter Ideas

  • Dragon Hunter. A blood-thirsty dragon hunter slays good and evil dragons alike to build an arsenal of draconic weapons. This whip is his favorite.
  • Penitent Cultists. In the depths of a dragon cult's temple, fanatic priests flagellate themselves with this whip in ecstatic devotion, spilling their blood to summon an ancient blue dragon.
  • Weird Artifice. A deranged artificer is attempting to use a voltaic spine to animate his new dragon construct to destroy the university that spurned him.

Whirlwind Spear.name: Whirlwind Spear
Whirlwind Spear.text:
Weapon (Spear), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This feather-light spear stands seven feet tall. Where the haft meets the wide spearhead, three colorful feathers hang, always dancing as if captured in a breeze, regardless of one's actual presence.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Whirlwind Shield. When you are hit by an attack or targeted by the magic missile spell, you can use your reaction to spin the spear around your body at incredible speed. Until the start of your next turn, you have a +3 to bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from magic missile. In addition, once per long rest, you can use your action to channel the weapon's power and cast gust of wind (save DC 14).

Encounter Ideas

  • Marauders. A band of marauding horsemen are attacking a merchant caravan. The leader is twirling the Whirlwind Spear around himself, deflecting the guard's arrows and spells alike.
  • Giant Eagle's Nest. The Whirlwind Spear protrudes from a tangled mass of branches, its colored feathers standing out among the more drab, molted plumage adorning the interior of this massive bird's nest.
  • Lizardfolk Shaman. Striking fear into all the lizardfolk of their tribe, an otherwise powerless shaman uses the Whirlwind Spear's abilities to keep them all in line.

Shocking Snare.name: Shocking Snare
Shocking Snare.text:
Weapon (Net), Common

This net has all the visual earmarks of a mundane net, but it sparks with a static charge when handled.

A creature that fails a Strength check to free itself or another creature from the net, misses an attack against the net, or deals insufficient damage to destroy the net with a single attack, takes [[/r 1d8[lightning]]]{1d8 lightning damage} and cannot take reactions until the start of its next turn.

Encounter Ideas

  • Lone Wolf. The party is adventuring in a forest when they hear the yelp of an injured creature. A wolf has been &Reference[restrained] by a shocking snare.
  • Tricks and Traps. The party is clearing out a dungeon infested with kobolds. A triggered trap releases a shocking snare that drops from the ceiling.
  • Fishy Business. The town guard has posted warnings noting that fishing with the use of shocking snares is illegal. A small reward is offered to anyone who makes legitimate reports of this activity.

Shatterstone.name: Shatterstone
Shatterstone.text:
Weapon (Warhammer), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This hefty, dwarven-crafted warhammer vibrates when touched, as if waiting to unleash destruction at a moment's notice.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Born of Thunder. While attuned to this weapon, you have resistance to thunder damage.

Spellcasting. Once per long rest, when you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can cast shatter (save DC 14), centered on the target. You are immune to the effects of this casting.

Encounter Ideas

  • Stone Giant's Talisman. A shatterstone hammer rests atop an artistically crafted granite altar. Its polished metal head is covered in swirls of pigment and paint; several stone giants sit in a dream state before it.
  • Hidden Crater. Resting amongst debris and rubble in the center of a mountaintop crater sits a solitary warhammer, its handle rising up, almost beckoning for someone to grasp it.
  • Dwarven Dowry. Due to be presented as a gift to cement the marital union between the Coppercrush and Granitebrace clans, a shatterstone hammer has mysteriously gone missing in transit. Lord Grimfrik Coppercrush is willing to pay good coin for the return of this precious family heirloom.

Screaming Sickle.name: Screaming Sickle
Screaming Sickle.text:
Weapon (Sickle), Uncommon

This unassuming farmer's tool, pocked with rust, is light as a feather when held and whistles as sharply as any finely crafted blade when swung through the air.

When you hit a creature with an attack using this magic weapon, it emits a scream of pleasure and delight, audible up to 60 feet away. Every time the weapon screams, there is a chance that its cries draw the attention of a curious fey. Roll a d12. On a 1, a sprite appears. Roll initiative for the sprite, which has its own turns. The sprite acts as an ally to you and your companions for [[/r 1d6 #rounds]]{1d6 rounds} before getting bored and returning to its home plane. Only one sprite can be summoned this way per day.

Encounter Ideas

  • Farmer's Last Stand. The sounds of otherworldly screams rip through the air around an isolated farmhouse as its owner desperately tries to hold off a pack of hungry wolves with the Screaming Sickle all by themselves.
  • Sideshow Delight. The traveling circus known as Merdalf's Amazing Delights provides those who spend a silver to gain entrance many a wonder. The most audible of which comes from a makeshift stage show where Merdalf himself wields the Screaming Sickle, its otherworldly screams punctuated by the appearance of a sprite—an angry faerie very tired of Merdalf's incessant summoning.
  • Crow's Bane. Alone, in an overgrown field, stands a seven-foot-tall scarecrow, its once brightly colored clothes faded by the sun and stained by the weather. Dangling from its burlap hand is a rusty sickle.

Worm Grunt.name: Worm Grunt
Worm Grunt.text:
Weapon (Club), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This club, its handle fitted with dark grooves, is carved and painted to resemble a monstrosity.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Grunt. Twice per long rest, as an action, you can rub the weapon's grooves with a stick, piece of wood, another weapon, or similar object, causing it to emit a grunting sound audible to anyone within 60 feet. Roll a d10. On a 1–9, you summon a swarm of poisonous worms (use the swarm of centipedes statistics), which erupt from the ground. The swarm is an ally to you and your companions. In combat, the swarm shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It obeys your verbal commands (no action required by you). If you do not issue any, it takes the Dodge action and uses its move to avoid danger. After 1 hour, the swarm returns to the earth. On a 10, you summon a purple worm, which is hostile to all. It acts on its own accord and remains until slain. Summoned creatures appear in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.

Encounter Ideas

  • Worm Singer. Locals complain about an orc bully who frequently demands a tax. If the tax is not paid, the orc rubs their club, and a swarm of biting worms appears.
  • Battle of Worms. While battling a group of bandits, their orc bandit captain uses Worm Grunt to summon a swarm of biting worms which attack a character.
  • Purple Freakin' Worm?!?! While battling a group of bandits, their orc bandit captain uses Worm Grunt to summon a purple worm. The surprised orc and bandits quickly flee the scene, leaving the characters alone with the summoned purple worm.

Rechargable Weapons.text:
The third section of the supplement contains unique rechargeable weapons. Rather than recharging after a short or long rest, these weapons require a character perform a special task, provide a monetary sacrifice or component, or something else.
