Assassin’s Remorse.name: Assassin’s Remorse
Assassin’s Remorse.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Black, vein-like markings spiderweb across this dagger's surface.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r (2)[psychic]]]{2 psychic damage} on a hit to the target and [[/r (1)[psychic]]]{1 psychic damage} to you.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with remorse for all the lives it has taken, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

If used to end the life of a Humanoid, there is a 10% chance that the creature will rise from the dead [[/r 1d4 #days]]{1d4 days} after being slain, fully healed and under a magical compulsion to find the wielder and prevent them from using the weapon again. The resurrected victim can sense the weapon's location from any distance while on the same plane of existence. Each additional Humanoid killed increases the chance of resurrection by 10%, resetting to 10% after a successful resurrection.

Encounter Idea

Death Times Two. The adventurers find two bodies. One is dressed all in black and has the look of an assassin. The other is wearing threadbare, dirty traveling clothes that look as if they had come across a great distance through an extraordinary effort to die in this place.

Axe of Roses.name: Axe of Roses
Axe of Roses.text:
Weapon (Greataxe), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This greataxe's haft is crafted from a red-tinted wood, reminiscent of auburn hair. Both the haft and the axe head are adorned with beautifully etched roses.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, during combat, the axe spews forth insults and threats at the enemy, dealing an additional [[/r 2d4[psychic]]]{2d4 psychic damage} to creatures on a hit.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the wit of an unruly comedic god, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack. This weapon does not know when to shut up.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on all Charisma checks as the weapon insults, threatens, and belittles anyone you are speaking with, audible to anyone within 30 feet of it.

Encounter Idea

Friendless Barbarian. While the adventurers are enjoying a quiet evening, they are approached by a half-orc (veteran) who is just trying to strike up a conversation. His axe, however, thinks the adventurers are weak, pathetic wannabes who could never hope to best its wielder, Ooroc Bonebreaker.

Bandolier of Darts.name: Bandolier of Darts
Bandolier of Darts.text:
Weapon (Darts), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This cracked, black leather belt houses half a dozen barbed darts.

This bandolier holds six magical darts. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with these darts. In addition, any darts thrown from the bandolier magically return to it at the end of your turn.

Wound. When you score a critical with an attack using this weapon, you can wound the target. A wounded creature takes [[/r (1)[necrotic]]]{1 necrotic damage} for each time you've wounded it at the start of each of its turns. A creature can use its action to make a [[/save constitution 15]]saving throw, ending the effect of all such wounds on itself on a success. Alternatively, the wounded creature, or a creature within 5 feet of it, can use an action to make a DC 15 Wisdom (Medicine) check, ending the effect of all such wounds on it on a success. Magical healing also ends the effect.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with vile necrotic energy, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you believe all weapons would be better if thrown. You must make a [[/save wisdom 12]]saving throw each time you finish a long rest. On a failed save, all your melee weapon attack rolls are made with disadvantage.

Encounter Idea

The Challenge. An attractive stranger wearing a cowboy-style hat and boots stands in the shadows and flings a dart across the adventurers' path. They say, "Bet my bandolier that none of y'all can throw better than me," as the thrown dart disappears and returns to the stranger's bandolier.

Blowback.name: Blowback
Blowback.text:
Weapon (Blowgun), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This blowgun is composed of a 3-foot-long tube of rolled and glued spell scrolls. The scrolls' spell symbols and text are still partially legible.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon, and ammunition fired through it is imbued with wild magical energy. When fired, roll a d6 and consult the following table, applying the extra damage and additional effect on a hit. If you roll a 1 on your attack roll, the extra damage and effect are instead applied to you.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-roll-tables.RollTable.lLrkKKR3sIxH70Ea]{Blockback Effect Table}

Curse. The weapon is cursed with the essence of a wizard's naughty, spoiled child, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on attack rolls with weapons other than this one, unless all foes in sight are within 5 feet of you.

Encounter Idea

Meet the Brat. A wizard's spoiled brat of a child threw a fit when they did not get their way and spent a night making papercraft creations out of the spell scroll library. One of these creations was a blowgun. While visiting an urban area, the child runs around a corner, bumping into a character and indignantly yelling, "Don't you know who my father is?! Out of my way, peasant!" before he runs away. It looks like he dropped a 3-foot-long tightly rolled tube of paper and a small pouch of needles. Is that writing on it?

Butterfly Kisses.name: Butterfly Kisses
Butterfly Kisses.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This dagger's hinged hilt allows it to fold over, concealing the blade. The two folded hilt halves resemble a butterfly.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, you can magically summon the weapon to your hand if the weapon is within 5 feet of you, requiring no action.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the duplicitous magic of a trickster god. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, each time you attack with this weapon, the weapon nicks you, dealing [[/r (1)[slashing]]]{1 slashing damage} to you.

Encounter Idea

Dagger for Sale. An accomplished thief, her face and fingers covered in short, thin scars, has decided to retire from adventuring and thievery. Having removed the curse on herself, she offers to sell the weapon to the characters for a mere 100 gp.

Chains of the Betrayer.name: Chains of the Betrayer
Chains of the Betrayer.text:
Weapon (Flail), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This spiked flail is coated in flakes of red rust.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, the target takes a –1 penalty to their next attack roll before the start of your next turn.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the traitorous essence of a trickster god, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, if you make a melee attack with this weapon and roll a 1 on the attack roll, you must reroll the attack, targeting a friendly creature within reach instead. If there are no valid targets for your attack, you lose your remaining actions and bonus actions for the turn.

Encounter Idea

Unfinished Business. A wounded soldier (guard) stumbles into the adventurers' camp, begging them to free him from the weapon that forces him to strike his friends but resisting any attempts to pry it from his hands. If he is slain or successfully disarmed, the curse passes to the character responsible.

Chittering.name: Chittering
Chittering.text:
Weapon (Quarterstaff), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Tiny insects crawl in and out of boreholes covering this gnarled, rotting staff.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature with this weapon, it must succeed on a [[/save constitution]] saving throw (the DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier) or some of the burrowing insects latch onto the creature. A latched creature takes [[/r (1)[piercing]]]{1 piercing damage} at the start of each of its turns and has disadvantage on saving throws made to maintain concentration until it takes acid or fire damage, or fully submerges itself in liquid.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of a maddening realm, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you occasionally see giant insects with bizarre features in your peripheral vision. When you complete a long rest, roll a d6. On a 1, these insects haunt your dreams, and you only regain half your lost hit points during that rest.

Encounter Idea

Something About This Bugs Me. While resting in a long-forgotten place, strange insects haunt a character's dreams. When they awaken, they are clutching the staff.

Deathlady.name: Deathlady
Deathlady.text:
Weapon (Glaive), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This glaive's blackened blade is wrapped in a red sash at its base, its vibrant color contrasting sharply with the ebony wood of the shaft.

On a successful hit with this magic weapon, you deal extra necrotic damage to the target equal to three times your proficiency bonus. If you are within 5 feet of the target, you can touch it as a bonus action to regain hit points equal to half the necrotic damage dealt (minimum 1).

Curse. This weapon is cursed with necromantic energy, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unable to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on attack rolls made with weapons other than this one.

When you attune to this weapon, your hands wither to a deathly gray. When you touch a Humanoid with your bare hands, you must make a [[/save wisdom 16]]saving throw. On a failed save, you become &Reference[paralyzed] for 1 minute as you experience their death repeatedly in different forms, as though it were happening to you, feeling intense pain with each instance. If the person you touch is an ally, you gain one level of exhaustion and the memories haunt your nightmares that night.

Encounter Idea

Stained Battlefield. The characters cross a recent battlefield, the ground stained with fresh blood and littered with the dead. One corpse stands out, its body unusually decayed as if they died months ago. The flesh has withered, with one hand tightly gripping the glaive against their chest.

Drowning Blade.name: Drowning Blade
Drowning Blade.text:
Weapon (Longsword), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This longsword's hilt is wrapped in tough, deep green seaweed that is constantly wet without making it slippery. Waves carved into the blade's surface call you to the sea.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. This bonus increases to +2 when attacking Humans and Elves. Attacks made against Sahuagin with this weapon have disadvantage.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the magic of a vengeful sahuagin shaman, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you have a strong desire to go to the sea. If you are fully immersed in sea water, the sword becomes locked to your hand, its weight becomes 100 pounds, and it attempts to drag you to the bottom.

If the curse is removed, the weapon's properties instead become: You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made against creatures with a swim speed and attacks made with this weapon while underwater do not impose disadvantage. In addition, once per long rest, you can cast control water.

Encounter Idea

Let Go! Along a beach at the site of a shipwreck, the sword is found with a severed human hand still clutching it tightly.

Fiendish Stiletto.name: Fiendish Stiletto
Fiendish Stiletto.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This reddish-hued spike is firmly mounted into a carved bone handle. When brandished, the smell of sulfur and brimstone betrays its devilish origins.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. This bonus increases to +3 versus Fiends.

Banishment. Once per long rest, when you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can cast banishment (save DC 14) on the target, sending them to the hells for the duration.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of a betrayed fiend, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times. You also have disadvantage on attack rolls with any other weapon.

After you use Banishment, during your next long rest, you must succeed on a [[/save wisdom 15]]saving throw or your rest is plagued by unsettling infernal visions and nightmares, causing you to gain no benefits from the rest.

Encounter Idea

Demonic Corpse. Among the carnage of several dead adventurers lies the fetid corpse of a slain demon; the fiendish stiletto protrudes from its bloated neck.

Finger of the Cult.name: Finger of the Cult
Finger of the Cult.text:
Weapon (Shortsword), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This shortsword is carved from multicolored coral.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you regain 1 hit point.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the dreams and desires of a dark cult, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you gain the following flaw.

  • Reckless. "No matter the threat level, I always attack my enemies!"

Encounter Idea

Prevailing Goblin. Gertruga Flem, a goblin adventurer (spy), is the talk of the town. She is quite handy with her colorful sword, which she uses to kill vermin that reside in homes and streets, attacking them violently and standing her ground even when she is overrun. Funny thing is, she always seems to prevail.

Flights of Fancy.name: Flights of Fancy
Flights of Fancy.text:
Weapon (Longbow), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This bow, appearing as if it were grown and not carved, is crafted from a rare fey wood. Pearlescent colors ripple along its pale limbs and its golden string hums with power.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This weapon has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. As an action, you can expend 1 charge to cast confusion (save DC 16), requiring no concentration.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the randomness of a chaotic realm, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, when you expend one of the weapon's charges to cast confusion and a target succeeds on their saving throw, you must succeed on the same saving throw or be affected by the spell instead.

Encounter Idea

Confused Forester. A local forester seems completely confused, running hither and yon, attacking randomly. The adventurers are tasked with stopping her, preferably by bringing her to the temple in the hope the priests can help her.

From Afar.name: From Afar
From Afar.text:
Weapon (Longbow), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This bow is fashioned from the spindly legs of an unrecognizable creature, but similar to those of a crab.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Prior to making an attack with this weapon, you can choose to have disadvantage on Wisdom checks and saving throws until the start of your next turn. If you do so, the weapon's attacks deal extra psychic damage equal to your Wisdom modifier on a hit.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the maddening essence of an alien realm, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, when you attack with this weapon and roll a 1 on the attack roll, the weapon summons a horror from another plane of existence, appearing in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you. The creature is not aggressive to you but is also not your ally. It acts on its own initiative count and attacks the nearest creature (including you). It can choose to disengage from combat. This creature plagues the realm until it is destroyed.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-roll-tables.RollTable.zRmOLtTfg5NGSxJW]{From Afar Creature}

Encounter Idea

Chaos Risen. A village is being attacked by a bizarre creature. The townsfolk state that the abomination appeared near the tavern when two bounty hunters had a long-range duel with their bows.

Butterfingers.name: Butterfingers
Butterfingers.text:
Weapon (Scimitar), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This weapon has a comfortable, buttery smooth ivory handle, and an exceptionally sharp obsidian blade.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 2d4[slashing]]]{2d4 slashing damage} on a hit.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of a betrayed thief, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on attack rolls made with any weapon other than this one. In addition, whenever you roll a 1 on an attack roll, the weapon slips from your grip and falls to the ground, and you take [[/r 2d4[slashing]]]{2d4 slashing damage}.

Encounter Idea

The Unlucky Thief. A thief, caught in the act of thieving, gets into an altercation with the local guard. The scoundrel's weapon slips from his hand and, in the chaos of combat, gets kicked toward the adventurers.

Manticore’s Tail.name: Manticore’s Tail
Manticore’s Tail.text:
Weapon (Morningstar), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This wickedly spiked weapon appears to be a mundane club with iron-hard spikes driven through it at odd angles.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Flying Spikes. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charges when you finish a long rest. As part of an Attack action, you can expend 1 charge to cause bone spikes to explode from the weapon. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere (including you) must succeed on a [[/save dexterity 15]]saving throw or take [[/r 1d4[piercing]]]{1d4 piercing damage} from the spikes.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of a powerful and legendary manticore, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and you have disadvantage on attack rolls with weapons other than this one.

While cursed, whenever a hostile creature approaches you, you must succeed on a [[/save wisdom 15]]saving throw or go berserk. While berserk, you must use your action each round to attack the creature nearest to you while also expending charges to activate the weapon's Flying Spikes property. You are berserk until you start your turn with no creatures within 60 feet of you that you can see or hear.

Encounter Idea

What Happened Here? While traveling, the adventurers encounter a strange sight: A dozen gnolls, their bodies riddled with boney spikes. From the way the corpses are arranged it looks like they may have done this to themselves somehow. A brutal, spiked morningstar lays near the largest gnoll's body.

Grimsbane.name: Grimsbane
Grimsbane.text:
Weapon (Greatsword), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This greatsword's hilt is as white as sun-bleached bone and shaped like a femur. Black runes undulate along the weapon's shining blade.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, you have advantage on attack rolls made against Undead with this weapon.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of death, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack. While cursed, the weapon's magic is powered by your lifeforce, rendering you vulnerable to necrotic damage.

Encounter Idea

Grave Robbers. A grave robber is the only survivor after a heist gone bad. After witnessing a mummy kill his companions, he wishes to sell the weapon and get out of the tomb raiding business for good. He can also provide directions to the mummy's tomb—for a fee, of course.

Pike of Unwieldiness.name: Pike of Unwieldiness
Pike of Unwieldiness.text:
Weapon (Pike), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

A nearly twenty-foot-long pike made of wood stained a deep black and sporting a gleaming bronze blade.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, this weapon adds an additional 10 feet to your reach when you attack with it.

Curse. This pike is cursed with the dark wit and humor of a trickster inventor, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using this weapon while an enemy is within 5 feet of you.

Encounter Idea

Vaulting Warrior. In his younger days, a pole-vaulter was forced to give up athletics to fight in war, and had this pike commissioned from a shady inventor to make use of his unique skills. Now retired, he is seeking a worthy inheritor.

Reprisal.name: Reprisal
Reprisal.text:
Weapon (Sickle), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This silver sickle, its blade intricately engraved with delicate wings, emits a faint glow.

When you attune to this magic weapon, two large silver wings sprout from your back, granting you a flying speed equal to your walking speed. You also gain resistance to necrotic and radiant damage.

Reprisal. Once per long rest, when you deal damage to a target with an attack or spell, you can choose to deal an extra [[/r 4d8[radiant]]]{4d8 radiant damage} to that target.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of an overzealous paladin, and attuning to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unable to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, your alignment becomes lawful good, and you gain the following flaw:

  • Good Is the Only Choice! You are compelled to punish any creature you believe is committing an evil act, without regard for the severity of the offense. Stealing an apple is punished the same as murder. After you judge an act as evil, you must make a [[/save wisdom 16]]saving throw. On a failed save, you immediately attack the creature you deem vile and in need of penance.

Encounter Idea

By the Book. In a forsaken land, the characters discover an abandoned, ruined shrine. The once-sacred site now holds no trace of the god that was worshipped here. On a weathered and cracked altar, they find a glowing sickle resting on a crumbling ancient tome. Snippets of the tome's legible text reveal it to be a religious artifact referring to lawfulness and good.

False God’s Hand.name: False God’s Hand
False God’s Hand.text:
Weapon (Mace), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This mace, its head carved in the shape of an open palm, is fashioned from a solid piece of jade.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. The weapon has 5 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can expend charges to activate various properties:

  • Necrotic Rot (1 charge). Deal an extra [[/r 3d10[necrotic]]]{3d10 necrotic damage} to the target.
  • Blindness/Deafness (2 charges). Cast blindness/ deadness on the target (save DC 15). When cast this way, it lasts until the end of the creature's next turn, instead of 1 minute.

  • Bestow Curse (3 charges). Cast bestow curse on the target (save DC 15, requires no concentration).

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of a dark realm, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, you must activate the weapon's Necrotic Rot ability once per day or you lose the ability to regain hit points from magic or short rests, and only regain half your lost hit points when you finish a long rest.

Encounter Idea

Vile Priest. Borlak Flax, an evil priest-for-hire, relaxes from several weeks of exploring and adventuring in the same city or town as the characters. However, during this downtime, the priest uses the weapon's Necrotic Rot ability on innocent people, killing several and causing quite a stir. The adventurers may witness his devious act or be hired to investigate.

Screech of the Deep.name: Screech of the Deep
Screech of the Deep.text:
Weapon (Whip), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

Resembling a sea creature's tentacle, this whip's crack sounds like the moan of a creature from the fathomless depths.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This weapon has a number of charges equal to half your level, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit a creature with this weapon, the target must succeed on a [[/save constitution]] saving throw (the DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier) or a cluster of barnacles erupts from the wound. When a creature with barnacles moves, it takes [[/r 1d6[piercing]]]{1d6 piercing damage} per cluster of barnacles. A creature can use an action to remove one cluster.

Curse. This weapon is cursed by an imprisoned kraken, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you must fully submerge yourself in water at least once every week or gain a level of exhaustion. In addition, you gain the following flaw:

  • Call of the Deep. "I don't feel safe or at home unless I'm submerged in the deepest, darkest reaches of the ocean."

Encounter Idea

Blood in the Water. A sinister sailor uses the whip to hunt sharks, explaining that they either have to stop moving and suffocate, or keep swimming and get shredded by the barnacles. One of the characters hears a deep voice call from beneath the waves, telling them that the sailor is unworthy of its gift and entreating them to take the weapon from them by force.

Sea Queen’s Call.name: Sea Queen’s Call
Sea Queen’s Call.text:
Weapon (Battleaxe), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

The shaft of this rippled-silver axe is wrought from pearl and sports a small conch shell pommel.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can use your reaction to cause the weapon to unleash a crashing tidal wave, dealing an extra [[/r 3d8[force]]]{3d8 force damage} to the target. In addition, attacks made with this weapon underwater do not impose disadvantage.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of an evil sea goddess, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times. In addition, you have disadvantage on attack rolls made with weapons other than this one.

While cursed, every night at sunset, you hear the seductive whisper of a feminine voice, calling you to join her royal guard. When you hear the voice, which is inaudible to anyone else, you must succeed on a [[/save wisdom 16]]saving throw or stop whatever else you are doing and begin making your way to the nearest ocean. You instinctively know how to find it and are compelled to travel there. When you reach the ocean, you attempt to drown yourself. You can repeat the saving throw at the end of every hour, ending the effect on a success.

Encounter Idea

Mer-cantile Dealings. A shopkeeper in a seaside town displays a battleaxe mounted above her counter, its evergreen seaweed an intriguing curiosity for both locals and travelers. She explains that she found it while beachcombing one morning and kept it as décor. She is willing to part with it in exchange for another unique weapon, item, or a favor.

Spear of Heroic Landing.name: Spear of Heroic Landing
Spear of Heroic Landing.text:
Weapon (Spear), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This spear's shaft is intricately carved with fierce-looking jungle beasts and adorned with colorful feathers.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. If you jump at least 5 feet prior to making an attack with this weapon, the bonus increases to +3 and the attack deals an additional [[/r 1d6[piercing]]]{1d6 piercing damage}.

Heroic Landing. Falling or jumping from a height of 10 feet or greater triggers a Heroic Landing. The speed of descent is normal, but you hit the ground in the classic superhero landing pose. Unfortunately, you are not a superhero. The fall hurts, but the damage is reduced to 1d4 per 10 feet fallen, with a maximum of [[/r 10d4[falling]]]{10d4 falling damage}. Getting out of the awkward landing pose and standing up requires you use 15 feet of movement.

Terminal Velocity. Once per long rest, when you complete a Heroic Landing, you can cast thunderwave (save DC 15), centered on you. When cast this way, the range is a 15-foot square centered on you.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with an inflated ego and desire for grand displays, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on Stealth checks.

Encounter Idea

Don't Look Up. While traveling through a forest, the adventurers are attacked by a group of thugs and bandits. Their leader, a veteran named Silver Bennet, leaps from her tree limb perch, triggering the Heroic Landing property when she lands.

Imagination.name: Imagination
Imagination.text:
Weapon (Longsword), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Unrecognizable, monstrous images are engraved in the blade of this finely crafted sword.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, once per long rest, while holding the weapon, you can cast phantasmal killer (save DC 15), requiring no concentration.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the devious magic of a trickster god, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, when you attack with this weapon and roll a 1 on the attack roll, the weapon targets you with phantasmal killer (save DC 15), requiring no concentration. When cast this way, the spell creates a frightening image from your nightmares, or a grotesque image from an unknown realm.

Encounter Idea

Phantom Pain. While battling a formidable opponent, the characters witness their adversary suddenly begin swinging wildly at empty air while they scream and yell in horror. Their body jolts in pain, and soon falls to the ground, destroyed by some unknown means.

Slime Totem.name: Slime Totem
Slime Totem.text:
Weapon (Club), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

Sticky, lime-green liquid oozes from foreign runes carved along the head of this wooden club.

When you attack a creature with this magic weapon and roll a 20 on the attack roll, slime erupts from its runes. Each creature within 10 feet of the target must succeed on a [[/save dexterity]] saving throw (the DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or have their speed reduced by half until the end of their next turn.

Curse. This weapon is cursed by an aboleth disease, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you emit pheromones typically exuded by an aboleth's minions. Aberrations can smell these pheromones from up to 5 miles away, even through strong winds, and instinctually view you as a threat. In combat, they prioritize attacking you.

Encounter Idea

Phlegm and Flotsam. A dead aquatic humanoid, its limbs twisted, and face locked in anguish, washes up on shore, clutching this weapon.

Staff of Many Voices.name: Staff of Many Voices
Staff of Many Voices.text:
Weapon (Quarterstaff), Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This redwood staff is covered in carvings of faces, each with wide, screaming mouths.

You gain a +3 bonus to spell attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. While holding it, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration.

Additionally, while attuned to this weapon, you know one additional language of your choice, and you know two cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. The spellcasting ability for these spells is your Intelligence. You make these choices when you first attune to the weapon. During a long rest, you can replace the language or one of the cantrips you know with another by opening your mind to the voices trapped within the staff. If you do so, you are unable to sleep for 24 hours and cannot successfully finish a long rest during this time period as a result.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the voices of a malevolent realm, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unable to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, whenever the area around you falls silent, particularly when you are trying to sleep, voices begin to echo in your mind. At first, a single voice attempts to persuade you to take specific actions, whether to travel to a certain place, perform a task, or act against someone. As time passes, the voices multiply, rising into a cacophony that lasts for 10 minutes. You must then make a [[/save intelligence 18]]saving throw. On a failed save, you gain no benefits from this long rest, and you gain one level of exhaustion.

Encounter Idea

Rambling Rambler. While traveling a long road, the party encounters an exhausted, frazzled old half-elf gasping for air as they lean against a tree. Their bloodshot eyes fixate on a carved staff on the ground. Suddenly, they grab the nearest character who looks like a spellcaster, shaking them urgently while shouting incoherently. Then, with surprising speed, they sprint down the road, leaving the staff behind.

Toxic.name: Toxic
Toxic.text:
Weapon (Hand Crossbow), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

Slightly gummy to the touch, the bright wood of this crossbow's base is mismatched with everything around it.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r (2)[poison]]]{2 poison damage} on a hit.

Curse. This weapon was made with the wood of a cursed and &Reference[poisoned] tree, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unable to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, toxins seep into your skin even while your skin is covered, giving you disadvantage on Constitution saving throws.

Encounter Idea

Stink Cloud. A large corpse flower thrives in a swamp after digesting one of the many cadavers inside of it. The crossbow—in discordance with the landscape around—can be seen within the fog of stench and rot around the creature.

Trident of Fish Metamorphosis.name: Trident of Fish Metamorphosis
Trident of Fish Metamorphosis.text:
Weapon (Trident), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This trident is fashioned from colorful coral, with images of aquatic humanoids engraved along its shaft.

The trident has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charges when you finish a long rest. While holding it, you can use an action and expend 1 charge to cast dominate beast (save DC 15) from it on a Beast that has an innate swimming speed.

Curse. This weapon is cursed by primordial magic from the Elemental Plane of Water, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you slowly transform into a fish-humanoid hybrid.

  • After one day, scales begin to sprout from your head, arms, and torso.
  • After three days, you develop gills and can breathe air and water.
  • After five days, your head becomes fish-like, your type becomes Aberration in addition to any types you had previously, and you have disadvantage on Charisma checks to interact with Humanoids without an innate swimming speed.
  • After seven days, your arms sprout fins and you gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.
  • After nine days, you can no longer stay outside of water for an extended period. You take [[/r 1d10[necrotic]]]{1d10 necrotic damage} at the end of each hour where you did not spend at least 5 minutes fully submerged in water and suffer a level of exhaustion at the end of each day where you did not spend at least 1 continuous hour fully submerged in water.

If you break the curse, the transformation reverses. Starting at the number of days you spent cursed (maximum 10), count backwards, removing features when the count is less than the day that you gained that feature.

Encounter Idea

Unexpected Initiation. The people of a coastal town gift the party a magical trident for helping them. After the curse begins to manifest, they attempt to recruit you into their kraken-worshipping cult.

Mouth of Madness.name: Mouth of Madness
Mouth of Madness.text:
Weapon (Dagger), Rare (Requires Attunement)

This alabaster dagger, highlighted with red, is carved in such a way that it resembles a hideous smile.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r (2)[psychic]]]{2 psychic damage} on a hit.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with maddening magic, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, you have disadvantage on savings throw against exhaustion and effects that would cause madness.

Encounter Idea

Rundown and Tired. A once-popular town hero is now lost in their thoughts, penniless and without purpose. Tired, broken, and rundown, they speak gibberish as they try to peddle their last remaining items in hopes of starting a new life, including their trusty dagger.

Unholy.name: Unholy
Unholy.text:
Weapon (Mace), Rare (Requires Attunement)

Grotesque faces are carved into this black iron mace's head.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an extra [[/r 1d4[necrotic]]]{1d4 necrotic damage} on a hit. If you roll a 20 on the attack roll, the weapon deals an additional [[/r (10)[necrotic]]]{10 necrotic damage}.

Curse. This weapon is cursed with the essence of a dark realm filled with evil gods, whose worshippers desire to wither away in service of their deity. Becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, your hit point maximum is reduced by 3 each time you roll a 1 on an attack roll with this weapon. If the curse is removed, your hit point maximum is restored at a rate of 3 hit points per successful long rest.

Encounter Idea

Last Breath. Immediately after a foe's unsuccessful attack with this mace, an adventurer witnesses the foe fall to the ground and exhale loudly, perishing for no apparent reason.

Rusalka’s Tears.name: Rusalka’s Tears
Rusalka’s Tears.text:
Weapon (Rapier), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This rapier's needle-like blade constantly drips water. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. While holding the weapon, you gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Curse. This weapon was cursed by a creature of watery depths, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, and choose to use it over any other weapon or attack.

While cursed, you find yourself persistently dripping water and have disadvantage on Stealth checks and saving throws against being &Reference[charmed].

Encounter Idea

Wild Rushes. A weary cry of heartache is heard as the adventurers approach a lake's edge. A young woman with hair covering her face and water dripping from her body is standing knee deep in water behind reeds. The rapier protrudes from a drowned, floating corpse next to her.

Tornado’s Whirl.name: Tornado’s Whirl
Tornado’s Whirl.text:
Weapon (Quarterstaff), Rare (Requires Attunement)

A staff made of dark wood with twisting lines carved into it.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. After making a successful attack with this weapon, you can expend 1 charge and speak the command word, causing a strong wind to billow forth. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you must make a [[/save dexterity 14]]saving throw. On a failed save, the target is pushed 10 feet away from you and knocked &Reference[prone]. On a success, the target is pushed 5 feet but is not knocked &Reference[prone].

Curse. This weapon is cursed by the windstorms of the plains, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unable to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, whenever you are holding the weapon and use at least half of your movement in one turn, a strong gust of wind releases from the weapon, pushing you 5 feet in a random direction into an unoccupied space. If there is no space available, you stay where you are.

Encounter Idea

Sudden Storm. A strong storm blows across the adventurers' path, bringing with it debris from its journey. Once the storm passes, they find the quarterstaff lodged in the ground with a mini storm still swirling around it, which dissipates when someone picks it up.

Unblinking Eye.name: Unblinking Eye
Unblinking Eye.text:
Weapon (Mace), Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

The head of this mace is not metal or stone, but a bulbous red eye that seems to stare at you.

When you hit a creature with this magic weapon and roll a 6 on your damage die, the creature is &Reference[frightened] of you until the end of its next turn. In addition, you gain eldritch vision out to a range of 60 feet, which means you can see in normal and magical darkness and can see &Reference[invisible] creatures and objects. You cannot discern color, only shades of red.

Curse. This weapon is cursed by the blind eldritch horror from whose eye it was created, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times.

While cursed, whenever you try to focus on faces or fine details (such as text or a tapestry's embroidery), you must make a [[/save wisdom]] saving throw (the DC is equal to 10 + the number of times you have made this saving throw since the last time you failed it, up to a maximum of 20). On a failed save, you see a writhing mass of tentacles instead, and are &Reference[frightened] of the creature or object in question until the end of your next turn.

Encounter Idea

Pyrrhic Implement. An &Reference[invisible] creature stalks a town, killing its inhabitants. The town elder suggests that with Unblinking Eye, the party could hunt the hunter, but warns of the heavy cost of the sight it gifts.

Alder’s Travelling Garden.name: Alder’s Travelling Garden
Alder’s Travelling Garden.text:
A little dirt can be a good thing.

Lore

The druid Alder's adventuring career took her and her trusty sickle to every corner of the world. As well as cleaving through monster hide, she used the sickle to harvest samples of every unique and wonderful plant she encountered. Proximity to an array of magics, combined with Alder's relaxed attitude toward weapon polishing, allowed the seeds to take root and thrive.

Once Alder realized what was happening, she poured her own magic into the blade, a trickle at a time over many years, until the Travelling Garden bloomed and she was able to reap the rewards.

When Alder walked into the forest for the last time to become one with the woods, she left the sickle with her apprentice Salviu.

Location

Salviu (druid), who lives quietly on a mountainside, still has the sickle. He lives off the land and is not interested in money so will not sell it, but he knows he does not fully understand the Travelling Garden's powers and will gift it to someone better able to use it if they prove themselves as defenders of nature and the land.

Encounter Ideas

  • Blight. The land Salviu protects is blighted: crops wither, trees die. The sickle is affected too. The source is a band of minor fiends (dretches) squatting in a nearby cave network. If the characters can solve the problem, Salviu gives them the sickle.

  • Nesting Material. A little-known fact about owlbears: they have nesting instincts. And, while Salviu was foraging for herbs, a local owlbear, Screechbeast, ambled through and took the sickle to line her nest. Get it back without hurting the owlbear or her cub, and the characters can have it.

  • The Path Untravelled. If the characters are travelling to somewhere Alder never visited, Salviu asks them to take the sickle with them and cultivate new seeds on it. He does not tell them this in advance, but if they add at least six new seeds to the garden, he will gift them the sickle when they return.

Progression

Alder's Travelling Garden progresses whenever the attuned creature's Wisdom modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Sickle), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Fertile Soil. Any seeds of a nonmagical plant that are placed on this magic weapon and remain there from sundown to sunrise take root on it and sprout in [[/r 1d6 #days]]{1d6 days}. Plants on the weapon require no light or nourishment to thrive. A maximum of six plants can live on the weapon. You can choose to remove any of the plants that have taken root.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Kitchen Garden. The weapon produces three nourishing berries (as per the goodberry spell) each dawn.

Rare

Bursting with Life. When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with an attack from this weapon, plants burst from the target's body, growing rapidly in a 20-foot radius centered on the target, creating difficult terrain. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, the creature must succeed on a [[/save dexterity 14]]saving throw or trip over the plants, falling &Reference[prone].

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. Additionally, Fertile Soil now affects magical plants. Finally, the DC of Bursting with Life increases to 16 and creatures who moves into or within the area now take [[/r 1d6[piercing]]]{1d6 piercing damage} from thorny growths for every 5 feet it travels.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. In addition, Bursting with Life now affects a 30-foot radius and the saving throw to avoid falling &Reference[prone] is replaced with a [[/save dexterity 18]]saving throw to avoid becoming &Reference[restrained] and the piercing damage increases to [[/r 2d6]]. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

Bow of Empee.name: Bow of Empee
Bow of Empee.text:
It's like having a targeting computer in your head, you'll never be able to use another weapon again.

Lore

While feared and revered alike for its unique properties and unimaginable power, this tactical bow is actually the standard issue weapon for a species of extraplanar warriors. Luckily, only one of these weapons has ever been spotted in this realm without its owner.

Encounter Ideas

  • Military Campaign. A warlord has learned of the existence of the bow and is gathering an army to find and retrieve it.

  • From Space. The characters witness a meteor strike the ground near them. If they investigate, they find the Bow of Empee in a cracked open chunk of rock.

  • Little Danger. The party runs into a single goblin that found the bow and is overwhelmed with power, using it against any that dare stand in their way.

Progression

The Bow of Empee progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Longbow), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

HUD. While holding this magic weapon, you can use a bonus action to activate or deactivate a heads-up display that appears in front of you. The display contains all options listed below, though those that require a rarity level above the weapon's current rarity are grayed out and unavailable. The display is visible to all creatures and disappears if you let go of the weapon.

Auto Reload. The weapon cannot use normal ammunition. Instead, it produces its own, creating one piece of magical ammunition when you make a ranged attack with it. The ammunition created by the weapon vanishes the instant after it hits or misses a target.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon as crosshairs appear in your HUD.

Psychological Warfare. Once per long rest, you can cause the weapon to produce menacing, glowing-red spikes for 1 minute. For the duration, you have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks.

Rare

Arcane Ammo. The weapon has 4 charges, and it regains 1d3 + 1 expended charges when you finish a long rest. Prior to making your attack, you can expend a number of charges to empower the created ammunition with one of the following spell effects: acid arrow (2 charges) and guiding bolt (1 charge). You can also empower the ammunition with fire bolt or ray of frost, requiring no charges. Empowered ammunition does not deal its normal piercing damage. A missed attack results in expended charges and no spell effect.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2 as an optical zoom option is unlocked, the weapon's total number of charges increases to 6, and it now regains 1d4 + 2 when you finish a long rest. In addition, Arcane Ammo gains the following spell effects: fireball (3 charges), lightning bolt (3 charges), and scorching ray (2 charges). Spells effects that target a point must instead target a creature or object. The spell save DC for spells which require targets to make a saving throw is 15.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3 as a new targeting system highlights potential targets, the weapon's total number of charges increases to 9 and it now regains 1d6 + 3 charges when you finish a long rest. In addition, Arcane Ammo gains the following spell effects, and the spell save DC increases to 17: disintegrate (6 charges), flame strike (5 charges), ice storm (4 charges), and sunbeam (6 charges).

Bellier’s Razorfin.name: Bellier’s Razorfin
Bellier’s Razorfin.text:
The fanning blades of this flail are fashioned from scintillating, polished steel.

Lore

The gnome inventor, Bellier Matchlight, kept a pond filled with fishlike automatons whose fins fanned out like razor blades. Linking one such fish to a flail, Bellier gifted his razorfin flail to the paladin Heorush, who used it in her war against the forces of the kraken Xenkat.

Location

When the last warrior in the Order of the Storm's Eye perished, a young scholar named Maritas recovered Bellier's Razorfin in the hope of delivering it to one who will finally carry it to victory against the kraken.

Encounter Ideas

  • Keeper's Tomb. Maritas died waiting for a worthy warrior. Her tomb houses challenges of duty, strength, and valor meant for the next keeper of Bellier's Razorfin.

  • Overtures of Greatness. Sahuagin raiders have gathered captives and stolen goods in a flooded cave. After defeating the sahuagin leader Cetyl'kikua, the characters are approached by Maritas, who offers the flail if they swear vengeance against the kraken's forces.

  • Scaly Scavengers. Dul'Uthamant the Voracious, an adult bronze dragon, has claimed Bellier's Razorfin and placed its keeper Maritas in a cage suspended above a waterfall. If the dragon can be placated, she will relinquish Maritas and the flail in exchange for favors. If not, Maritas must be saved by stealth and cunning.

Progression

Bellier's Razorfin progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Flail), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Propellers. While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cause the fin blades to spin like propellers, granting you a swimming speed of 30 feet until the end of your turn.

Uncommon

Propellers no longer requires an action to use.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. In addition, this weapon has the reach property.

Rare

Burst of Spinning Blades. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, creatures (other than you) within 5 feet of the target must succeed on a [[/save dexterity 15]]saving throw or take [[/r 1d6[slashing]]]{1d6 slashing damage}.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Fish Reel. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can pull the target 10 feet toward you if it is your size or smaller. It must then succeed on a [[/save strength 15]]saving throw or be &Reference[grappled] (escape DC 15). While &Reference[grappled], the target is also &Reference[restrained].

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

Electrocute. Once per long rest, when you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can cause it to generate a 10-foot-radius sphere of electricity. Creatures of your choice within the sphere must make a [[/save dexterity 15]]saving throw, taking [[/r 8d6[lightning]]]{8d6 lightning damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures &Reference[restrained] by this weapon automatically fail this saving throw.

Bluefire.name: Bluefire
Bluefire.text:
The heat is on!

Lore

Little is known about Bluefire's origin. Rumors imply that the original owner and her companions were incinerated in a ball of blue flame.

Location

Bluefire is currently located in Millburg's Magic Menagerie, a shop that deals with the buying, pawning, trading, and selling of magical wares, owned by the pompous human proprietor Keifer Millburg (noble).

Encounter Ideas

  • Bluefire for Sale! Due to the rumors, Keifer has had little interest in the mace, which he acquired due to a delinquent pawn deal. He will happily sell the mace for the 500 gp sum owed.

  • This for That. Keifer offers to trade the mace for a lesser item (+1 shortsword) he has heard is stashed in a nearby monster's lair. If the characters currently possess Keifer's desired weapon, or a similar weapon, Keifer is more than willing to trade. He is more likely to sell the lesser item.

  • Stolen! Millburg's Magic Menagerie has been robbed! The store's "most valuable item," Bluefire, is offered as a reward if anyone retrieves it and the majority of the stolen wares.

Progression

Bluefire progresses whenever the attuned creature's Wisdom modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Mace), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Bluefire. Once per long rest, while holding this magic weapon, you can use a bonus action to speak the command word to cause the head to emit blue flames for 1 hour. You can speak the command word again (no action required) to end the effect early. While the flames have no heat, they cast bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. In addition, while Bluefire is active, the weapon deals extra fire damage equal to your proficiency bonus on a hit.

Rare

Azure Eruption. Once per long rest, while Bluefire is active, you can use an action to speak the command word to cause it to unleash a 30-foot cone of blue fire. Each creature in this area must make a [[/save dexterity 14]]saving throw, taking [[/r 3d6[fire]]]{3d6 fire damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2 and Bluefire's duration becomes a number of hours equal to your proficiency bonus. In addition, the DC of Azure Eruption increases to 16 and now recharges after a short or long rest.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3 and the DC of Azure Eruption increases to 18.

Azure Annihilation. Once per long rest, while Bluefire is active, you can use an action to speak the command word, causing it to unleash a ball of blue fire centered on the weapon. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere (including you) must make a [[/save dexterity 18]]saving throw, taking 10d10 + [[/r (10)[fire]]]{10 fire damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Brazen Hammer.name: Brazen Hammer
Brazen Hammer.text:
Made of brass. Not, you know, shameless.

Lore

There are many hells, home to demons, devils, their servants and prisoners. It is, somewhat famously, hard to escape them.

History remembers Tyrul the Forge Priest as a selfish, venal hypocrite who never wasted a moment's thought on the happiness of anyone but himself. He deserved to end up in the scorching hot city of brass to which his soul was condemned—but he had never been one to accept discomfort. Stealing materials from the monumental architecture around him, Tyrul forged a hammer to smash open the gates of hell and win his freedom.

It's not clear what happened to Tyrul afterwards, but the hammer is located on the Material Plane, which suggests he was successful.

Location

The maul now belongs to the tiefling bandit captain Vanyasha, who preys on traffic along the roadway from a kingdom's capital to its coast.

Encounter Ideas

  • My Worthless Father. Vanyasha is Tyrul the Forge Master's child, and it's not a happy relationship. Van would be delighted, and grateful, to characters who dragged their father back to hell. They'd express their gratitude with the gift of a big, brass hammer.

  • Whack-a-Mole. Vanyasha's not the only threat on the royal highway. There is a persistent bulette problem. Someone needs to go down into the deep, flooded caves beneath the road and deal with the situation. Van will even give the characters the hammer.

  • Restorative Justice. Vanyasha would sell the hammer for the right price—a few hundred gold pieces and a royal pardon for their crimes.

Progression

Brazen Hammer progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Maul), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Hell-Touched. This magic weapon is permanently warm. It is uncomfortable (but not damaging) to touch without gloves.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, and you have resistance to fire damage while holding it.

Rare

Infernal Body. When you finish a short or long rest, you gain temporary hit points equal to twice your proficiency bonus. While you have these temporary hit points, a creature who hits you with a melee attack takes fire damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Infernal Resilience. When you fail a saving throw against fire damage, roll a d6. On a result of 4–6, the weapon prevents you from taking damage, absorbing the damage and storing it as a charge. It can store up to 3 charges in this manner. If absorbing damage would increase the number of charges above 3, the weapon automatically discharges Infernal Brilliance (see below) as though 3 charges had been expended.

Infernal Brilliance. While holding this weapon, you can use an action to expend 1 charge to create a wave of heat. Each creature (including you) in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on the weapon must make a [[/save dexterity 16]]saving throw, taking [[/r 3d6[fire]]]{3d6 fire damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. You can expend additional charges to increase the radius by 5 feet or to increase the damage by 1d6 per charge. If you would take damage from this effect, you cannot prevent it with Infernal Resilience.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, the base damage for Infernal Brilliance increases to 5d6, and the number of storable charges increases to 5.

Cindersmash.name: Cindersmash
Cindersmash.text:
The warmth of home is something we often cannot do without.

Lore

After learning he would be trekking deep into the arctic regions of his realm, the renowned dwarven fighter Ezekial Hammerfist commissioned this mace. The weapon, which is made of a chunk of red lava rock attached to an ivory handle, provided the cleric and his companions a bit of warmth during his journey, until they were buried in an avalanche.

Location

Cindersmash's current location is unknown, although it is thought to still be buried under several feet of snow, with Ezekial and his companions.

Encounter Ideas

  • Frozen Dead. A band of undead (two skeletons and two zombies), led by an emaciated dwarf ghast wielding a fiery mace, have been attacking small villages and caravans.

  • Hole in the Snow. While trekking a snow-covered region, the adventurers' path is interrupted by a 15-foot-wide, 15-foot-deep hole in the snow. At the bottom of the hole lays a dead Ezekial, his companions, and Cindersmash.

  • Fun New Toy. A group of teenage explorers has found the weapon, though they are being chased by a group of undead (see above). The teenagers, having run for several miles, are becoming tired, while the unwavering undead are catching up to them.

Progression

Cindersmash progresses whenever the attuned creature’s proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Mace), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Warmth. Once per long rest, as a bonus action, you can speak this magic weapon's command word, causing its pocked-stone head to glow red, generating a 5-foot-radius sphere of heat for 1 hour. Each creature within the sphere has resistance to cold damage and advantage on cold related savings throws for the duration.

Uncommon

You now regain use of Warmth when you finish a short or long rest.

Blaze. Once per long rest, as a bonus action, you can speak the command word, causing the weapon's head to glow red and pop with molten sparks for 10 minutes, or until you use a bonus action to end the effect. For the duration, the weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[fire]]]{1d6 fire damage} on a hit.

Rare

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, and the fire damage of Blaze increases to [[/r 2d6]].

Very Rare

Eruption. Once per long rest, as an action, you can speak the command word while raising the weapon above your head, causing molten lava to erupt from it. Each creature within a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on the weapon (including you) must make a [[/save dexterity 15]]saving throw. A target takes [[/r 6d6[fire]]]{6d6 fire damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The eruption does not spread around corners but does ignite flammable objects in the area that are not being worn or carried.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. In addition, the fire damage of Blaze increases to 3d6, and the fire damage of Eruption increases to [[/r 8d6]]. You also have resistance to fire damage, or immunity if you already have resistance.

Counterpoise.name: Counterpoise
Counterpoise.text:
The scales of justice often weigh heavy.

Lore

Too often, the goddess of justice sees those in authority wield too much power, unbalancing the scales. To rebalance them, she created Counterpoise, a cursed sword that is both powerful and underwhelming.

Curse

This weapon is cursed with the power of a mighty god of justice, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. Until the curse is broken with greater restoration or similar magic, you are unwilling to part with the weapon, keeping it within reach at all times, and you have disadvantage on attack rolls made with weapons other than Counterpoise.

Location

Counterpoise is currently wielded by Samara Thorn (orc gladiator), a hired peacekeeper and bounty hunter. Samara, a brutish figure, enjoys using Counterpoise. She sees it as a test of her martial prowess.

Encounter Ideas

  • Bounty. Samara Thorn, hired by someone or something the characters recently irritated, confronts them, ready to claim her bounty.
  • Battle in Progress. The characters encounter a teenage group of new adventurers who recently stole a sum of gold from a local bandit captain. This young party tells the heroes they are being chased by an orc bounty hunter, but fails to tell them why.
  • Not So Fast! Samara, currently working as a peacekeeper in the town or village the characters are visiting, catches them doing dastardly or illegal deeds.

Progression Counterpoise progresses whenever the attuned creature's Wisdom modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Longsword), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Counterpoise is a nonmagical weapon that becomes magical when one of its properties is used.

Common

Advantageous Attack. Once per long rest, when you make an attack with this weapon, you can choose to attack with advantage. Doing so also makes the weapon magical until the end of your next turn.

Uncommon

The weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Tip the Scales. You can expend up to 2 charges to gain a bonus to attack and damage rolls with this weapon equal to the number of charges expended for 1 minute. Doing so also makes the weapon magical for the duration.

Rare

The weapon's total number of charges increases to 4, and you can now expend up to 3 charges at once. In addition, you can now use Advantageous Attack twice between long rests.

Very Rare

The weapon's total number of charges increases to 6, and you can now expend up to 4 charges at once.

Legendary

The weapon's total number of charges increases to 8, and you can now expend up to 5 charges at once.

Constellation.name: Constellation
Constellation.text:
A multitude of power from the stars.

Lore

Harbor Flur once adventured alongside his older sister,

Haven. Harbor, a bard fascinated by the stars and constellations, spent many years in his sister's shadow, but he never complained. He enjoyed their sibling bond too much. As a token of her love and appreciation when she retired, Haven commissioned Constellation for her younger brother, who still had many adventuring years ahead of him.

Location

Harbor and his companions are currently being held captive by the lich Gulgulspech. The undead arcanist frequently hires groups of thugs and adventurers to gather captives, which she then imprisons in her phylactery over the course of many months, appeasing the item's need for souls.

Encounter Ideas

  • The Request. Haven Flur, the priest of the small village Barcatur, has not heard from her younger brother in nearly a year. She hires the adventurers to locate him, offering a suitable reward. She details Harbor's thin build, red hair, and constellation-inspired rapier. She also gives them a special star-themed gold ring, which gently vibrates when it is within 1 mile of her brother's magical rapier, Constellation.
  • Um…That's Not Yours. The characters encounter a group of evil adventurers, who were recently hired by Gulgulspech (if they have the star-themed gold ring, it begins to vibrate). One of the evil sellswords carries a constellation-inspired rapier. They can share information about the lich and how she hired them to gather captives, but that information does not come easy.
  • Freakin' Lich. After destroying a lich named Gulgulspech, the adventurers find several prisoners in the undead's lair. Harbor may be one of the captives, or he may already be trapped inside the phylactery hidden somewhere in the lair. Harbor's famed rapier, Constellation, is found in the lich's treasure.

Progression

Constellation progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Rapier), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

This weapon's properties, which are inspired by the zodiac constellations, are learned as the weapon increases in power. These properties are detailed under "Constellations" below.

Common

When you attune to this magic weapon, you learn one of the following Constellations of your choice: Aquarius, Capricorn, Libra, or Virgo. To activate a Constellation, you must speak the command word (the Constellation's name). Each learned Constellation can only be used once per long rest.

Uncommon

You learn an additional three of the following Constellations of your choice: Aquarius, Aries, Cancer, Capricorn, Leo, Libra, or Virgo.

Rare

You learn an additional three of the following Constellations of your choice: Aquarius, Aries, Cancer, Capricorn, Gemini, Leo, Libra, Sagittarius, or Virgo.

Very Rare

You learn an additional three locked Constellations of your choice.

Legendary

You learn all remaining Constellations.

Constellations

The Constellations are presented here in alphabetical order.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.kh1RQEPRObdJvH3D]{Aquarius}. You can cast create food and water, but when cast this way, you can only create water.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.Xq2twOIA0nka6HFf]{Aries}. As an action, you can transform the weapon into a portable ram to break down doors. When doing so, you gain a +4 bonus on the Strength check. One other creature can help you use the ram, giving you advantage on this check. This transformation lasts for 1 hour, or until you speak the command word again (no action required).

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.UXboZHad9DrbxgrV]{Cancer}. As an action, you can manifest a phantasmal chitinous carapace to cover your body, granting you temporary hit points equal to three times your proficiency bonus. The carapace dissipates when the temporary hit points are lost, or when you finish a long rest.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.0dZnc9CuMrOu4kh7]{Capricorn}. You can cast spare the dying.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.cd3UBdBKQQpQVZF7]{Gemini}. You can cast mirror image.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.8vH6FiC3dNajdgY5]{Leo}. You can cast conjure animals. When cast this way, you summon one lion.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.UBxqIT5wOxEB4AOV]{Libra}. When you roll a 1 on the d20 for an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can use your reaction to reroll the die and must use the new roll. Alternatively, immediately after another creature makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw within 30 feet of you, you can use your reaction to force the target to reroll the die and they must use the new roll.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.AgMZjZNLzHBlce1S]{Pisces}. You can breathe underwater for a number of hours equal to your proficiency bonus.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.Et2gcp1ycaZKivbR]{Sagittarius}. You can cast magic missile. The level at which the spell is cast is equal to half your proficiency bonus.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.9oaUyEfpUUgpU52b]{Scorpio}. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can use your reaction to inject the target with poison. The target must make a [[/save constitution]] saving throw (save DC equal to 10 + your proficiency bonus), taking [[/r 4d10[poison]]]{4d10 poison damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.fdcYNe4IhF25OCsd]{Taurus}. Your Strength increases by 2, to a maximum of 22, for a number of hours equal to your proficiency bonus.

@UUID[Compendium.weapons-of-lore.jsg-wo-lore-progressing-weapons.Item.YfP2yYMdwpZQoX28]{Virgo}. You gain a bonus to Wisdom (Perception) and Intelligence (Investigation) checks equal to your proficiency bonus for a number of hours equal to your proficiency bonus. However, this bonus is not applied to your passive Perception.

Death Nail.name: Death Nail
Death Nail.text:
Sometimes, they do come back.

Lore

Death Nail was the magical weapon of The Ivory Fist, an undead knight who commanded legions of undead for centuries.

Location

The Ivory Fist was defeated many years ago during a battle between the undead and the dwarves. The dwarves created four bags of bones from the undead knight's corpse, and carried them unknown miles to the north, south, east, and west. Each bag was then secretly buried or hidden. The dwarf gladiator Ishira Bronzetongue claimed Death Nail from the battlefield. Not to use, but to keep safe and secure, out of evil's grasp.

Encounter Ideas

  • The Ivory Fist Rises! A cult has gathered The Ivory Fist's remains (use knight and add Undead Fortitude from the zombie stat block), allowing him to reassemble and walk the realm once again. The undead knight destroys lives and pillages towns as he hunts for Death Nail.
  • Safety First. The characters are hired by Ishira Bronzetongue to act as a security entourage as she transports a rare artifact. The Ivory Fist finally catches up with Ishira and Death Nail during the journey.
  • In the Hand of The Ivory Fist! The Ivory Fist has reclaimed the weapon from Ishira. Due to their fame, The Ivory Fist now hunts the characters.

Progression

Death Nail progresses whenever the attuned creature's Strength modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Javelin), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

After you make a ranged attack using this magic weapon, it flies back to your hand.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Death Splinters. Once per long rest, when you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can speak the command word, causing it to explode into a cloud of bone splinters. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on the weapon (including you) must make a [[/save dexterity 12]]saving throw, taking [[/r 4d6[piercing]]]{4d6 piercing damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Once this damage has been dealt, the weapon reforms and returns to your hand.

Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. In addition, the save DC for Death Splinters increases to 14, its damage increases to 5d6, its radius increases to 15 feet, and you are immune to the damage.

Very Rare

The save DC for Death Splinters increases to 16, its damage increases to 6d6, and its area increases to 20 feet.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

Life for Death. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can choose to lose a number of hit points equal to or less than your Strength score and deal necrotic damage to the target equal to the hit points lost.

Devouring Anvil.name: Devouring Anvil
Devouring Anvil.text:
"Swing and the Devouring Anvil will answer. Feed it the bones of the earth, the blood of the forge, or the breath of the storm—it hungers for more."

Lore

When her anvil was cursed by a rival runesmith, causing it to devour any substance worked upon it, Holena Runemane made the best of a difficult situation by converting the anvil into a large maul to take advantage of its new properties.

Location

Holena never fancied boats, and avoided them all her life, until conflict took her aboard an ironclad warship to the pirate kingdom of the Seaward Isles. She should have held to her skepticism. The warship, Vigilance, sank with all hands when it ran afoul of a kraken.

Encounter Ideas

  • The Iron Curse. Devouring Anvil's curse has spread, randomly transforming hulls into random substances. After many wrecks, something needs to be done to end, or move, the curse.
  • Rival Runesmith. Kudrass Goldbringer (gladiator) employs the characters to recover Devouring Anvil from the final resting place of his "friend." Holena's rival plans to betray the characters should they succeed.
  • Wreck of the Vigilance. The Vigilance went down with a map of the pirate fleet's holdings that many would pay dearly for, if the undead crew might be braved.

Progression

Devouring Anvil progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Maul), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Metamorphic Form. You can use a bonus action to change the composition of this magic weapon to either iron, quartz, silver, or wood.

Uncommon

Devour. You can use an action to feed the weapon 10 gp worth of the materials listed below. When you do, the weapon's composition transforms to match the material devoured and it gains a unique property (as detailed below) while transformed. The weapon can have only one material devoured at a time and devouring a new material replaces the current one.

Obsidian. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.
