Stone. Once per turn, a creature hit by this weapon must succeed on a [[/save strength 15]]saving throw or be knocked &Reference[prone] or pushed 10 feet (your choice). You can use this property a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain all uses when you finish a long rest.

Rare

You can now use Devour with the following materials, requiring 50 gp of each.

Adamantine. The weapon ignores resistance to bludgeoning damage for Constructs and objects.

Gemstone. The weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[radiant]]]{1d6 radiant damage} on a hit.

Very Rare

You can now use Devour with the following materials, requiring 500 gp of each.

Dragonscale. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra [[/r 2d8]] damage of a type determined by the breath weapon of the dragon that provided the scales.

Meteoric Iron. While holding this weapon, you have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Legendary

You can now use Devour with the following materials, requiring 1,000 gp of each.

Brimstone. The weapon emits bright light in a 40-foot radius and dim light for an additional 40 feet. This light illuminates any magical darkness except that created by a deity. In addition, the weapon deals an extra [[/r 3d10[fire]]]{3d10 fire damage} on a hit.

Titan's Blood. This weapon's damage ignores all resistances and immunities. In addition, it deals an extra [[/r 3d10[lightning]]]{3d10 lightning damage} on a hit.

Eclipse’s Edge.name: Eclipse’s Edge
Eclipse’s Edge.text:
This scimitar was designed to balance the forces of light and shadow.

Lore

Forged during a rare celestial event where the sun and moon align, Eclipse's Edge is a weapon of duality, embodying both the sun's radiant warmth and the moon's mysterious darkness.

Location

The last known bearer of Eclipse's Edge was a paladin torn between the power of two deities. The scimitar now lies in a temple that exists in both the material world and a shadowy realm, accessible only during solar and lunar eclipses.

Encounter Ideas

  • Twilight's Call. An order dedicated to maintaining balance in the world seeks heroes to wield the scimitar and free the sun god from a dark cult's imprisonment. They have enacted a powerful spell which stops the movement of the sun and moon during a solar eclipse, and now a shadow is perpetually cast over the land.
  • Shadow and Light. A thief specializing in acquiring magical artifacts hires the adventurers to steal Eclipse's Edge during a solar eclipse, not understanding its true power. When the weapon is removed from the sacred temple, the party is thrust into a shadowy realm and must find a way to return.
  • Moon's Light. A monster slayer recovered the scimitar but perished when they encountered their first lycanthrope. Now, a shapechanger wields Eclipse's Edge.

Progression

Eclipse's Edge progresses as its wielder performs acts that maintain or restore balance between opposing forces. Significant achievements are determined by the GM, but may include reconciling feuding factions or vanquishing a creature threatening to disrupt the world's natural order.

Statistics

Weapon (Scimitar), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to instantaneously light or snuff a candle, torch, or small campfire within 30 feet. In addition, you can use an action to cast the light cantrip, targeting this weapon.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. When you hit a creature with a CR equal to or greater than half your proficiency bonus with an attack using this weapon, the weapon gains 1 charge and begins to glow. The weapon can hold a maximum of 2 charges.

Lunar Strike. You can use an action to expend 2 charges to cast moonbeam (save DC 13). Once you have cast moonbeam from this weapon, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

Rare

The maximum number of charges the weapon can hold increases to 4 and you can expend additional charges to cast moonbeam at a level equal to the total number of charges expended. In addition, its save DC increases to 15. The weapon deals an extra 1d6 necrotic or radiant damage (your choice) to any target it hits. Additionally, you have darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision from your race, its range increases by 30 feet.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, the maximum number of charges the weapon can hold increases to 6, and the save DC of moonbeam increases to 17. In addition, you are immune to the &Reference[blinded] condition.

Solar Strike. You can use an action to expend 6 charges to cast sunbeam (save DC 17). Once you cast sunbeam from this weapon, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

Totality. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to speak the command word, causing magical darkness to spread in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on you for 1 minute. A creature with darkvision cannot see through this darkness, and nonmagical light cannot illuminate it. When you take this action, you can designate up to six creatures that can see through the magical darkness.

Eclipse’s Reach.name: Eclipse’s Reach
Eclipse’s Reach.text:
Morning’s light, darkest night, in the shadows twixt wield eclipse’s might.

Lore

The blade of this glaive was miraculously forged during the twilight of a solar eclipse. Legend claims that all the gods—light and dark—poured their energies into its blade, that it might be used by a mortal to fight against a foretold apocalypse.

Location

Eclipse's Reach is held in an aerie vault atop an ice-covered arctic mountain, where it is bathed in either constant sunlight or darkness for months at a time. Jarl Trym Goreslund (frost giant) prizes the glaive, preparing for the end of the world when he hopes to wield it in the final battle.

Encounter Ideas

  • Champions of the Trickster. The trickster god sees something special in the characters and hires them to acquire the glaive from Jarl Trym Goreslund.
  • Object of Contention. The celestial Jasophiel and the fiend Dorzizen prepare for the coming ruin of the mortal world. Both send champions to recover Eclipse's Reach from Jarl Goreslund.
  • Tentacle of Oblivion. Asuggatai the End Maker, an abomination between the stars, stirs in its slumber. As its attention grows, so do those that follow it. The Cult of Asuggatai seeks to destroy Eclipse's Reach so it cannot be prevented from destroying the world.

Progression

Eclipse's Reach progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Glaive), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Eclipse's Reach has Light and Dark properties, which can only be used by creatures of particular alignments and only at certain times. Light properties can only be used by good or neutral-aligned creatures and only during the day (between dawn and dusk). Dark properties can only be used by evil or neutral-aligned creatures and only during the night (between dusk and dawn).

Common

Once per long rest, while holding this magic weapon, you can either extinguish all nonmagical flames (Dark) or light all candles, torches, and lanterns (Light) within 60 feet of you.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Flames of the Sun (Light). Once per long rest, you can use an action to cast guiding bolt (spell attack bonus +5).

Stars' Design (Dark). Once per long rest, you can use an action to cast augury.

Rare

The weapon deals an extra 1d6 radiant (Light) or necrotic (Dark) damage on a hit. This damage increases to 2d6 against Aberrations and Monstrosities.

Flare's Reach (Light). When you attack with this weapon, you can increase your reach by 5 feet.

Subtle Shadows (Dark). You can use a bonus action to reduce this weapon to one-tenth its size (roughly the size of a dagger), making it easy to conceal. While this size, it cannot be used to make attacks. It remains this size for 1 hour, or until you use a bonus action to return it to normal size.

Very Rare

Solar Flare (Light). Once per long rest, you can use an action to create a brilliant flare of light in a 60-foot-radius sphere centered on you. Creatures in the area (excluding you) must succeed on a [[/save constitution 17]]saving throw or be &Reference[blinded] until the end of their next turn.

Starfall (Dark). Once per long rest, you can use an action to cause small comets to crash in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you can see within 100 feet. Each creature in this area must make a [[/save dexterity 17]]saving throw, taking [[/r 4d10[bludgeoning]]]{4d10 bludgeoning damage} on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. At the end of your turn, you can teleport anywhere within the former area of effect.

Legendary

Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to activate one of the following properties and alter your form for 10 minutes.

Brilliant Form (Light). You are infused with radiant energy. You gain resistance to necrotic damage and a +2 bonus to AC. In addition, whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes [[/r 2d8[radiant]]]{2d8 radiant damage}.

Shadow Form (Dark). You are infused with necrotic energy, covering you in shadows. You gain resistance to radiant damage and attack rolls against you have disadvantage.

Flowing Water Blade.name: Flowing Water Blade
Flowing Water Blade.text:
Never stop. Never break.

Lore

When she found herself fighting in the shallows of a river and disarmed by her opponent, it is said the monk Danae simply channeled her ki and drew a new blade from the current itself. She has never confirmed whether there is any truth to the tale—she just asks the teller if they believe it. However she came by it, Danae was never seen without her Flowing Water Blade; the many portraits and statues made in her honor all depict it, and all the tales tell of her grace, elegance, and command over the waters.

Location

Danae (gladiator) still has the blade to this day. She believes it's ready to find a new home, but the new wielder must swear to defeat the one enemy Danae never could: her nemesis, the fire elemental Gythaxzan.

Encounter Ideas

  • The Long Journey. Danae has become reclusive in her retirement. To reach her, the characters must not only follow a long and winding river to its mountainous source, but also navigate a challenging obstacle course she has created to deter visitors.
  • Fire and Ice. If the characters are going to take Danae's greatest weapon, she would appreciate it if they first made her home a little safer by dealing with the remorhaz that's made its lair in a nearby ice cave.
  • The Blade Itself. A temple Danae once rescued now finds itself in danger again. Danae cannot travel there herself, but charges the characters to take the blade, show it off as a symbol of her protection, and do what they must to defend the temple. Afterwards, they can keep the blade.

Progression Flowing Water Blade progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Shortsword), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement by a Monk)

Common

One With the Current. While holding this magic weapon, you have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Move as Water. You ignore difficult terrain created by liquid.

Rare

Flow State. You regain 1 ki point when you use the Dodge action.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Whirlpool. If you use the Dodge action, you have advantage on the next attack roll you make before the end of your next turn.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

The Flow and the Tide. You can use an action and spend 4 ki points to cast control water or freedom of movement. Once per long rest, you can cast one of these spells without spending ki points.

Hag’s Ladle.name: Hag’s Ladle
Hag’s Ladle.text:
What’s cooking in the hag’s kitchen?

Lore

Once upon a time, there was a swamp witch by the name of Abigail Blacktongue. The ill-tempered "Slurpin' Abby" had a reputation for concocting incredibly potent elixirs and equally powerful pejoratives. She would spread the latter about with a stunning liberality as she delighted in frustrating those who sought her concoctions. When her customary tirade drew the ire of a particularly hot-headed nobleman, causing him to draw steel and attack, Abby defended herself with the closest thing in reach: her long-handled metal spoon. While she had not quite intended to kill the bloke, she had, and, of course, it drew the expected bands of would-be justice seekers, revenge-takers, and bounty hunters. Unfortunately for each of them, Abby grew quite skilled with her silvery scoop, and before long, the legend of Hag's Ladle was born.

Location

Conflicting rumors state Hag's Ladle currently belongs to Sarah Sourheart, a pernicious, people-eating green hag, or is part of the kitchen equipment in the cave of the hill giant Hurghla the Huge.

Encounter Ideas

  • Boil and Bubble. The adventurers are hired to deliver rare ingredients to an isolated patron, only to discover they are on the menu! Their employer, a famished green hag, has Hag's Ladle.
  • Wicked, Shmicked. A frugal, yet naive cleric salvaged Hag's Ladle from a scrap heap. Now her healing draughts are drawing customers and making her famous. However, bad luck and ill fortune have befallen all who visit her small temple, and the party has been hired to investigate.
  • I'll Get You! The party discovers an insensate, babbling, travel-worn halfling clutching Hag's Ladle, who mumbles only "Ding Dong! Her sister is coming… Ding Dong!" until approached. Momentarily gaining lucidity, the halfling presses the spoon into the party's hands stating "She mustn't, MUSTN'T get this! EVER!" and runs off terror-stricken.

Progression

Hag's Ladle progresses whenever its wielder defeats a hag, witch, or similar malevolent entity, whether by force of arms, or by trickery and guile.

Statistics

Weapon (Light Hammer), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

While attuned to this magic weapon, when you finish a long rest, you gain proficiency in your choice of Arcana, Medicine, or Nature for 12 hours.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1 charge whenever you prepare a meal during a short rest, or 3 charges if you prepare a meal during a long rest.

Indigestion. You can use a bonus action to expend 1 charge while targeting a creature you can see within 60 feet of you, giving it a bout of severe stomach discomfort. The creature must succeed on a [[/save constitution 13]]saving throw or take [[/r 1d6[acid]]]{1d6 acid damage} and have disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws until the end of its next turn. Creatures that lack a digestive system are immune to this effect.

Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, the DC of Indigestion increases to 15, and its acid damage increases to [[/r 3d6]]. Your Charisma score is reduced by 1 as you develop unsightly warts, but your Constitution and Wisdom scores increase by 1, to a maximum of 20.

Very Rare

Your Charisma score decreases by 1.

Hideous. You can use an action to expend 1 charge to temporarily cause your face to appear grotesque and hideous, and your tongue to fork like a serpent's, granting you advantage on Charisma (Deception and Intimidation) checks for 1 minute.

Dire Hunger. You can use an action to expend 1 charge to unleash a powerful psychic wave that engulfs a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. The target must succeed on a [[/save intelligence 15]]saving throw or take [[/r 5d6[psychic]]]{5d6 psychic damage} and become afflicted by an insatiable hunger.

While under this effect, the target's mind is consumed by an overwhelming desire for sustenance. On its turn, it must use its movement to move toward the nearest source of nourishment, which can include food, creatures, or organic objects. The target must use its action to attempt to consume the source of sustenance, disregarding any potential consequences.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, or whenever it takes damage, ending the effects on itself on a success.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

Sisters Three. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to manifest two illusory duplicates of yourself, as per the simulacrum spell, that appear in unoccupied spaces within 5 feet of you, creating a temporary coven. The duplicates follow the rules of the spell with the following exceptions:

  • They do not know or have prepared the spells which you do, but they can cast any spell of 5th level or lower from the illusion or necromancy schools of magic that has a casting time of 1 action and does not have a material component with an indicated cost. They do not require spell slots to cast these spells.
  • At the end of your next turn after creating them, the duplicates are destroyed.

Hammer of Haughtiness.name: Hammer of Haughtiness
Hammer of Haughtiness.text:
Usually a symbol of keen intelligence, the wielder soon discovers the true meaning of the owl symbol.

Lore

This small warhammer was created by a halfling druid named Falamin, who was known as a trickster. Frustrated with self-proclaimed learned and wise elders, she spent years searching for the right wood to carve into the intricate owl figure, pouring all the irony she could muster into her craft.

Location

Before her death, Falamin set out to build a shrine in the forest where she lived. The shrine grew to be a sizable faux-temple, complete with imagery dedicated to gods of knowledge from many different pantheons.

In the inner sanctum of the complex, she placed Hammer of Haughtiness, hoping that one day she could trick someone into taking it.

Encounter Ideas

  • A Scholarly Endeavor. Acolytes of the god of intelligence have recently learned of the location of Falamin's "temple" and hire the party to retrieve the warhammer from the forest.
  • Trickster Fey. A group of fey have discovered the "temple" and share Falamin's sense of humor. While walking through the forest, the characters are herded in the direction of the temple by animated plants and given visions of power.
  • Dumb Opposition. An enemy of the party has recently learned of the warhammer and successfully retrieved it. That enemy has now decided to confront the adventurers with its newfound source of power.

Progression

Hammer of Haughtiness progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Warhammer), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Once per short or long rest, while holding this magic weapon, you can use a bonus action to gain darkvision out to a range of 60 feet for 1 minute.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, which deals an additional [[/r 1d6[bludgeoning]]]{1d6 bludgeoning damage} to creatures with an Intelligence score of 9 or less.

Rare

Hoot. Once per short or long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to cause it to emit a loud hooting noise. Any creature within 30 feet of you that can hear must succeed on a [[/save constitution 15]]saving throw or be &Reference[stunned] until the start of your next turn. Creatures with an Intelligence score of 9 or less have disadvantage on the saving throw.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, the additional damage to creatures with an Intelligence score of 9 or less increases to 2d6, and the DC of Hoot increases to 17.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, and the DC of Hoot increases to 19.

Mind Bonk. When you score a critical hit with this weapon against a creature that has an Intelligence score of 10 or higher, the target must succeed on a [[/save intelligence 19]]saving throw or have its Intelligence score reduced to 9 until it finishes a long rest.

Hearthfriend.name: Hearthfriend
Hearthfriend.text:
"Look, it cooks a mean meal and bashes a mean head— just think of the blood as seasoning."

—Tin Hillfeather, halfling warrior-chef

Lore

This mithral frying pan is a renowned weapon among halflings, passed between various legendary warriors in their hours of need. Meals cooked on its seasoned metal are said to imbue the consumer with heroic traits.

Location

Hearthfriend's most recent wielder was a halfling ranger called Meredith Rosemantle. After retiring from adventuring, she built a tavern called The Laughing Rose, where she uses her magical frying pan to serve delicious meals.

Encounter Ideas

  • A Nostalgic Meal. Meredith is hosting a banquet for her old adventuring companions. She offers Hearthfriend to the characters if they bring her rare and exquisite ingredients from nearby monster lairs.
  • Evil Resurges. An old enemy from Meredith's adventuring days destroys The Laughing Rose and abducts Meredith, leaving only Hearthfriend behind. The townsfolk offer a hefty reward for her safe return.
  • Passing the Torch. The characters encounter a halfling warrior killed by a dragon. The halfling's ghost bequeaths Hearthfriend to the party and begs for their fallen comrades to be avenged.

Progression

Hearthfriend progresses the first time its wielder cooks a meal for their friends after each proficiency bonus increase, or during other important meals, at the GM's discretion.

Statistics

Weapon (Warhammer), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Heroic Meal. When finishing a long rest, you can cook and eat a heroic meal. You gain temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus (or twice your bonus if you are a Halfling).

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. In addition, you can share your Heroic Meal with up to two other creatures, granting them the same benefits.

Flick and Flip. When you score a critical hit against a creature with this weapon, the target must succeed on a [[/save strength 13]]saving throw or be flipped like an pancake, landing &Reference[prone].

Rare

The DC of Flick and Flip increases to 15 and the target is now also flung 10 feet in the air, taking falling damage before landing &Reference[prone]. In addition, Heroic Meal is now imbued with the gifts of the weapon's previous wielders. When you cook a Heroic Meal, choose one of these virtues: bravery, hardiness, or wit. Each creature that eats the meal can add 1d4 to its saving throws against the condition corresponding to the chosen virture until the end of its next long rest. The conditions are as follows: &Reference[frightened] (bravery), &Reference[poisoned] (hardiness), or &Reference[charmed] (wit).

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, the DC of Flick and Flip increases to 17, and it now flings its target 20 feet into the air. In addition, you can now share your Heroic Meal with up to four other creatures.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, the DC of Flick and Flip increases to 19, and it now flings a target 30 feet into the air. In addition, you can now share your Heroic Meal with up to eight other creatures.

Heroic Banquet. When you cook a Heroic Meal, you can replace the meal's normal benefits with those of the heroes' feast spell. Once used, you cannot use this property again for 7 days.

Icon of the Deceiver.name: Icon of the Deceiver
Icon of the Deceiver.text:
Believe it, or not!

Lore

Ages ago, a brazen witch trapped the Deceiver in a crystal orb. From within his prison, the demon appears like a swollen, watchful eye. It's said the black blade the witch fashioned around the eye is quick, cunning, and can guide the wielder with visions—if one can trust visions granted by the Lord of Liars.

Location

Icon of the Deceiver lies within the Vaults of Turgoth, where its champion was overcome with despair and discarded it once and for all.

Encounter Ideas

  • Border Ruffians. A bandit captain and her followers seem to always know the exact time and place nobles are transporting their riches on the road. Reports say she carries a sword with a crystal eye.
  • Come and Get It. A foolish thief struts into a tavern with Icon of the Deceiver on his hip. Within minutes, the place is roaring with bloodshed as cutthroats fight over the sword.
  • Doomed Lovers. Hired to discover the fate of a renowned assassin and his betrothed, the characters find them in the Vaults of Turgoth, embracing with the sword piercing them both.

Progression

Icon of the Deceiver progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Longsword), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

This magic weapon has the light and finesse properties when you wield it.

Ravenous Razor. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the blade howls and roars with delight, which can be heard up to 300 feet away.

Uncommon

Spells of Truth and Delusion. You can cast the following spells from this weapon (save DC 13): alter self, augury, hideous laughter, and see invisibility. Once you cast one of these spells, you cannot cast it this way again until you finish a long rest. For the spell's duration, the Deceiver's voice taunts you through the crystal ball, loudly divulging your secrets, audible to anyone within 30 feet.

Rare

Uncharmed. If you are targeted by an effect that would charm you, roll a d100. On a result of 36 or higher, you are immune to the effect for 1 minute.

Delusion of Grandeur. The weapon deals an additional [[/r 2d8[psychic]]]{2d8 psychic damage} on a hit. If you roll an 8 on one or more of these damage dice, you also take half the psychic damage.

Very Rare

The save DCs of all spells cast using Spells of Truth and Delusion increase to 15.

Soul Siphon. When this weapon reduces a creature to 0 hit points, the creature's soul is drawn into the crystal, blocking any magic that would restore it to life, short of a wish spell.

Form of the Slain. Once per long rest, you can use an action to cast seeming (save DC 15), granting targets the appearance of one or more creatures whose souls are in the crystal eye.

Legendary

The psychic damage inflicted by Delusion of Grandeur increases to [[/r 3d8]]. In addition, Spells of Truth and Delusion can now be used to cast nondetection and scrying, and the save DCs of all spells cast using this weapon increase to 17.

Lucid Warblade.name: Lucid Warblade
Lucid Warblade.text:
This headsman’s axe lulls its victims into a slumber they can never return from.

Lore

It is written in pages of the Necronomicon that lucid warblades contain a fragment of a nightmare conjured by Cthulhu itself. Inscribed along the haft is the prayer, "Ph'nglui mglw'nfah Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn," which translates as "In his house at R'lyeh, dead Cthulhu waits dreaming." Cthulhu's Phgl'noigh (or Grand Shade), leads the congregation of Cthulhu cultists wielding a lucid warblade.

Location

Lucid warblades are displayed in a place of honor within any unholy den the Cult of Cthulhu is using as a sanctuary. The blade is always within easy reach for the Phgl'noigh giving a sermon or conducting a ceremony. The cult would never abandon a sanctuary without taking the lucid warblade with them; to discover a lucid warblade is a strong indication that that cell of cultists has been defeated.

Encounter Ideas

  • Iron Maiden. Qevvit Mesk was a powerful Phgl'noigh, in his time. According to legend, he was a dream warrior without equal. He was ultimately defeated by trapping him and his lucid warblade within an enchanted iron maiden, which prevented him from focusing his dream-self. Today, Mesk is a weakened lich trapped within the torture coffin with a lucid warblade.
  • Dreamlands. The adventurers are whisked into the realm of dreams. There, they must recover a lucid warblade with the hope that it can break the spell that has trapped them in the lands of the unreal.
  • The Call. An adventurer, sensitive to magics that permeate the land, feels a compulsion to find the lucid warblade. They can feel it calling out to them in their dreams, which steadily become nightmares that haunt them even during their waking hours until they recover the damned blade.

Progression

Lucid warblades progress whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Battleaxe), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

This magic weapon has 3 charges, and regains a variable number of charges at night based on the current phase of the moon.

Moon Phase

Number of Charges

Full moon

3 charges

Half moon

2 charges

Crescent moon

1 charge

New moon

0 charges

Energize. You can use a bonus action to expend 1 charge to energize the weapon, bathing it in a green glow until the end of your next turn. For the duration, you gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Uncommon

You can now expend up to 2 charges when using Energize, gaining a bonus to attack and damage rolls equal to the number of charges expended. In addition, Energize now lasts for 1 minute.

Nimble. While the weapon is Energized, you gain uncanny combat dexterity. When hit by an attack you can see, you can use your reaction to attempt to reduce the damage by half. To do so, make a [[/save dexterity]] saving throw, with the DC equal to the attacker's attack roll.

Sleep. You can use an action to expend 1 charge to cast sleep. You can expend additional charges to cast it at a level equal to the total number of charges expended.

Rare

The weapon's maximum number of charges increases to 6 and you can now expend up to 3 charges at a time when using Energize. In addition, Energize now lasts for 1 hour.

Lucidity. While attuned to this weapon, you no longer need to sleep, but can choose to fall asleep if you wish.

Very Rare

Gifts from Cthulhu. While attuned to this weapon, your Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores increase by 1, as does the maximum for each score. However, your Wisdom score is reduced by 1. In addition, you gain 2d6 hit points, and your hit point maximum increases by the same amount.

Dreamwalk. While sleeping, you can astrally project yourself into another sleeping mind as long as you know exactly where the target is slumbering. Your astral form has the same statistics as your material form, and you can communicate and interact with the sleeper's astral form, including attacking it. While using Dreamwalk, your material form holds an ineffective, ethereal version of the weapon.

Legendary

Vorpal. When you attack a creature that has at least one head with this weapon and roll a 20 on the attack roll, you cut off one of the creature's heads. The creature dies if it cannot survive without the lost head. A creature is immune to this effect if it is immune to slashing damage, does not have or need a head, has legendary actions, or the GM decides that the creature is too big for its head to be cut off with this weapon. Such a creature instead takes an extra [[/r 6d8[slashing]]]{6d8 slashing damage} from the hit.

The Call of Cthulhu. While sleeping, you can communicate with Great Cthulhu. Cthulhu may answer up to 3 questions, but each answer reduces your Wisdom score by 1. If your Wisdom is reduced to 0, you become &Reference[incapacitated]. While &Reference[incapacitated] this way, you are aware of your surroundings but cannot interact with them. It is at the GM's discretion how truthful or helpful Cthulhu's answers are.

Mariway’s Staff.name: Mariway’s Staff
Mariway’s Staff.text:
No cleric, no problem.

Lore

Tired of her adventuring party's cleric constantly falling in battle before they could heal her, Mariway Quell, a renowned wizard, commissioned a magical quarterstaff. Her instructions were that the staff would hold the power to heal, while also providing additional protection against weapon attacks. Mariway was unaware, however, that the artist she commissioned the staff from was a bit of a trickster. Yes, the staff held the ability to heal, but that came at a cost. Yes, the staff provided additional protection, but not all at once.

Slightly miffed at the artisan's final product, Mariway took the staff and found it not only met her needs, but its reputation also thwarted would-be bandits or thugs from confronting her.

Location

The quarterstaff is still in the possession of Mariway Quell (mage), who quietly rests in her lakeside cabin. Mariway is wealthy enough, so she is not interested in selling the staff. However, she is willing to offer it as a reward if the characters can complete a quest for her.

Encounter Ideas

  • Hydra Power. The lake near Mariway's cabin has recently attracted a hydra. If the characters successfully dispatch the monstrosity, Mariway rewards them with the staff.
  • Deep Dive. Mariway stores much of her treasure in small yet heavy chests, which are scattered in secret locations about the bottom of the 300-footdeep lake. She is running low on gold and asks the adventurers to retrieve a small chest by diving to the bottom, pointing out a specific location. The chest requires a combined Strength score of 30 to lift and retrieve from the bottom of the lake.
  • Ransacked. While away, Mariway's cabin was looted by brigands (three bandit captains, an assassin, and a mage). Her only possession of high value is the quarterstaff, which she offers as a reward if the characters can locate her stolen goods and return them to her.

Progression

Mariway's Staff progresses whenever the attuned creature's Wisdom modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Quarterstaff), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement by a Creature with the Spellcasting Feature)

Common

Mariway's Cost. When you attune to this magic weapon, you must permanently sacrifice one Hit Die to the weapon. You remove this Hit Die from your pool but regain it when your attunement to this weapon ends. The size of the sacrificed die is the size of your Cost die, which is used for properties gained as this weapon progresses.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Mariway's Health. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to expend a 1st-level spell slot to regain hit points equal to your Cost die roll + your spellcasting ability modifier.

Rare

When using Mariway's Health, you can now expend a higher level spell slot (up to a maximum of 3rd level) to increase the healing by one Cost die for each slot level above 1st.

Mariway's Armor. You gain a +1 bonus to AC while holding this weapon.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. The highest level spell slot you can expend for Mariway's Health increases to 4th level.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. In addition, the bonus to AC granted by Mariway's Armor increases to +2. The highest level spell slot you can expend for Mariway's Health increases to 5th level.

Master Key.name: Master Key
Master Key.text:
Who needs a key when you have an axe?

Lore

Lore Master Key was once wielded by the mighty paladin Adamis, who had a hankering for cleaving doors with his axe. To speed up Adamis's holy quests, Master Key was gifted to him by his god.

Location

Adamis and his companions perished while fighting a menacing vampire. Master Key currently lies next to Adamis's plate-armor-clad skeleton in a dark, musty dungeon filled with undead creatures and the vampire.

Encounter Ideas

  • A Gift from the Dead! The party's holiest character is confronted by the ghostly image of the glorious, dark haired Adamis, who carries an ethereal Master Key. Adamis gifts the weapon to the character while saying, "For when you have no key." The ethereal weapon becomes tangible when Adamis's ghostly image dissipates.

  • Vampire Thief. The characters are tasked with investigating a series of murders and robberies. In nearly every case, the location's door was bashed in, and those inside were drained of blood. A human thief, now a vampire spawn, wields the weapon, unable to satisfy their thirst for blood and hunger for riches.

  • What's That on the Wall? A group of adventurers recovered Master Key from a vampire's dark dungeon and, before perishing from their wounds, sold it to a local shopkeep.

Progression

Master Key progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Greataxe), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Breaker of Doors. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls against doors and locks made with this magic weapon.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, and the bonus granted by Breaker of Doors increases to +3.

Tools. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to speak the command word, causing the weapon to transform into a mundane set of thieves' tools for 10 minutes. You gain proficiency with thieves' tools while using the weapon this way. You can speak the command word again to end the transformation early.

Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and you can now use Tools once per short or long rest.

Knock. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to cast knock.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls granted by Breaker of Doors increases to +5.

Dispel. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to cast dispel magic (if you do not have the Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature, you make an [[/skill arcana]] check in place of the spellcasting ability check).

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, and you can now use Knock once per short or long rest.

Lock. Once per short or long rest, you can use a bonus action to cast arcane lock.

Open Sesame. Once per long rest, you can cast passwall.

Mist Guardian.name: Mist Guardian
Mist Guardian.text:
“Fly, Ixkakaw, and may your beauty bring the mists and rain!”

Lore

When the warrior Yaluk lost her toucan companion Ixkakaw, an archdruid enchanted her war pick, so that it took on the toucan's form, bestowing blessings of renewal.

Location

Yaluk was buried 200 years ago deep in the jungle, but the intervening centuries saw her tomb (and Mist Guardian) plundered.

Encounter Ideas

  • Hunt for the Pick. Until a warrior tracks and soothes it, Mist Guardian flies about the jungle in the form of a resplendent toucan.
  • Spring Cleaning. A satyr named Henker Mosstoe stole Mist Guardian to wash and tidy his grove in the Feywild. Henker wields the enchanted war pick with gusto.
  • Grave Robbers. Pirates stormed Yaluk's tomb and took Mist Guardian, but their voyage home was cut short when the ship sank and became a giant shark den.

Progression

Mist Guardian progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (War Pick), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Misty Dew. While holding this magic weapon, you can use a bonus action to cause your space to be lightly obscured by a refreshing spray of cool mist. This mist disappears after 1 minute, or when you use this property again.

Uncommon

Ixkakaw's Virtue. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to create a rainbow arch in your space. Creatures of your choice that can see the rainbow can use their reaction to regain 2d4 hit points and neutralize one poison affecting it.

Rare

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Rain of Renewal. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to cause a pleasant-smelling rain to fall from the sky in a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on you, which lightly obscures the area. The rain moves with you and falls for 1 minute, or until you dismiss it as a bonus action. Creatures within the rain immediately end any of the following conditions affecting them: &Reference[blinded], &Reference[paralyzed], &Reference[poisoned], or &Reference[stunned].

Very Rare

Bird of Paradise. Once per long rest, you can use an action to summon a toucan spirit from the weapon. The spirit disappears after 1 minute or when it drops to 0 hit points.

The spirit is an ally to you and your companions. In combat, the spirit shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It obeys your verbal commands (no action required by you). If you do not issue any, it takes the Dodge action and uses its move to avoid danger. While the spirit is summoned, you cannot use Ixkakaw's Virtue or Rain of Renewal.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the spirit summoned by Bird of Paradise gains new spells, as detailed in its stat block.

My Lady’s Favor.name: My Lady’s Favor
My Lady’s Favor.text:
Are you saying a greatclub’s not a romantic gift?

Lore

If you're in love with a mighty barbarian warrior who faces only the most lethal opponents and the most dangerous challenges, you do not give her flowers. You give her something she can use.

That was the line of thinking the mage Ceridwen used when devising a suitable gift to woo the legendary barbarian hero Amalthea. Give her something she could use. Something practical. Something that would solve Amalthea's two most frequent problems: smashing a creature's head like a ripe melon, and fitting in at the sort of sophisticated events all heroes are eventually required to attend. Given that Amalthea already excelled at meeting the first challenge, Ceridwen placed greater emphasis on the second.

Location

Amalthea (gladiator) still has the greatclub, but after her breakup with Ceridwen she used it as a support beam to shore up her cellar ceiling. She will give it away readily once reminded of its existence, but there will be a devastating fit of rage first, as she recalls the dramatic end of her relationship.

Encounter Ideas

  • Tell Her I Said… In exchange for giving away the greatclub, Amalthea wants the characters to deliver a letter to her ex-lover, Ceridwen. It details the breakdown of their relationship, everything Amalthea blames Ceridwen for, and could well earn the characters an archmage as an enemy.
  • Load-Bearing Club. The characters are going to need to find something to hold up that ceiling, if they're taking the greatclub away.

  • Where Did You Get That? Once the characters have My Lady's Favor, they encounter Ceridwen. Once convinced they did not steal it from the woman the mage once loved, Ceridwen asks them for help: appease the dryads from whose grove she, umm, liberated the club's wood.

Progression

My Lady's Favor progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Greatclub), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Appropriately Dressed. While this magic weapon is on your person, you can use a bonus action to change the appearance of your clothing to something appropriate to the current situation.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Appropriately Charming. You gain proficiency in the Persuasion skill. If you are already proficient, you gain expertise instead.

Rare

When you use Appropriately Dressed to change your clothing, you can also remove bloodstains, damage, or other imperfections.

Appropriately Vicious. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to increase your Strength score by a number equal to your proficiency bonus (to a maximum of 22). This increase lasts for 10 minutes.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Appropriately Devastating. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can use your reaction to expend 1 charge to cast shatter as a 4th-level spell (save DC 17) centered on this weapon. You are unaffected by the spell.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. The maximum Strength score you can achieve with Appropriately Vicious increases to 25.

Onomatopoeia.name: Onomatopoeia
Onomatopoeia.text:
Don’t leave a mark? I’ll leave a mark!

Lore

Knuckle dusters are designed to enhance a person's fist attacks. Onomatopoeia was designed to not only inflict more damage, but to also humiliate its target.

Location

Geoffrey Tonguesplitter, a dwarf brawler, wears this weapon, brandishing it in taverns and bars as he tries to instigate brawls. Geoffrey is known as a bully, but would be much less without his magical knuckle duster.

Encounter Ideas

  • Nomipotiwa!! The characters witness Geoffrey (gladiator) brandishing his knuckle duster in a tavern as he exclaims, "I'll bash you with my magic weapon Nomipotiwa!" Geoffrey cannot pronounce or spell onomatopoeia.
  • What's That on Your Face? The characters encounter a townsperson with the word "Wham!" embedded in their face. The townsperson explains they had a run in with Geoffrey, the town bully.
  • Let's Get It On!? A frisky Geoffrey challenges one of the characters, who then encounters the weapon's power firsthand.

Progression

Onomatopoeia progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Wondrous Item, Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

These knuckle dusters are worn over your fists. When you hit a target with an unarmed strike, the creature takes an additional [[/r (1)[bludgeoning]]]{1 bludgeoning damage}.

Ka-Pow! Once per short or long rest, when you hit a target with an unarmed strike, you can speak the command word "Ka-Pow!" to deal an extra [[/r 1d4[bludgeoning]]]{1d4 bludgeoning damage}.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with unarmed strikes. In addition, Ka-Pow! can now be used at will.

Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

This item has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Bam! When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can expend 1 charge while speaking the command word "Bam!" to deal an extra [[/r 1d8[thunder]]]{1d8 thunder damage}. In addition, the creature must succeed on a [[/save strength 15]]saving throw or be pushed 5 feet away from you.

Insulting Injury. When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike and speak one of this item's command words, you can expend 1 charge to give the target disadvantage on its next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw.

Very Rare

The item's total number of charges increases to 5, and the save DC of Bam! increases to 17.

Wham! When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can expend 2 charges while speaking the command word "Wham!" to deal an extra [[/r 1d10[bludgeoning]]]{1d10 bludgeoning damage}. After the attack, the word "Wham!" is embossed on the creature's armor, clothing, or skin where your hit landed, which remains until the creature finishes a short or long rest. While the word remains, the creature has disadvantage on Charisma checks and saving throws.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, the item's total number of charges increases to 7, and the save DC of Bam! increases to 19. In addition, you can now customize the embossed word created by Wham! and the word remains until the creature finishes a long rest.

Ka-Pow! Bam! Wham! When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can expend 4 charges while speaking all three command words "Ka-Pow! Bam! Wham!" to deal an extra [[/r 6d6[thunder]]]{6d6 thunder damage}. In addition to gaining an embossed word as per Wham!, the creature must succeed on a [[/save strength 19]]saving throw or be pushed 10 feet away from you and knocked &Reference[prone].

Osterot’s Hand.name: Osterot’s Hand
Osterot’s Hand.text:
When in combat, time is of the essence.

Lore

The elf ranger Evelyn Osterot was not only precise with a bow, she was also deadly with her short swords. Despising the time it took to change weapons, and unwilling to drop one on the battlefield, Evelyn commissioned this weapon, which acts as both a bow and a melee weapon, and provides additional defense when in melee combat.

Location

Osterot's Hand currently rests under a glass case secured by an arcane lock spell, inside Professor Waddle's Weapons of Lore: a museum dedicated to preserving historical weapons. During tours, Professor Waddle, a duck-like humanoid, explains how the ranger Evelyn Osterot's heroic and noble acts not only made her a famous adventurer, but also lead to her demise: devoured by a giant lizard creature from the deep southern jungles.

Encounter Ideas

  • Stolen. Professor Waddle's Weapons of Lore was recently ransacked. The devious villains stole many historical and magical weapons. Professor Waddle hires the adventurers to retrieve the stolen goods. As a reward, he offers the party one Weapon of Lore (including Osterot's Hand), or a combination of common, uncommon, and rare magic weapons.

  • New Prize. Professor Waddle requires gold to fund his planned expansion: Professor Waddle's Arcane Wonders. To facilitate the funding, he sold Osterot's Hand to a collector. Transactions have occurred via messenger, but the weapon's transfer requires armed security, which the adventurers can provide. For their services, Professor Waddle offers a total of 1,000 gp, or a combination of common, uncommon, and rare magic weapons.

  • Death Patrol. The Death Patrol—a band of villains consisting of an assassin, knight, mage, spy, and veteran—conspire to acquire Osterot's Hand. They either steal the weapon from Professor Waddle's Weapons of Lore or, having learned of its recent sale and planned transportation, ambush the security team tasked with transferring the weapon to its new owner.

Progression

Osterot's Hand progresses whenever the attuned creature's Wisdom modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Longbow), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Piercing Stab. You can use this magic bow as a melee weapon with the finesse property. When used this way, the weapon deals [[/r 1d4[piercing]]]{1d4 piercing damage} on a hit.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Parry. You can use your reaction to add 1 to your AC against one melee attack that would hit you. To do so, you must see the attacker and be wielding this weapon.

Rare

Silvered Ammunition. The weapon no longer requires ammunition. Instead, when you draw the weapon's string, a piece of silvered ammunition appears. This ammunition disappears after hitting its target.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. In addition, the weapon's melee damage increases to 1d6, and the bonus to AC provided by Parry increases to 2.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. In addition, the weapon's melee damage increases to 1d8, and the bonus to AC provided by Parry increases to 3.

Pilum of the Lost Legion.name: Pilum of the Lost Legion
Pilum of the Lost Legion.text:
Thin green ichor perpetually drips from this spear’s barbed head. A tattered pennant flaps even when there is no wind.

Lore

In a city so lost to antiquity that not even its name is remembered, a lone legionnaire prayed to the god of death the night before the city's fall. He knew his small legion could not prevail against the besieging hordes, so he asked for the ability to deal as much death to his enemies as he could before he succumbed himself. When he woke, Pilum of the Lost Legion was gripped in his hand. The hordes took the city later that day, but not before the legionnaire felled dozens of them.

Location

After its first appearance, Pilum of the Lost Legion occasionally appeared at other battles where all seemed lost for the forces of order. Following the death of its most recent wielder, it has been lost once again.

Encounter Ideas

  • Gift of the Sands. While lost in the desert, or following a prolonged sandstorm, the characters find Pilum of the Lost Legion partially buried in the sand. When they pick it up, a trio of earth elementals rise to prevent it being claimed.
  • Lost Cause. The night before a climactic battle, one of the characters has a dream in which a shadowy figure offers them a better chance to prevail in return for serving the god of death. If the character agrees, they wake gripping Pilum of the Lost Legion.
  • Undead Legion. A mummy leading a horde of zombies and skeletons wields the spear.

Progression

Pilum of the Lost Legion progresses each time its wielder uses it to kill a creature with a CR that is 3 or more higher than their level. The wielder must use the spear to deal at least one third of the damage required to kill the creature. Once the spear has progressed, it cannot do so again until the wielder's level increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Spear), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Living Banner. While holding this magic weapon, and while no friendly creature is within 10 feet of you, you have advantage on saving throws against being pushed or knocked &Reference[prone].

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, which now deals an extra [[/r 1d8[poison]]]{1d8 poison damage} on a hit. In addition, Living Banner now grants immunity to being pushed or knocked &Reference[prone].

Rare

Stand Like a Bastion. Once per long rest, if you are within 5 feet of an enemy, and no friendly creature is within 10 feet of you, you can use a bonus action to enter a defensive stance. While in this stance, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures within 5 feet of you and you add your proficiency bonus to your AC and the damage you deal with this weapon. You can remain in the stance for 1 minute, or until you are &Reference[incapacitated].

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the extra poison damage increases to [[/r 2d8]].

Legendary

While in the defensive stance of Stand Like a Bastion, having 0 hit points does not knock you &Reference[unconscious]. You still must make death saving throws, and you suffer the normal effects of taking damage while at 0 hit points. However, if you would die due to failing death saving throws, you do not die until your stance ends, and you die then only if you still have 0 hit points. In addition, you are immune to being &Reference[grappled], &Reference[incapacitated], &Reference[paralyzed], &Reference[petrified], &Reference[restrained], &Reference[stunned], or &Reference[unconscious] while in this stance.

Rising Tide.name: Rising Tide
Rising Tide.text:
Pearlescent light reflects off the conch-like head of this mace. Lightly etched tentacles wind around the haft.

Lore

Rising Tide was crafted for the monarch of an ancient aquatic empire, as a gift from his most loyal subjects. As it passed from one ruler to another over the ages, it came to be seen as the sign of sovereignty over the entire ocean. When the empire fell, Rising Tide was lost and forgotten for centuries.

Location

Rising Tide is currently in the hands of a tyrannical gladiator who uses the power it grants him, as well as his two pet basilisks, to reign over the inhabitants of a series of small islands. The tyrant is building their power base in order to conquer a coastal kingdom on the mainland.

Encounter Ideas

  • Servants of the Waves. A troupe of eight merfolk knights riding upon giant sharks is harassing coastal villages and local shipping. The leader of the group is wielding Rising Tide.
  • Sunken Treasure. Characters find Rising Tide in a waterlogged chest near a long-sunken wreck. The chest is guarded by the wraiths of the ship's captain and first mate.
  • Dragon Runners. The characters are given the mace as a reward for besting a competitive dragon turtle in a race.

Progression

Rising Tide progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Mace), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Attacks made with this magic weapon while underwater do not impose disadvantage.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Tidal Reach. You can use a bonus action to mentally command the weapon's haft to extend into a ten-footlong tentacle tipped with the mace's pearlescent conch head, granting it the reach property.

Rare

The weapon has 5 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Master of Tides. While holding this weapon, you can use an action to expend a number of charges to cast one of the following spells: alter self (2 charges), conjure animals (3 charges), control water (4 charges). You can expend additional charges to increase the spell slot level of these spells by one for each additional charge expended. When you cast alter self from this weapon, you can only choose the Aquatic Adaptation benefit, and when you cast conjure animals from it, the spirits you summon must take the form of creatures who make their home in the ocean.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the weapon's total number of charges increases to 7.

Tidal Shield. When you are hit with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to expend 1 charge to push your attacker 20 feet away from you with a jet of water.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, and the weapon's total number of charges increases to 9. In addition, you can now cast the following spells with Master of Tides: freezing sphere (6 charges), wall of ice (6 charges), or control weather (8 charges). Once per long rest, using Master of Tides, you can cast alter self without expending charges.

Ruldar’s Steeds.name: Ruldar’s Steeds
Ruldar’s Steeds.text:
One may not always need a steed, but when they do, this club provides.

Lore

Ruldar the Barbarian's clan crafted this club for their champion. Being the protector of the clan, Ruldar often needed to travel in a hurry. This club, exquisitely worked from the tree of a white elm and carved with the likenesses of a lizard, duck, scorpion, and shark, provided him with steeds for various environments.

Location

Ruldar, an 85-year-old human man, still wields the club, but is in search of someone to purchase it. He has become too old to be a reliable protector, and the clan needs gold to repair deteriorating property.

Encounter Ideas

  • Horde of Steeds. The adventurers witness Ruldar (gladiator) battling a group of bandits. Though seemingly outnumbered, Ruldar uses Summon the Horde to tip the scales in his favor.
  • Travel by Duck. While traveling to their next destination, the adventurers encounter Ruldar, who at the time is riding Quackers.
  • Club For Sale. Ruldar travels from village to village seeking out a buyer for the club. However, his asking price of 6,000 gp is too high for many interested parties.

Progression

Ruldar's Steeds progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Club), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Animal Love. While attuned to this magic weapon, you gain proficiency with the Animal Handling skill. If you are already proficient, you gain expertise instead.

Uncommon

Honorable Steed. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to cast find steed. When cast this way, the spell summons Lula, a giant lizard. All steeds summoned by this spell are Fey.

Rare

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. When you use Honorable Steed, you can now summon Lula or Quackers, a giant duck.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. When you use Honorable Steed, you can now summon Lula, Quackers, or Chips (giant scorpion).

Summon the Horde. When using Honorable Steed, you can choose to lose 35 hit points. When you do, you summon Lula, Quackers, and Chips at once. When summoned this way, the spell's duration is 1 hour. You can extend the duration by an hour by losing an additional 10 hit points per hour the duration is extended.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. When you use Honorable Steed, you can now summon Lula, Quackers, Chips, or Garg (giant shark). Summon the Horde now summons your choice of three of the four available steeds and you can summon all four at the cost of an additional 15 hit points.

Dimension Door. While holding this weapon, you can use an action to lose 40 hit points and cast dimension door.

Scalehead.name: Scalehead
Scalehead.text:
The power of dragons, in the palm of your hand..

Lore

It is said that the Council of Metallic Dragons bequeathed this weapon to a trusted paladin during the Great War of Dragons, granting the righteous spirit a weapon to use against the council's enemies.

Location

Though it has been many years since the Great War of Dragons, Helena Southfall, a half-elf paladin, still possesses Scalehead. Sadly, Helena's adventuring days are over, as she currently resides in a retirement home for elderly adventurers.

Encounter Ideas

  • Hello, Youngster! While visiting a contact or relative in a home for elderly adventures, Helena spots a young, good-souled adventurer. She offers to sell Scalehead to them for 350 (1d6 x 100) gp. As it turns out, homes for elderly adventurers are expensive.
  • Stolen Flail. The orog G'Narla G'Nash and her crew of six orcs recently robbed the inhabitants of the retirement home. Now, they're robbing local merchants and caravans. Witnesses and survivors speak of a dragon-headed flail wielded by the large orog.
  • Bequeathed. Sadly, Helena has passed on. Her will states that Scalehead is to be bequeathed to her distant relative, who happens to be one of the adventurers. Henrich, a very posh and proper gnome lawyer, locates the adventurer, explains the will and gift, and then has them sign seventy-three legal documents.

Progression

Scalehead progresses whenever the attuned creature's Charisma modifier increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Flail), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Dragonspeak. Once per long rest, while holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to speak the command word to grant you the ability to read, speak, and write Draconic for 6 hours.

Uncommon

The duration of Dragonspeak increases to 12 hours.

Dragonhead. When you finish a long rest, you can choose from the below metals, each associated with a particular metallic dragon. When you do, the weapon's head takes the shape and color of that dragon's head, granting it extra damage on a hit until you finish your next long rest.

  • Brass. The weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[bludgeoning]]]{1d6 bludgeoning damage}.

  • Bronze. The weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[lightning]]]{1d6 lightning damage}.

  • Copper. The weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[acid]]]{1d6 acid damage}.

  • Gold. The weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[fire]]]{1d6 fire damage}.

  • Silver. The weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6[cold]]]{1d6 cold damage}.

Rare

You can now change the metal type of Dragonhead when you finish a short or long rest. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Very Rare

The extra damage granted by Dragonhead increases to [[/r 2d6]].

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the extra damage granted by Dragonhead increases to [[/r 3d6]].

Frightful Presence. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to speak the command word to instill fear into your enemies. Each creature of your choice that is within 60 feet of you and aware of you must succeed on a [[/save wisdom 20]]saving throw or become &Reference[frightened] for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to this property for the next 24 hours.

Serpent’s Tongue.name: Serpent’s Tongue
Serpent’s Tongue.text:
The unique snake motif hilt of Serpent's Tongue draws eyes upward to the spear-tip-shaped blade. Few weapons have elicited as much notice… or been responsible for as many murders.

Lore

Metrus Iagus, the self-proclaimed minstrel king, was gifted Serpent's Tongue from a paramour. When a previous lover murdered him with it, it is said the dagger absorbed his glibness and granted it to future wielders. From time to time, Metrus's spirit advises the wielder, though rare is the fool who has not followed that advice to their own doom.

Location

Serpent's Tongue changes hands frequently. It is currently wielded by the treacherous noble seneschal to King Vanin Vandebere and his queen, Ghriehe.

Encounter Ideas

  • Snake Oil Salesperson. The current wielder of Serpent's Tongue attempts to sell the characters magical weapons and potions that are merely dressed up mundane items and liquors.
  • Murderer's Mark. The assassin wielding the dagger has grown jealous of the acclaim one or more of the characters are receiving. They and their gang of eight thugs plan to accost the characters while they sleep.
  • Whispered Pleas. One of the characters hears a whispered, hissing voice emerging from a locked chest containing Serpent's Tongue. A poison needle trap springs on the character that attempts to open the lock without the key.

Progression

Serpent's Tongue progresses each time its wielder succeeds at persuading or deceiving a creature into giving up something it does not want to part with. The creature tricked must have a CR that is at least one higher than the wielder's level, and cannot be &Reference[charmed] or otherwise ensorcelled by magic. The creature's proficiency bonus must increase before the item can increase in power again.

Statistics

Weapon (Dagger), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

You gain proficiency in the Deception skill. If you are already proficient, you gain expertise instead.

Uncommon

Forked Tongue. When you make a [[/skill deception]] check, you can roll 1d4 and add the number rolled to the check. If you use this property and your check fails, the creature you made the check against becomes unfriendly or hostile toward you (the GM decides).

Rare

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Mind Venom. When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can choose to deal psychic damage instead of piercing damage.

Very Rare

The Forked Tongue die increases to [[/r 1d6]].

Erode Confidence. If you succeed on a Charisma (Deception) or Charisma (Persuasion) check against a creature, it is &Reference[charmed] by you for 1 hour, or until you, or an ally, attack it or cast a spell on it. If the creature remains &Reference[charmed] for the duration, its attitude toward you afterward remains neutral or friendly until you take a hostile action toward it. You can use this property a number of times equal to half your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Legendary

Slippery Tongue. You are immune to being &Reference[charmed], and to spells and magical effects that force you to tell the truth, such as zone of truth. Truth-telling magic indicates you are being truthful.

Master of Lies. When you make a [[/skill deception]] check, you treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10. Additionally, when you fail a Charisma (Deception) check, you can choose to succeed instead. If you do, you are incapable of telling a deliberate lie for 24 hours.

Silent Strings.name: Silent Strings
Silent Strings.text:
Its voice is a whisper, its touch a thunderclap.

Lore

The wandering elven minstrel Vulwin Brysatra traveled the land searching for lost songs and forgotten poems. On one such quest, he offered sharp words to a bravo who was deeply offended. In his wounded pride, the bravo slashed Vulwin's neck deeply. While the grievous wound healed, Vulwin never regained the use of his voice.

The loss changed him. Where he once was a firebrand, Vulwin became known for soft melodies and stealth over force of arms. For the rest of his life, he avoided carrying weapons beyond his lyre.

Location

Vulwin fell to The Weeping Lady of Mag Rúnda (banshee) while searching for a lost copy of Karalosis's Reflections. Vulwin's bones, and Silent Strings, lie in a forgotten hall of the Weeping Lady's ruined castle on the edge of a grim moor.

Encounter Ideas

  • Lost Library. The ruined library of Caer Mag Rúnda is said to hold a trove of lost lore, music, poetry, and Silent Strings, but treasure hunters must defeat the undead within the castle walls to claim it.
  • Melancholy Moor. The Lady's weeping has attracted will-o'-wisps who have lured unfortunate souls to drown. Now a horde of zombies threaten to shamble out from the moor.
  • Wandering Ghost. The spirit of Vulwin Brysatra does not rest. The roads near Caer Mag Rúnda have been haunted by a silent ghost, who simply points across the moor. The ghost appears nightly until the bard's remains are laid to rest.

Progression

For Silent Strings to progress, the attuned creature must locate a lost song or poem unknown to any living being. When its tune or rhythm is strummed on the lyre's strings, the weapon's rarity increases. The creature's proficiency bonus must increase before the item can progress again.

Statistics

Weapon (Whip), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Instrument or Weapon. You can use an action to change this magic item's form into an instrument (lyre) or a weapon (whip), or back again. Once per day, while holding the instrument, you can cast the message cantrip.

Uncommon

You can now cast message at will while holding the instrument.

You gain a +1 bonus to Charisma (Performance) checks. In addition, you gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the weapon. Once per long rest, while holding the instrument, you can cast silence.

Rare

The weapon deals an extra [[/r 2d6[thunder]]]{2d6 thunder damage} on a hit. Once per long rest, while holding the instrument, you can cast greater invisibility.

Very Rare

The bonus to Charisma (Performance) checks, and to the attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Stolen Stories. When you damage a creature with the weapon, the target must make a [[/save wisdom 17]]saving throw. On a failed save, you learn a significant story or anecdote about the target. The story might be a secret, a key motivation, a weakness, or a strength. The story might include poetry or a song, as determined by the

GM. You can use this property a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Legendary

You can now cast each of the previously listed spells twice per long rest.

Symphony of the Forgotten. Once per long rest, while holding the instrument, you can use an action to play a forgotten melody. All allies within a 60-foot-radius sphere that can hear you gain temporary hit points equal to 5 + your Charisma modifier and can immediately end one condition affecting them. All enemies within this radius that can hear you must make a [[/save constitution 17]]saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/r 4d10[thunder]]]{4d10 thunder damage} and is &Reference[stunned] until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and is not &Reference[stunned].

The Hivetender’s Edge.name: The Hivetender’s Edge
The Hivetender’s Edge.text:
Open your mind and she will sing you to sleep.

Lore

There are ships that sail between worlds and planes, powered by magics and piloted by creatures those below them have never dreamed of. The great hive ships of the mantis warriors, which sail between stars in search of a new homeworld, are but one amongst many star-faring species.

The ships are home to broods of mantis young, kept in a magically induced stasis and watched over by highly trained, supremely loyal warriors.

To cut a long story very, very short… one of the ships crashed, and was promptly looted by an adventuring party that included the halfling Alvina Merrimeet, whose retirement plan was charging folk admission to see the weird treasures she collected throughout her career. So she plundered everything she could from the ship, including this rather beautiful weapon.

Location

Alvina (knight) is currently the proprietor of an attraction she calls her "Cabinet of Curiosities," a three-room museum stuffed with things she bought, found, looted, or stole on her adventures. The halberd is one of her best pieces. She will sell it, but not for less than 3,000 gp—or she will trade it for something equally unusual and bizarre.

Encounter Ideas

  • Beyond Mortal Ken. A powerful wizard approaches Alvina and begs her to let the wizard destroy the halberd, for the safety of the world. Is the wizard truly scared, or a con artist attempting to obtain a rare and powerful weapon?
  • Guiding Light. When a certain configuration of stars align, the halberd lights up, projecting a beam of iridescent light that points towards the crash site where it first fell to earth—and the former owner who's looking for it.
  • Others Like Us. A patrol of insectile soldiers (use lizardfolk stats), survivors of the crash from which Alvina stole the halberd, arrive in the city in search of it. Suddenly Alvina's extremely keen to get the halberd far, far away from her.

Progression

The Hivetender's Edge progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Halberd), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Signature Weapon. When anyone but the person attuned to this magic weapon picks it up, it emits a high-pitched noise (audible up to 100 feet away) for 10 minutes, without stopping. This includes the first 10 minutes of the attunement process.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Radiant Blade. In dim light or darkness, the weapon glows, emitting bright light in a 30-foot-radius sphere.

Rare

Shield of Light. The weapon projects a circle of shimmering force around itself, granting you a +2 bonus to AC. Shield of Light counts as a shield for any feats, class features, or other abilities that apply to shields.

Hive Thoughts. The weapon picks up the thoughts of insects within 30 feet and telepathically communicates them to its wielder. This is not usually terribly useful, or comprehensible. You can choose to tune these thoughts out or focus on a particular thought.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. Additionally, you can now choose whether or not the Radiant Blade and Signature Weapon properties trigger when the appropriate conditions are met.

Forceful Critical. When you score a critical hit on an attack with this weapon, it deals an extra [[/r 2d6[force]]]{2d6 force damage}.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. In addition, Shield of Light now applies to up to two creatures of your choice who are within 5 feet of you.

The Hunger.name: The Hunger
The Hunger.text:
"Styling the axe to look like a chimera was a nice bit of visual poetry, but the thing trapped inside is much older and more twisted. Pray it does not escape."

— Morrissar, Keeper of Forbidden Lore

Lore

The Saga of Cyldaerdyr tells the story of the titular elven hero outrunning and outwitting an unkillable monster of pure hunger—a massive, twisted, chimera-like beast—and then encasing it in metal. Most today consider the story allegorical, but the weapon and the beast it contains are very real.

Location

The axe is within the ruins of the city that Cyldaerdyr called home an age ago, in a vault built to contain dangerous items. Or, at least, it should be…

Encounter Ideas

  • Cult of Hunger. An aristocrat bankrolls an expedition to recover the axe, which they frame as a trinket of cultural value. Secretly, they work for a cult seeking to destroy the weapon to free the beast inside.
  • It Escaped. A string of gory murders paralyzes a city and the party is hired to find and stop the killer. They discover the killer is a bandit that somehow found the axe and became twisted by it.
  • Order of Cyldaerdyr. The scholar Morrissar hires the party to escort him to the axe's vault. He secretly belongs to an order that maintains its seals. When disaster strikes, he passes that charge to a character.

Progression

The Hunger progresses each time its wielder kills an exceptionally powerful Beast or Monstrosity, as determined by the GM.

Statistics

Weapon (Greatsaxe), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

As this magic weapon progresses, it unlocks properties known as Bestial Aspects. Activating or deactivating an Aspect uses a bonus action. Aspects last until you finish a long rest. You can have a number of Aspects active at once equal to half your proficiency bonus, rounded up. If you try to exceed your maximum number of Aspects, the oldest Aspect immediately ends, and then the new Aspect applies. The saving throw DC for Aspects is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier.

Aspect of the Goat. You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Aspect of the Lion. If you move at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hit them with an attack using this weapon, they must succeed on a [[/save strength]] saving throw or be knocked &Reference[prone].

Rare

Aspect of the Dragon. When you score a critical hit with this weapon, a cone of fire erupts from it in a direction you choose as if you cast burning hands (save DC equal to your Aspect save DC).

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Aspect of the Wyvern. Once per short or long rest, when you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can force it to succeed on a [[/save constitution]] saving throw against your Aspect save DC or become &Reference[poisoned] for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

Aspect of the Predator. When you kill a creature with an attack using this weapon, you gain temporary hit points equal to its challenge rating. In addition, you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

Once per long rest, while this Aspect is active, you can choose to gain hyper-acute senses for 1 hour. For the duration, you can detect the location of any creatures within 1,000 feet that are missing any of their hit points. You can home in on a specific creature and if the creature is moving, you know the direction of its movement. Additionally, your movement speed is increased by 10 feet.

The Rat-King.name: The Rat-King
The Rat-King.text:
"At first, I thought the squeaking was old metal—but after oiling it a hundred times, I'm forced to conclude the flail's heads are just talkative."

—Lech Rusty, mercenary

Lore

Decades ago, a swarm of sentient, malevolent rats devoured most of the village of Abershine. When the vermin threatened to spill into the neighboring towns, the local lord bargained with a hag, Baba Pennyweld, to deal with them. She tied the rats' tails together and drowned them in molten steel, creating this many-headed flail.

Location

The Rat-King is held by Baba Pennyweld (hag) in her scrap-metal hut outside Abershine. She sometimes lends it to adventurers who agree to run errands on her behalf— and if the adventurers die, the flail always crawls home.

Encounter Ideas

  • Ongoing Debt. The Lord of Abershine has been under the ruthless thumb of Baba Pennyweld since he asked for her help. He begs the characters to free him from his bargain by defeating the hag or stealing the flail.
