  • Party Crashers. The local villagers are holding a feast, and Baba Pennyweld is eager to ruin it. She offers The Rat-King to the characters if they sneak into town and use its hungry heads to gobble up the feast.
  • Rats on the Move. As the characters approach the entrance of a dungeon, they notice The Rat-King crawling out, still attached to the hand of a dead adventurer. Where could it be going?

Progression

When you kill a Medium-sized creature, you can allow The Rat-King to consume its corpse, progressing from common to uncommon. For each subsequent rarity, the required size of corpse increases by one category, to a maximum of Gargantuan. Each consumption takes [[/r 1d4 #days]]{1d4 days}. The Rat-King cannot progress more than once per month.

Statistics

Weapon (Flail), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Vermin Speech. You can communicate in a limited manner with rats and other rodents. They can understand the meaning of your words, though you have no special ability to understand them in return. You have advantage on all Charisma checks you make to influence them.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest. You can expend a number of charges to cast the following spells from it: animal friendship (1 charge), animal messenger (2 charges), and speak with animals (1 charge). When you cast animal friendship or speak with animals this way, you can only target and communicate with rodents. When you cast animal messenger this way, one of the weapon's heads untangles itself and delivers your message, reappearing when the spell ends.

Rare

The weapon's total number of charges increases to 4.

Gnawing Wave. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to swing it and unleash a 30-foot cone of hungry metal rats. Each creature in the area must make a [[/save dexterity 14]]saving throw, taking [[/r 8d6[piercing]]]{8d6 piercing damage} on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Until the start of your next turn, the area is covered in swarming rats, making it difficult terrain.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, the weapon's total number of charges increases to 6, and the save DC of Gnawing Wave increases to 16.

In addition, a creature that fails its saving throw against Gnawing Wave is covered in hungry rats and must repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns. On a failure, the target takes an additional [[/r 2d6[piercing]]]{2d6 piercing damage}. On a success, the effect ends for it.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. In addition, the save DC of Gnawing Wave increases to 18, its damage increases to 10d6 for the initial save and 4d6 for subsequent saves, and you can now use it twice between long rests.

Tidal Lash.name: Tidal Lash
Tidal Lash.text:
"It flows with the delicate beauty of a trickling stream, but strikes with the weight of an ocean wave."

—Lambent Bloom, nereid

Lore

This whip was formed when an ocean goddess tore a riptide from the deep sea and trapped it in a seashell as a gift for her beloved mortal daughter, an ancient seafaring adventurer called Maristela the Reefborn. Maristela wielded the water-whip in many of her heroic tales, including slaying a kraken, challenging a demigod of the winds, and pioneering an important route across the ocean.

Location

Tidal Lash is buried with Maristela alongside her other treasures in the Reefborn Tomb, a coral temple far beneath the waves. The tomb is filled with traps and aquatic servants.

Encounter Ideas

  • Divine Patron. One of the characters is visited by a servant of the ocean goddess, who urges them to seek Tidal Lash and become her champion before a great evil arrives.
  • Wrath of the Seas. A fearsome pirate lord (bandit captain) has stolen Tidal Lash and now wreaks havoc on merchants and sailors everywhere—including the characters.
  • The Reefborn Hoard. The characters are hired to protect an archeologist (noble) as they explore the Reefborn Tomb and recover its many treasures. As they explore, Tidal Lash calls to the characters, hungry for new adventures.

Progression

Tidal Lash is bound to the ocean goddess who created it, and progresses each time its wielder performs an important task for her, as determined by the GM. The goddess favors wielders who protect the oceans, slay terrible sea monsters, and embark on long ocean voyages to undiscovered places.

Statistics

Weapon (Whip), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Attacks made with this magic weapon while underwater do not impose disadvantage.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Riptide. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to slam the target with a heavy wave. The target must succeed on a [[/save strength 13]]saving throw or be pushed 10 feet in a direction of your choice.

Rare

The weapon's total number of charges increases to 5, and the DC of Riptide increases to 15. In addition, when you use Riptide, instead of pushing a target that fails its saving throw, you can hold it in place with a miniature whirlpool, reducing its speed to 0 until the end of its next turn.

Water Breath. While holding this weapon, you can breathe underwater.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, the weapon's total number of charges increases to 7, and the save DC of Riptide increases to 17.

Command the Waves. You can use an action to expend 4 charges to cast control water.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, and the save DC of Riptide increases to 19.

Octopus Strike. Once per short or long rest, you can use your action to make an attack with this weapon against any number of creatures within 5 feet of you, with a separate attack roll for each target. You can expend 3 charges as part of this action to use Riptide against each target hit this way.

Tomato Vine.name: Tomato Vine
Tomato Vine.text:
One quick splat and they’re gone!

Lore

Ingrid Bellweather, a halfling farmer, became absolutely fed up with the number of rabbits, deer, turtles, and other creatures that invaded her garden. A local druid provided Ingrid with this sling, which produces tomatoes if the ammunition pocket is not loaded with a sling bullet.

Location

Ingrid still owns the sling, but rarely uses it. Over the years, and after countless uses of the sling, she has trained the animals to stay away from her vegetable garden. However, this has had an adverse effect. Her cottage and garden are now surrounded by tomato plants, growing rampantly wherever the sling's magic ammunition met its mark.

Encounter Ideas

  • Lost in Tomatoes. The adventurers find themselves lost in a maze of tall vines loaded with succulent tomatoes. Smoke from Ingrid's chimney leads to her cottage.
  • Sling for Sale. Ingrid, no longer requiring the sling, places an advertisement on a local notice board, offering to sell "A Magical Sling" for 100 gp. The advertisement states, "find Ingrid in the tomato field for more information."
  • Rumble in the Tomato Jungle. The party witnesses Ingrid using the sling against a herd of deer that have recently started eating sweet corn and squash blossoms from her garden.

Progression

Tomato Vine progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Sling), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Ammunition. If you load no ammunition in this magic weapon, it produces its own, automatically creating one tomato (which counts as magic ammunition) when you make a ranged attack with it. Ammunition created by the weapon rots into goo 1 minute after being created.

Uncommon

The weapon has 4 charges, and regains all expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Caustic Tomato. Immediately before making a ranged attack with this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to create a black tomato plump with acid, which deals an extra [[/r (4)[acid]]]{4 acid damage} to the target on a hit. Fruit of Life. You can expend 2 charges to create a juicy, red tomato that restores 2d4 + 2 hit points if consumed. This tomato can also be loaded into the weapon and used as ammunition. A target hit by a ranged attack using this ammunition takes no damage and instead regains 1d4 + 1 hit points.

Rare

The hit points restored by consuming a Fruit of Life tomato increase to 2d6 + 4 and the hit points restored by being hit with one increase to 1d6 + 2, and the acid damage of Caustic Tomato increases to 6.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. The hit points restored by Fruit of Life increase to 3d6 + 6, the hit points restored by being hit with one increase to 2d6 + 3, and the acid damage of Caustic Tomato increases to 8. In addition, the total number of charges increases to 6.

Rotten Tomato. Immediately before making a ranged attack with this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to create a mushy, rotten tomato. This ranged attack deals the weapon's normal damage and, on a hit, the target must make a [[/save wisdom 17]]saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes an additional 1d4 + [[/r (3)[psychic]]]{3 psychic damage} and has disadvantage on the next attack roll or Charisma saving throw it makes before the end of its next turn.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, the hit points restored by Fruit of Life increase to 3d6 + 10, the hit points restored by being hit with one increase to 2d6 + 8, and the acid damage of Caustic Tomato increases to 10. In addition, the total number of charges increases to 8.

Trident of R’lyeh.name: Trident of R’lyeh
Trident of R’lyeh.text:
Wielding this weapon’s blasphemous power comes with a cost.

Lore

Forged thousands of years ago in the city of R'lyeh before it sank beneath the waves, the trident was a gift from Father Dagon and Mother Hydra, greatest of the deep ones, to their favorite disciple, Iaunulelbh. Deep ones are an ancient race of sea-dwelling fishfolk with bulging frog-like eyes, greyish green skin, and webbed feet.

Location

The Trident of R'lyeh has changed hands many times over the centuries, but is currently claimed by Usha-zueth, a Deep One high priest of Cthulhu who presides over the Drowned Cathedral, an underwater cavern complex beneath the infamous Whalebone Reef. Usha-zueth has the statistics of a sahuagin with 36 hit points and the Dark Devotion and Spellcasting traits of a cult fanatic.

Encounter Ideas

  • Shipwreck! The characters' ship crashes into Whalebone Reef, forcing them to seek refuge in a sea cave leading to the Drowned Cathedral.
  • Fishy Behaviour. There is something odd about Carabella Tackleknot, local priest of the remote fishing village of Driftwood Bight. Why is she visiting the jetty at midnight, and why does she sometimes swim out to Whalebone Reef?
  • Sunken Treasure. The characters obtain a map showing the location of the wreck of the Silver Shark, a treasure-laden pirate ship that sank in the treacherous waters around Whalebone Reef.

Progression

The Trident of R'lyeh progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases. Each time the weapon progresses, its owner's body changes to more closely resemble a deep one.

Curse of Cthulhu. A creature attuned to the weapon cannot end the attunement voluntarily. A greater restoration spell breaks the attunement, but it takes it takes a number of days equal to 1d6 times the creature's proficiency bonus for their body to return to its original appearance.

Statistics

Weapon (Trident), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

When you attune to this magic weapon, tiny gills appear on your neck. You can breathe underwater for 10 minutes at a time.

Uncommon

Your gills now allow you to breathe underwater indefinitely.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Blessing of the Deep Ones. Your feet and hands become webbed. You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Rare

Return. The weapon returns to your hand immediately after it is used to make a ranged attack.

Shocking Stab. The weapon has 3 charges, and regains 1d3 expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to deal an extra [[/r 1d8[lightning]]]{1d8 lightning damage}, and the target cannot take reactions until the start of its next turn.

Blessing of Mother Hydra. Your eyes change shape, becoming bulbous and fish-like. You gain darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision from your race, its range increases by 60 feet.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the damage dealt by Shocking Stab increases to [[/r 2d8]]. In addition, the weapon's total number of charges increases to 6, and it now regains 1d4 + 2 expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Ally from the Depths. While underwater, you can expend 3 charges to summon a hunter shark or 5 charges to summon two hunter sharks. The sharks arrive in [[/r 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}. The sharks are allies to you and your companions. In combat, they share your initiative count, but take their turns immediately after yours. They obey your verbal commands (no action required by you). If you do not issue any, they take the Dodge action and use their move to avoid danger. The sharks disappear after 1 hour or when they are reduced to 0 hit points, you are killed, or you dismiss them.

Blessing of Father Dagon. Your skin becomes gray and scaly, and your hair falls out. You gain resistance to cold damage.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, and the damage dealt by Shocking Stab increases to [[/r 3d8]]. The weapon's total number of charges increases to 10, and it now regains 1d6 + 4 expended charges when you finish a long rest.

Doom of Sunken R'lyeh. While you are within 10 miles of the sea, you can expend 7 charges to cast earthquake (save DC 19).

Blessing of Great Cthulhu. Your body fully transforms into that of a deep one (sahuagin), and you gain the following traits:

  • You have advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that does not have all its hit points.
  • You can magically command any shark within 120 feet of you, using a limited telepathy.
  • You can read, write, and speak Sahuagin.
  • Your swimming speed is 10 feet more than your walking speed.
  • If you go more than one week without becoming immersed beneath the surface of the sea, you gain one level of exhaustion each time you finish a long rest.

Trouble Clef.name: Trouble Clef
Trouble Clef.text:
Copper embossed musical notes scroll across the limbs of this crossbow.

Lore

The most talented arbalist of a previous age crafted this hand crossbow for his muse, the high priestess of the god of sonnet and song. The god, so pleased with the crafter's devotion and skill, blessed the weapon and guides it into the hand of a devoted follower whenever the forces of art and creativity are threatened.

Location

The god that blessed this weapon plucks it from the Material Plane when its holder dies. Decades may pass before it is returned to the mortal world as a gift to an adherent in a time of great need. The last wielder of Trouble Clef was killed while reclaiming a temple to their god that had been lost to demonic corruption.

Encounter Ideas

  • Song From On High. A character wakes from a dream in which an agent of their deity warns of a coming disaster to the faith, and finds the crossbow resting in their hand.
  • Dirge Of Doom. Across the kingdom, performers are being murdered and their hearts removed. The villain, a fallen champion of the god of song, wields Trouble Clef.
  • Challenge Accepted. A rival performer claims that their works of songcraft are superior to one of the characters, and challenges them to create a song that will silence the birds and beasts. The character receives Trouble Clef as a reward for succeeding at the challenge.

Progression

Trouble Clef progresses whenever the attuned creature gains an Ability Score Improvement.

Statistics

Weapon (Hand Crossbow), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement by a Spellcaster)

Common

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to transform it into any musical instrument with which you are proficient, or back into its weapon form.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Paramount. When you roll initiative while carrying this weapon, you add your proficiency bonus to your initiative roll.

Rare

Bass Note. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, you can choose to expend a spell slot to deal an extra [[/r 1d8[thunder]]]{1d8 thunder damage} per level of the slot expended to the target. Creatures within 5 feet of the target must make a [[/save constitution]] saving throw against your spell save DC, taking the same amount of damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Irrepressible. You cannot be &Reference[deafened] while wielding this weapon and you are unaffected by spells and other magical effects that prevent you from casting spells with verbal components.

Legendary

Prima Donna Performance. When you roll initiative and have no spell slots remaining, you can expend a Hit Die or Bardic Inspiration die to recover a number of slots whose total is equal to half the number rolled on the die (minimum 1). For example, if you roll an 8 on the die, you could recover a number of spell slots whose total equals 4, such as two 2nd-level slots, one 3rd-level slot and one 1st-level slot, or another configuration of spell slots that adds up to 4. Once you have recovered 6 levels worth of slots this way, you must finish a long rest before you can recover any more.

Whispers of Treason.name: Whispers of Treason
Whispers of Treason.text:
Never listen to an imp.

Lore

Imps may be the bottom-feeders of the infernal ranks, but many believe they are every bit as clever as an archdevil. One intrepid imp got ahold of a djinni and demanded "immortality and a position of influence." The djinni transformed them into this bow and gifted it to a human prince. Predictably, chaos ensued.

Location

Whispers of Treason is a coveted possession of a local noble, crime boss, or other leadership figure.

Encounter Ideas

  • Djinn't See That Coming. The party encounters the same djinni that crafted the bow. They respond to any wish for power by gifting the bow to the party.
  • Crime Pays. A formerly negligible criminal is rapidly consolidating power as their rivals wash up dead. The party is hired to find out how. The criminal wields Whispers of Treason.
  • Soul Proprietor. A devil that the imp inside the bow once served has taken an interest in the imp's fate. He gifts the party the bow, "no strings attached." However, the fiend secretly schemes to siphon away the souls the imp collects, citing the imp's former contract.

Progression

Whispers of Treason progresses when it consumes enough souls, as determined by the GM.

Statistics

Weapon (Shortbow), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

This magic weapon can only be destroyed by an effect that would destroy an artifact.

Sentience. Whispers of Treason is a sentient lawful evil weapon with an Intelligence of 11, a Wisdom of 12, and a Charisma of 14. It has hearing and darkvision out to a range of 120 feet, and can speak, read, and understand Common and Infernal.

The weapon seeks to ingratiate itself with a powerful person, then convince or trick them into acquiring souls for it. Its aim is to acquire enough souls to descend to a more powerful form of devil, freeing itself from its bow form in the process. Conflict arises if the wielder refuses to aid Whisper's schemes.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

This weapon has 6 charges. When an attack from this weapon reduces a creature that is not a Construct or Undead to 0 hit points, it regains 1 charge.

Infernal Brass Arrow. As part of making a ranged weapon attack with this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to summon an infernal brass arrow that deals an additional [[/r 2d6[fire]]]{2d6 fire damage} on a hit.

Rare

Infernal Iron Arrow. You can expend 2 charges to summon an infernal iron arrow. A creature hit by this arrow must use their reaction, if available, to make an attack against an allied creature of their choice they can see.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the fire damage of Infernal Brass Arrow increases to [[/r 4d6]].

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

Infernal Obsidian Arrow. You can expend 4 charges to summon an infernal obsidian arrow. A creature hit by this arrow must choose to either take [[/r 8d6[psychic]]]{8d6 psychic damage} that cannot be reduced, or be &Reference[charmed] by you for 1 minute and, while &Reference[charmed], use their action on their turn to make an attack against an allied creature of their choice they can see. A creature that is immune to being &Reference[charmed] must take the damage.

Whisperwind.name: Whisperwind
Whisperwind.text:
Crafted from a branch of the oldest treant in the realm of the fey, this glaive is imbued with the essence of the wind itself.

Lore

For eternity, a mighty treant shepherded over the trees of the fey realms, using the wind to carry messages for its flock and to warn the realms' beings in times of trouble. When a corrupted archfey threatened to twist the enchanted forest to his wicked design, the treant bestowed one of its branches in the form of an enchanted glaive named Whisperwind to an elf champion who saved the forest. With each swing, the weapon is said to whisper secrets of the wind, granting its wielder the ability to move like a breeze and strike with the fury of a tempest.

Location

Whisperwind was last seen marking the gravesite of the elf hero, appearing as a sapling that is forever blossoming in the fey realms.

Encounter Ideas

  • Gale's Testament. An oracle implores the party to retrieve Whisperwind, believing it's the key to stopping a cataclysmic storm unleashed by a vengeful storm giant.
  • Whispers on the Wind. As the party enters an enchanted grove at the boundary of the fey realms, Whisperwind telepathically reaches out to them through a gentle breeze. The weapon implores the characters to confront a green hag who has turned the forest into a nasty bog, killing the trees and natural wildlife.
  • Thief of Breezes. A notorious thief has stolen Whisperwind and offers it to the highest bidder. However, whoever possesses the weapon is cursed by fey magic that can only be broken by returning Whisperwind to the resting place of the treant that created it. There, the ghost of the elf champion gifts it to a character with a kind heart. While cursed, whenever the possessor rolls a 1 on a d20 roll, they must use that roll, regardless of advantage or other effects that allow a character to reroll d20 rolls (other than Inspiration).

Progression

Whisperwind progresses as the attuned creature bests elements of wind. Specific milestones are determined by the GM, but may include defending nature, or surviving natural or magical storms.

Statistics

Weapon (Glaive), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast message.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Sturdy Retreat. When you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, that creature has disadvantage on opportunity attacks made against you until the start of your next turn.

Rare

Razorwind Strike. Once per long rest, when you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can force each creature within a 60-feet-long, 5-feet-wide line extending from the weapon in the direction of the target to make a [[/save dexterity 15]]saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes [[/r 6d6[slashing]]]{6d6 slashing damage} and is pushed 5 feet in a direction of your choice. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and is not pushed.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.

Gathering Gale. Once per long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to gain a flying speed of 60 feet for 1 minute. While flying this way, ranged attacks made against you have disadvantage.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, and the slashing damage of Razorwind Strike increases to [[/r 8d6]].

Tempest-Toss. Once per long rest, if a creature scores a critical hit against you, you can use your reaction to cast storm of vengeance (save DC 17).

Wilderland.name: Wilderland
Wilderland.text:
This trident is blessed by woodland creatures.

Lore

To help protect their forest from intrusion, the woodland spirits created this weapon for their champion, a treant named Oaksaple.

Location

It is rumored that Wilderland is hidden somewhere in the forest. However, few have entered the forest as stories of Oaksaple's power and stories of the weapon deter anyone from entering.

Encounter Ideas

  • Rare Resource. A crime lord hires the party to enter the forest and gather a rare mushroom. They defer telling the characters about Oaksaple and the weapon unless asked about the forest's threats.
  • Missing Lumberjacks. A village, located on the outskirts of the forest, hires the adventurers to enter the forest to look for missing lumberjacks.
  • Proud Adventurers. A group of adventurers, who recently entered the forest and killed Oaksaple, flaunt Wilderland while celebrating in a tavern. Later that night, the tavern and its patrons are accosted by several awakened trees and awakened shrubs, determined to retrieve the weapon.

Progression

Wilderland progresses whenever the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Trident), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Sure-Footed. While holding this magic weapon, you gain a +1 bonus to saving throws made against effects that would knock you &Reference[prone].

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, and Sure-Footed now grants you a bonus equal to your proficiency bonus.

Charge. If you move at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hit it with an attack using this weapon on the same turn, the target takes an additional [[/r 2d6[piercing]]]{2d6 piercing damage}. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a [[/save strength 12]]saving throw or be knocked &Reference[prone].

Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the save DC for Charge increases to 14.

Beast Sense. Twice per long rest, when you roll initiative, you can choose to roll with advantage.

Very Rare

The save DC for Charge increases to 16.

Fight or Flight. Once per long rest, while you have fewer than half your hit points remaining, you can choose Fight or Flight.

  • Fight. You gain temporary hit points equal to four times your proficiency bonus and have advantage on all ability checks, saving throws, and attack rolls you make before the start of your next turn.

  • Flight. Until the end of your next turn, your speed is doubled, your AC increases by 2, and you have advantage on Dexterity saving throws.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3, the DC for Charge increases to 18, and its additional piercing damage increases to [[/r 3d6]].

Glyph.name: Glyph
Glyph.text:
Arcane runes run from the tip of this longsword’s mithral blade to its hook-like pommel.

Lore

Glyph was crafted by the archmage founders of the Blue Flame Combine, a consortium of mage-killing wizards. The Combine carefully chooses the blade's wielder, and spares no effort to recover the weapon when it falls out of their hands.

Location

Six months ago, Glyph's wielder was killed by the lich Poitreva. The lich then gifted the blade to her champion, the tiefling archmage Helle Kystral, and commanded her to use it to hunt and kill the members of the Blue Flame Combine.

Encounter Ideas

  • Mage Hunter. Suspecting one of the characters is associated with the Blue Flame Combine, Glyph's wielder stalks them to determine the best time to strike.
  • Reclaim the Blade. An archmage hires the characters to find and retrieve Glyph. Upon the successful return of the blade, the mage offers to become the patron of the characters.
  • Fallen to Darkness. While the characters are taking some downtime, a quartet of driders steals Glyph for their mistress, a drow priest. The victim of the theft seeks assistance in retrieving their property.

Progression

Glyph progresses as the attuned creature grows in magical power. The weapon's rarity increases each time the wielder gains spell slots of the following levels: 2nd level (uncommon), 3rd level (rare), 5th level (very rare), and 7th level (legendary).

Statistics

Weapon (Longsword), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement by a Bard, Sorcerer, or Wizard)

Common

You are proficient with this magic weapon even if you are not proficient with longswords. In addition, you can cast comprehend languages using your spellcasting ability and spell slots.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

Arcane Resistance. Once per long rest, if you fail a saving throw against a spell or other magical effect, you can choose to expend a spell slot to reroll. If you do so, you must use the new roll.

Rare

Cleave Magic. While holding this weapon, you can cast counterspell using your spellcasting ability and spell slots. Once per long rest, when a creature within 5 feet of you casts a spell, you can use your reaction to cast counterspell without expending a spell slot.

Deflect Magic. If a creature makes a spell attack against you, you can use your reaction to expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher to impose disadvantage on the creature's attack roll. You can use this property a number of times equal to half your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Very Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and you can now use Arcane Resistance twice between long rests. In addition, when you use Arcane Resistance on a saving throw against an area of effect spell and succeed on your reroll, all creatures of your choice that you can see within 10 feet of you can reroll their saving throws against the same effect.

Legendary

Mute Opposition. Once per short or long rest, when you hit a creature with an attack using this weapon, the target must make a [[/save constitution]] saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature is muted until the start of your next turn and cannot cast spells that include a verbal component.

Legendary Resistance. Once per short or long rest, when you fail a saving throw against a spell or other magical effect, you can expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher to succeed instead.

Krampus Cane.name: Krampus Cane
Krampus Cane.text:
While Santa dispenses gifts of hope and joy, Krampus bequeaths these vile canes.

Lore

It is said that Krampus, the horned anthropomorphic figure who often stands opposite Santa during the winter holidays, grants these magical canes to those who believe in him. However, one must be worthy of such a gift, following evil traditions and of a non-good nature.

Location

There are several Krampus canes throughout the realm. While a few locations are listed in the following Encounter Ideas, the weapon can be found nearly anywhere, including being wielded by an unruly, intoxicated bar patron.

Encounter Ideas

  • A Gift from Krampus. While good-hearted adventurers may be visited by Santa, Krampus visits those with an evil heart, bequeathing them either a magic item to help them in their struggles against good, or a Krampus cane. A particularly evil adventurer may be visited by Krampus while their companions celebrate Christmas.
  • Museum. The characters notice a Krampus cane in a local museum. If they do not recognize the weapon and know its lore, an archmage does, and steals the weapon from the museum.
  • Mother Krampus. Mother Krampus is an evil night hag who despises Christmas and enjoys kidnapping children on Christmas Eve. Krampus, approving of the hag's actions, gave her a Krampus cane.

Progression

Krampus canes increase in power as the attuned creature's proficiency bonus increases.

Statistics

Weapon (Club), Rarity Varies (Requires Attunement)

Common

Stench of Death. Once per long rest, while holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to speak its command word, causing it to emit the foul stench of death and decay for 1 minute. The smell is noticeable by any creature within 60 feet of you that can smell.

Uncommon

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. In addition, while Stench of Death is active, attacks made with this weapon deal an extra [[/r 2d6[necrotic]]]{2d6 necrotic damage}.

Rare

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the extra necrotic damage dealt by Stench of Death increases to [[/r 3d6]]. Stench of Death can now be activated with a bonus action, its duration increases to 5 minutes, and you regain its use when you finish a short or long rest.

Very Rare

Once per short or long rest, while holding this weapon, you can use an action to speak the command word to activate one of the following properties, each of which has a duration of 2 hours.

Goatshape. You transform yourself into a goat, as per the polymorph spell. Form of Krampus. Your body takes on several of Krampus' physical traits and special attacks.

  • Cloven Hooves. Your feet transform into cloven hooves. You have advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock you &Reference[prone], and your movement is unaffected by difficult terrain.

  • Horns. Long, pointed horns erupt from your skull. For the duration, you gain the following magical attack and ability.

    • Ram. Melee Weapon Attack (Horns): Proficiency Bonus plus STR Modifier to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 3d6 + STR Modifier piercing damage.

    • Charge. If you move at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hit it with a Ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra [[/r 3d6[piercing]]]{3d6 piercing damage}.

Legendary

The bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. The duration of Stench of Death increases to 10 minutes, and its extra necrotic damage increases to [[/r 4d6]]. In addition, while Stench of Death is active, any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of you must succeed on a [[/save constitution 17]]saving throw or be &Reference[poisoned] until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to Stench of Death for 24 hours.

Also, when using Goatshape, you can now choose to polymorph into a goat or a giant goat.
